headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good day, and welcome to the Roper Industries Fourth Quarter and Full Year Financial Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I will now turn the call over to John Humphrey, Chief Financial Officer. Please go ahead.
componenttext: Good day, and welcome to the Roper Industries Fourth Quarter and Full Year Financial Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I will now turn the call over to John Humphrey, Chief Financial Officer. Please go ahead.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, David, and thank you, all for joining us this morning as we discuss the results for the fourth quarter and full year 2010. Joining me this morning is Brian Jellison, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Paul Soni, Vice President
componenttext:
Thank you, David, and thank you, all for joining us this morning as we discuss the results for the fourth quarter and full year 2010. Joining me this morning is Brian Jellison, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Paul Soni, Vice President and Controller.
Earlier this morning, we issued a press release announcing our financial results. The press release also includes replay information for today's call. We prepared slides to accompany today's call, which are available through the webcast and also are available on the website at www.roperind.com.
So if you turn to Slide 2, we'll begin with our Safe Harbor statement. During the course of today's call, we'll be making forward-looking statements which are subject to the risks and uncertainties that are described in this page and as detailed in our SEC filings. You should looked into today's call in the context of that information.
And now if you'll please turn to Slide 3. I'll turn the call over to Brian Jellison, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer. After his prepared remarks, we'll take some questions from our telephone participants. Brian?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, everyone. We'll start off by just saying the outline for today, we'll talk first about our full year financial results here for 2010 and then go into the enterprise results on a financial basis for the fourth quarter. Then we'll l
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, everyone. We'll start off by just saying the outline for today, we'll talk first about our full year financial results here for 2010 and then go into the enterprise results on a financial basis for the fourth quarter. Then we'll look at the individual segment details and the outlook for each one of those segments for 2011. I'll talk a little bit about sort of beyond the numbers, things that happened in 2010 that have been learnings for us during the downturn as we come out, and then establish our 2011 guidance and move to Q&A for you.
So next slide. For 2010, our enterprise financial results are just fundamentally in every category, an all-time record whether it's orders, sales, backlog, earnings, EBITDA, cash flow, anything one can think of. Our EBITDA margins for the year reached 26.7%, of course, another all-time high.
Our operating teams performed exceptionally well, and we enjoyed full year EBITDA leverage on the next dollar of incremental sales of 40%. We had a record asset loss, we will have more to talk about there. And for the first time, we ordered $500 million in operating cash flow for the calendar year.
Our free cash flow became 20% of sales. We look around it, capital market competitors for us, and many of the S&P 500 businesses don't enjoy 20% operating margin, a little 20% free cash flow to sales. Our free cash flow exceeded net income for the 13th consecutive year. We increased our dividend this year by 16% for 2011 after raising them last year, 15% for 2009.
Our book-to-bill ratio for the full year was 1.06. This has created a record backlog of $785 million, which is up $220 million from our year-end backlog last year, and I think one of the things that's amazing for us is that the excellence that we had really permeated throughout the enterprise with only to our three businesses not participating.
Next slide. Our full-year income statement, you can see here bookings reach  about $2.5 billion for the first-time. Our bookings were up 25% on the year. Our net sales were up 16%, 8% organic for the year but of course, it continued to move up throughout the year starting out the year with a minus 3% and then a plus 5%, and a plus 14% and closing out at a plus 15%. Our gross margin, again, spectacular 53.4% for the year, up 250 basis points over the prior year.
Our income from operations for the year was up 30% at $514 million, and I would like to remind people that we had about $86 million of non-cash and capital intangible amortization that depresses those income margin. So our operating profit margins reached 21.6% for the year. If you add back the non-cash tangible amortization, you're over 25%.
Our interest expense was up just modestly at $67 million, and the tax rate was slightly down this year at 28.1% versus 29.5% for the prior year. That left us with net earnings of $323 million, up from last year's $239 million, and full-year diluted earnings per share of $3.34 versus $2.58 last year.
Next slide. Our full-year operating cash flow as we said before was $500 million, that was up 36% from last year's $367 million, and our operating cash flow as a percent of sales, you can see it continues to trend up. It was 16% in '07, 19% in '08, dropped by a point to 18% in the great recession, and it's now back to 21% here in 2010, and our cash conversion, or on operating cash flow basis was 155% of net income.
Next slide. On a full-year free cash flow basis, the $500 million drops to $471 million, as we have about $29 million of CapEx. Our free cash flow as I said was 20% of revenue, up 300 basis points from last year. We had stellar execution, which you'll see our asset velocity numbers in just a minute. And you could see here, you've gone from 122% free cash flow in 2006 to 128%, and then 143%. I think, 2008 that was of course, a record for us. People expected with fallout in a downturn, and we did, we held the 143%. Now this year us to start back up, we're at 146%. So really, sustained cash flow performance conversion despite very difficult economic markets during that five-year period.
Next slide. On asset velocity, this is sort of a slight internal year because we focus so much on it, it takes our breath away. You look here at 12/31/10, and our inventory is down to 6.6% of revenue and receivables at 14.8%, payables and accruals at 16%. So when you add inventory in receivables and Subtract be able that accruals, which is our core measurement, we are at 5.4% of sales. if you go back to '07 and we were at a 10% of sales, and those of you who followed us a long time though, the numbers you could dramatically higher than that.
And when you think about 5.4%, the support your revenue and you've got 26.7% EBITDA and 20% free cash flow to sales on a 5.4% number, it truly is outstanding performance and speaks volumes about this asset-like business strategy and execution that we put in place.
Next slide. On a balance sheet perspective, we closed the year up with $270 million in cash and $520 million in undrawn revolver, so it's that about $800 million existing capacity. Our net debt to EBITDA is at only $1.07 billion, and our EBITDA and interest coverage is at 10x. We've invested $900 million in the last 50 months in transactions and certainly, we're positioned to capture opportunities at that level in the next 15 days.
Next slide. We'll here, we look at the specific Q4 enterprise results. Once again, to an all-time right heard. Truly remarkable quarter fries. Sales were up 23% to $679 million, and organic growth represented 15%. Our backlog at $785 million is up 39% from the prior year. Net earnings were up 49% to $107 million. EBITDA at $200 million in the quarter kind of breath-taking number, up $53 million from a year ago, and EBITDA margins at 29.4%, I just asked people to compare those to gross margins from your S&P 500 diversified companies. 
Our free cash flow at 22% of sales and up 21% to $147 million, again, just very strong and by closing out the year, as strong as we have, truly gives us a lot of confidence going in to 2011, it will have another record here in 2011.
Next slide. Our Q4 income statement, you can see here sales and bookings of 23% both organic and 15%. Book to bill closed down at 102%. Gross profit, 54.7%, up 210 basis points from a year ago. Operating margins at 24.5%, and I'd remind you again about our non-cash intangible amortization which is about $25 million in the quarter. So another 3.7%, you take a 20 4.5% and a $3.7 million, you get an EBITDA number of $20.2 million in the quarter ended. 
Interest expense, the same in the fourth quarter of oh then as it was last year. Our tax rate dropped to 27.7%. Our guidance was for it to be a little bit above that. We had the benefit of the R&D tax credit there in the quarter.  Net earnings were up 49% as we said to $107 million, and earnings per share on a debts basis, $110 million versus $0.77.
When we get specifically into each of the segments, we'll talk a little bit about how the fourth quarter was and more importantly, what we think 2011 looks like, next slide. So if you look at the margin performance in the segments, you can see Our Avenue was at 50% gross margins and industrial, 52%, energy, 56%, and medical and imaging 63%. Just virtually, the same EBITDA performance along the way to 31%, 32%, 31%, 32%, which excludes the corporate costs that brings us down to our enterprise number. 
We had really exceptional margins throughout the enterprise with really no segment lagging very much. Of course, the RF is made up of two entirely different kind of entities now, with a little less than half of it being totally transportation and administrative activities, which of course carry much lower margins.  And then the majority of the business in our Software-as-a-Service and other RF products basis which enjoy the higher margins.
Next slide. In the RF Technology segment, you can see orders were up 4%, sales up 17%, organic sales were up 6%, finally returning to organic growth in the radio frequency. Our CBORD and Horizon software businesses had excellent results, with campus security, which is picked back up, as people are interfacing new systems and integrating them on the blocks and other technologies on campus, and then the healthcare applications were a little better than we expected given the Hospital weakness. 
We got the benefit of the first full quarter of iTradeNetwork in the numbers, and then in a bit of a surprise, we actually shipped the first phase of the Houston Metropole project which actually we've switched over now to our United Toll service system technology, just quite valuable for not only the city but for us as well. That was something that we would've expected much earlier in the year having committed earlier the year, we thought it will be an 2011 item. A little bit of that has been moved into 2010.
For full-year 2011, we expect that the software businesses will grow through expanding subscription-basis, new applications that are going to be offered to existing clients, and then a roll out of the recent wins, which is going to benefit us throughout the year and certainly more so in the second half of '11.
Our tolling project in 2011 as we ship much more of the Houston project will add growth but it does come in at lower margins. And that organic growth could be expected to reach double digits in that segment in 2011. However, we don't see any improvements in the state and local government activities, so we're really not counting for anything incrementally out of that space.
Next slide. In the Industrial Technology arena, you can see organic growth here was 21%. We had double-digit order growth in every business that reports into that segment. Our Oil & Gas business that go along with the broker pomp and a few of the other businesses were exceptionally strong. And we had said earlier this year that we thought we'd do a little bit better on our material test equipment sales. 
Well, we did a little better. We did 50% better, which was certainly well above anything we would've envision. We also won Mexico City for Neptune for products that have been selected for delivery in 2011. And that will add to our Toronto project, which is finally underway a little bit in the fourth quarter.
For 2011, full year, we think Neptune will be able to grow, driven by the Toronto project ramp-up and the Mexico City shipments, and then modest growth in the U.S. water market. We still have copper cost pressures, that could drag down pretax earnings as much as $10 million in 2011. And if it keeps going at a rate that is going, but hopefully, we won't have to suffer all of that.
We expect a record year in Fluid Handling. Everyone in these businesses is doing exceptionally well, and we see continued recovery in industrial end markets, which is very important for our Material Analysis business which could have a record here this next year.
Our backlog supports very strong first half in the segment. The DuraTorque products that we're selling for drilling technologies continued to gain share rapidly, and our De-watering comp sales are growing very sharply here on 2011.
Next slide. Energy Systems & Controls, it was up organically, 26%. You can see orders up 26% as well. Again, we had double-digit growth in every business in that segment, very strong performance for any global activity that was related to oil and gas, and we have several businesses and this segment at our. And then we had very strong continued momentum in our sensors and analytical instrument businesses.
For 2011, we see favorable end markets, particularly in upstream oil and gas, all the process industries in our turbine control business which is performing at a spectacular level. And we see growth and operational execution across the segment in 2011, actually improving the margins from where they are today, and with very solid, detail bridges as to why we think our margins will be better again in 2011.
Next slide. Here, if you look at medical and our scientific imaging technology businesses, just again driven by the Verathon acquisition, orders up 41%, sales up 34%. Verathon just performed in an outstanding way, both economically and with the growth that they've demonstrated and the fourth quarter and the full year as a whole. We had very strong sales of our small dosage pump business that really has performed at full-time record levels in 2010 and we would expect more of the same next year. Medical Consumables has been very strong here in the fourth quarter, and we've had quite strong continued growth in the OEM solutions we provide for videoconferencing, things like telepresence and the like.
Our full-year 2011 to us, it looks again, like a double-digit growth year. Medical continues to do really well, with the investment we've made on a global basis and adding sales talent. We've got new product launches that will curb midyear in Verathon, with premium products, and we have a better global reach to be able to launch these things around the world instead of just here in North America. 
We've got a record backlog as we enter 2011 for scientific imaging, so really think that, that should insulate us from what we would worry about being softness in research funding as the year unfolds on a global basis. Although we haven't seen that yet.
Next slide. If you go beyond just the quantitative numbers in the business us, these were some critical things we feel we've learned this year. The recovery really continued throughout the year in almost all of our end markets, which is why we went from negative 3% to plus 5%, plus 14% and plus 15%. The worst-performing end markets we had all seemed to have bottomed, and while some of them are balancing off the bottom much, they are all trending a little bit more favorably.
And we have fewer downside risk concerns going in to 2011 and in '10, or about finished with all of our 2011 through '13 planning, and struck by the confidence level that all of our business leaders have about 2011 compared to where we were last year at the same time. The business as we thought would do well this year, really dramatically outperformed our assumptions. Some of these businesses were up 50%, and we would've expected small double-digit growth from them.
Our niche businesses has held or gained share during the downturn. We had been worried that some of these would be attacked by larger companies that aren't in the space today who would try to enter. I think some of that happened, and they were really entry barriers prove to be quite significant, just anybody trying to enter these markets in which we participate. And our growth investment in R&D and product development and sales channel development are really helping guide this organic growth you've seen in the second half of the year, and why we have confidence going into 2011 on organic growth.
Our more cyclical business that had variable costs did very well last year in terms of decremental margins, and they've done spectacularly well this year in terms of incremental margins that we've grown. 
Our restructuring benefits from the fourth quarter of '08, first part of '09, along with this organic growth drive have really brought us to margin expansion to heights that most people thought were the never attainable. 
Our United toll service technology customer acceptance in the year was really a wonderful development and allowed us to ship a number of products that could have been supplied the other people to our own UTS technologies, and have created a number of new bid opportunities for us and programs we're working on throughout the country, people to deploy this much improved technology in the tolling arena.
Verathon exceeded our expectations and the integration benefits have been more substantial than we had forecast at the time of the acquisition. The investment in sales coverage and global channel reach and product development, they've been able to turn around immediately into measurable growth.
Next slide. So with that, we'll get into our 2011 guidance. Next slide. Here we go you'll see we're establishing full-year guidance on a diluted earnings per share basis of $3.82 to $4.02. We'll talk a little bit about how we made that our. We see sales up on the year between 11% and 13%, we should be organic growth of 9% to 11% in 2011, and about two points from acquisitions. 
Our iTrade acquisition will roll over in the second half of the year, so we really don't have a lot yet from acquisitions to add to those numbers at the moment. Our foreign exchange rates would be the same as they actually were on January 1 of 2011 as you model what we're doing.
Our tax rate's an important thing this year in 2011, we think will be in around 30% tax. This past year, we were able to close up at 20.1%. The different in tax is it gives us and about $0.11 a share headwind in 2011 versus '10. When you're looking at $3.82 to $4.02, that's in the face of. Our diluted share count of $90.5 million is what we would expect to route the year, is up from the 2010 number of 96.7%, and our primarily share count closed out the year December 31 to 95.1 million shares, probably would reach 97 million shares at the end of the year. And I do think there are some people that have share counts that are lower out there then what's the reality. So again, diluted share count for the year, 90.5 million primary share count by the 95 million now, and still DEPS of $3.82 to $4.2. First quarter, we're seeing $0.83 to $0.87 in the quarter, which represented about 21.5%, and the full year, slightly better than normal, usually we're in the sort of 80% to 81% range for Q1. And then full year operating cash flow should exceed $550 million, which is once again, very, very modest CapEx for 2011.
Next slide. So in summary, what we have year is just a wide variety of all-time performance records that were established in 2010. We had the $500 million in operating cash flow, 20% in free cash flow to sales, really quite outstanding margin leverage as the growth continues, and then broad-based momentum throughout the enterprise which gives us the belief that we'll have a strong record here at 2011. And with that, I think we can open it up, John, for Q&A.

componenttext: Well, we had dropped margins in Q1 this year in energy with some things that were self inflicted, and we don't expect that to happen. So yes, I think you should see more level margins throughout the year, as opposed to down in Q1 and catching up through the rest of the year.

componenttextpreview: A lot of the energy businesses have little longer lead time than the rest of our book and ship kind of businesses, and we're seeing very strong backlog and lots of activity. So we wouldn't see any falloff during 2011 in terms of our sales. If there was an
componenttext: A lot of the energy businesses have little longer lead time than the rest of our book and ship kind of businesses, and we're seeing very strong backlog and lots of activity. So we wouldn't see any falloff during 2011 in terms of our sales. If there was any order softness, we are not seeing anything that would indicate order softness in the upstream area.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: But Christopher, in terms of the fourth quarter activity where we normally see stronger performance, I'd have a couple of those businesses, and they're end markets and their customers kind of spend within there budget, that returned so that seasonality re
componenttext: But Christopher, in terms of the fourth quarter activity where we normally see stronger performance, I'd have a couple of those businesses, and they're end markets and their customers kind of spend within there budget, that returned so that seasonality returned in 2010. We would expect to see that continue in 2011 as well.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: Brian, I'd be interested in hearing some further color around the comment of that state and local municipalities having a more of a challenging budget outlook, not surprising there. But just in terms of is this affecting tolling bidding projects? And is t
componenttext: Brian, I'd be interested in hearing some further color around the comment of that state and local municipalities having a more of a challenging budget outlook, not surprising there. But just in terms of is this affecting tolling bidding projects? And is there any of the E-ZPass delays involved in that as well?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, this past year, we would've been off in those areas in excess of $30 million, and yet, you can still see the performance we've generated. So it's been a drag throughout the year in terms of actual sales, and its been certainly frustrating, the E-ZPa
componenttext: Well, this past year, we would've been off in those areas in excess of $30 million, and yet, you can still see the performance we've generated. So it's been a drag throughout the year in terms of actual sales, and its been certainly frustrating, the E-ZPass thing is beyond unbelievable. And I can't say a lot more about it. Some people have written recently that we maybe be a decision in August of 2011. We saw another article from somebody was talking to somebody else well, maybe they won't decide and then maybe they would rollover to August of 2013. And we have a lot of questions about what's going on there but we have very little influence in. We just offer them the best technology in the world at the lowest price, and continue to pay money to get it tested. And sometimes, somebody will decide something. And now as far as other projects are concerned, the decision-making around project has been very slow. We thought we might get some benefit in 2010 as just this stimulus situation went away. But in fact, there's just very slow decisions. We saw a lot of questions, we got a lot of people who are wanting to convert to our United toll products and so that's given us kind of a leg up. But we're not assuming any kind of real spike in 2011 on that portion of the business. Now remember in that segment for us, it's now finally less than half of the segment. So we got a lot of other things in this segment that are really driving margin and driving cash and driving economic performance. I do think that our results in terms of revenue have really bottomed on the items in the transportation and traffic arena. We've got a meeting later this week to kind of refresh where we are, and no people are starting to develop a little bit more confidence.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then just a clarification on the Copper headwind for Neptune. Does that to do advanced purchasing? And how much of that additional copper price can just be passed through to the customer?
componenttext: And then just a clarification on the Copper headwind for Neptune. Does that to do advanced purchasing? And how much of that additional copper price can just be passed through to the customer?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, certainly, we do some advanced purchasing. We do several things you're although we never found it meaningful to hedge because we don't have enough volume. And it's just that the sharp rise in copper, pretty overwhelming and so we model it against ou
componenttext: Well, certainly, we do some advanced purchasing. We do several things you're although we never found it meaningful to hedge because we don't have enough volume. And it's just that the sharp rise in copper, pretty overwhelming and so we model it against our mix of things in the copper content we have. We've been very successful in reducing the copper content inside the water meters itself but on a residential meter basis, it's not easy to get pass throughs the way we can in our Pump businesses. We generally, are maybe six months ahead of what we think consumption is going to look like so we have a pretty good idea around that. But at the end of the day, we're going to have some leakage. We try to do surcharges on material. We try to certainly do pass throughs on bids, but it's a challenge.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: And just an observation, I see that the segment is now medical and scientific imaging, and how you present it, really reflecting the whole portfolio transformation with Verathon bringing you much more of a medical side of the story. Is that both that beco
componenttext: And just an observation, I see that the segment is now medical and scientific imaging, and how you present it, really reflecting the whole portfolio transformation with Verathon bringing you much more of a medical side of the story. Is that both that become unofficial reported segment as well?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, the real reason is medical is over half of the segment. So the imaging continues to wane as a portion of the total segment, so critically important but it's mostly medical now.
componenttext: Yes. Well, the real reason is medical is over half of the segment. So the imaging continues to wane as a portion of the total segment, so critically important but it's mostly medical now.

componenttext: Brian, talk about the growth you made during the downturn. What's your R&D spend like right now. I know it's been trending higher, as a percentage of sales in the growth of your higher tax and gross margin businesses?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: In the R&D spend in 2010 was a little over $100 million. So that was up sharply from 2009 -- 2009 and '08 are about the same in the mid-80s. I think, and 2010 was $102 million. But what happens -- it's important to understand is remember, you take about a
componenttext: In the R&D spend in 2010 was a little over $100 million. So that was up sharply from 2009 -- 2009 and '08 are about the same in the mid-80s. I think, and 2010 was $102 million. But what happens -- it's important to understand is remember, you take about a little less than half of R&D it's kind of an administrative services that we do, revenue management for people and stuff like that. There's not a lot of R&D in there. So R&D spend is a positive revenue is very high in medical and scientific imaging, reasonably high in energy, quite modest in industrial over than in Neptune, and then mixed in our RF software business, most of that stuff, we don't treat as R&D. And then we've really spent quite a bit of money in adding to our global reach and sales development, MarCom, Web access and things like that and each of the divisions.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011

componenttext: And then with that, are you comfortable with your current investment grades? Or would you record margins right now, you think you will use some of that maybe cushion your investments even more animated pickup more market share to '11 looking out into '12?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that we have an aggressive internal measurement that the field people use. It is to be rare that few people will commend with spending strategies that we wouldn't embrace. Product development and product management is kind of a critical skil
componenttext: Well, I think that we have an aggressive internal measurement that the field people use. It is to be rare that few people will commend with spending strategies that we wouldn't embrace. Product development and product management is kind of a critical skill set within the company. I mean product managers always like to have more but they have all that they really need. I think you'll see our excess cash that we throw off lightly to get reinvested in acquisitions as we've been doing for a long period of time, and the opportunities in the pipeline are pretty interesting.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: And next, we'll go to Wendy Caplan with Suntrust Robinson Humphrey.
componenttext: And next, we'll go to Wendy Caplan with Suntrust Robinson Humphrey.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: One of your most successful strategies, I think, internally has been to lower the break even across the company. Can you give us some examples of what you see as potential, some ideas about how you might potentially continue to lower the break even as we
componenttext: One of your most successful strategies, I think, internally has been to lower the break even across the company. Can you give us some examples of what you see as potential, some ideas about how you might potentially continue to lower the break even as we go into 2011?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, certainly, the break even for us continued, the drop in 2010 as a function of revenue, the nominal break even number for sales went up a little bit in 2010. Our breakeven as a function of revenue probably at the lowest point of our history if I have
componenttext: Well, certainly, the break even for us continued, the drop in 2010 as a function of revenue, the nominal break even number for sales went up a little bit in 2010. Our breakeven as a function of revenue probably at the lowest point of our history if I have to say, if you get back to nearly 90, probably not -- I'm not sure about that because it wasn't collected that way, and I don't know how you can really segregate the mixed and variable cost component that will be a pure guesstimate. But in the last 10 years, we're in the best position we have been, and I think IP technology it is to improve, and while we don't believe in enterprise-wide IT strategies, we do believe and look, here's four we're willing to go with. And people get to pick the one that suits their business, so you have a couple of different CRM opportunities here, and you have different kind of things related to how you're going to pull things through the factory operations, all of those are very good. John, I think you might want to take a swag at that.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, I think what you've said covers. For us, Wendy, it's much around that making sure that our operating leaders or always focused on the leverage ratio. I think you have seen our leverage on incremental sales actually gets a little bit better as we have
componenttext: No, I think what you've said covers. For us, Wendy, it's much around that making sure that our operating leaders or always focused on the leverage ratio. I think you have seen our leverage on incremental sales actually gets a little bit better as we have moved from the 2008 range in through 2010, looking into 2011. So we look at that fixed cost leverage and the break even point as a key input and one of the things that all of our businesses need to manage to make sure that the leverage on the growth opportunities that are there really delivers to the bottom-line.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: And along with that, John, and Brian, you've done a great job with your working capital. I mean do we get to the point where, I mean, I feel almost foolish saying this is as good as a guess given that it's so amazing. But do we think there's still a littl
componenttext: And along with that, John, and Brian, you've done a great job with your working capital. I mean do we get to the point where, I mean, I feel almost foolish saying this is as good as a guess given that it's so amazing. But do we think there's still a little room there?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, there's a lot of room. There's always a little room. We are blown away with this 5.4 number. And have to say one of the things we do, we pay bonuses on incremental operating profit performance, and then there's is quite a big kicker for asset veloci
componenttext: Well, there's a lot of room. There's always a little room. We are blown away with this 5.4 number. And have to say one of the things we do, we pay bonuses on incremental operating profit performance, and then there's is quite a big kicker for asset velocity. we're paying a lot of bonus money this year for the asset velocity picker and our industrial and energy businesses. They have really performed remarkably. I don't see anything that says they get any worse. I would think they get a little bit better, and they've gotten better dramatically in receivables management in their Global businesses, and they've got dramatically better inventory. And then we have also the last several acquisitions we've made, Verathon is just, man, we have a lot of turns here at Verathon, because really put that through quickly. And then the software businesses don't really have any inventory to speak of. So we're getting mixed variances that have to do with our strategy of the kind of assets we want to own versus people that are in full and in integrated manufacturing.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: And speaking of that, finally, the M&A environment is clearly been improving. You had notably bought high margin kind of asset-light businesses that generate a lot of cash with an emphasis on the SaaS business has most recently. Are there any other factor
componenttext: And speaking of that, finally, the M&A environment is clearly been improving. You had notably bought high margin kind of asset-light businesses that generate a lot of cash with an emphasis on the SaaS business has most recently. Are there any other factors more recently, are seeking in terms of acquisitions? And can you say something about what's out there for you?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, there's a lot of stuff that's for sale last year, a lot of private equity transactions wound up not getting and to the sale category as they were really able for a finance at extremely attractive rates, and kind of had an obviously a double dip, if
componenttext: Well, there's a lot of stuff that's for sale last year, a lot of private equity transactions wound up not getting and to the sale category as they were really able for a finance at extremely attractive rates, and kind of had an obviously a double dip, if you will, or where they get ref financing takeout fees, and then they can to wed and tell them again later in 2011 or '12 or whatever. So as long as the finance arrangements in terms of what people are willing to staple on the transactions remains as high as it is, and it's frankly ridiculous levels in our opinion. There's a lot of bid/ask spread variances that are still there. But I think people want to make sure that they do exit their positions that they've hope to exit in 2010 and 2011. We've seen an awful lot of activities. Certainly there's so much opportunity, Wendy, the challenge is we don't want to do something that's good at the expense of some of the substantially better. And so we're , I think you'll see us be slow in the first month of the year because there's just so many different things that we are currently doing diligence on.

The problem is that these projects like Houston, don't carry the kind of margins that you're accustomed to seeing what us. The accrete to us eventually but at the beginning of these, they're relatively low-margin projects.

componenttext: And then our Toronto, we had some revenue kind of mid-single-digit revenue for that. Of course, we're talking $200 million, or so over a five-year to six-year period. SO there'll be a ramp-up and it will come down a little bit on the Toronto side. And in Mexico City, is the results are going to be adding to us for Neptune, somewhere in the kind of mid-teens, millions of dollars for 2011.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011

componenttext: And then just one follow-up, on the Oil & Gas business, how much would you guys, say today, has been driven by upstream versus Downstream activity? And can you just provide a little more granularity into your thoughts regarding the growth outlook in those two buckets, if you will, for 2011?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, certainly the V-shaped balance, energy was really upstreamed. So there's quite substantial upstream activity. Now in the case of our threshold drilling business, that's a different situation, right? So they have to introduce the proprietary technolo
componenttext: Well, certainly the V-shaped balance, energy was really upstreamed. So there's quite substantial upstream activity. Now in the case of our threshold drilling business, that's a different situation, right? So they have to introduce the proprietary technology that's really clearly superior to what people have used in the past. So it's growing really well. And I think we'd do that because it's less around economy and more about the disruptive technology that allows people to drill deeper faster and with much better performance. But in the Other category in energy, it's mostly upstreamed. The refinery business that we have an instrument nation in a lag are in our segment. But still up that it's going to continue to be up, just not at that pace that will change the rest of the segment.

componenttext: It's meters. It's just meters periodically from time to time, we get those and the reading technology that goes on them is variable bearable based on what happened. It's not the first time we've gotten an update from Mexico City. So this is not like a system win that you're going to have a $100 million over four years. It's pretty much 2011 throughout the year growing against something as John said, it's in the low-teens of millions of dollars.

componenttext: And then when I switch down to the RF-type segment, what do you think, Bryan, the margin profile looks like there through calendar '11? Because we've got iTrade that's accretive. We'll have certainly, Houston, that may be pulled back in a little bit. Can we work off kind of a 23% EBIT margin as a floor here going forward?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, let's do a couple of things here. a part of it is the mix of what happens in the quarter, right? So if you look and there's a reconciliation to reconciliation pages that are in the appendix that show you by quarter, and we try to make this really gr
componenttext: Well, let's do a couple of things here. a part of it is the mix of what happens in the quarter, right? So if you look and there's a reconciliation to reconciliation pages that are in the appendix that show you by quarter, and we try to make this really granular this time where you'll see in a reconciliation in OP line, the amortization line segment and then an EBITDA number, and then depreciation added through EBITDA, we gave you the revenue number, we gave you the  EBITDA margins. So for instance, and RF in the fourth quarter, the EBITDA margin was 29.7%, EBITDA margin was 31.2%. In the fourth quarter, I think, our intangible amortization was about right at $25 million. Our full-year intangible amortization of '10 was about 86 million. So clearly, you're seeing the affect of the intangible amortization on iTrade just quite sizable. And a portion, which has nothing to do with the reinvestment CapEx or anything else is going to be like $100 million. So that tends to pull down operating profit margins and it is, in our view, a foolish way for somebody to think about how well the company is performing. So you'll see continued growth in iTrade. If we'll add significantly to our cash performance. It will add aggressively to the OP margin line. So that's an important distinction. And then the tolling traffic business is less than half the segment. It comes in at dramatically lower gross margins. We are not talking 50% and 60% there. We are talking very much less than that. And then it's operating profit margins is relatively good given its low gross margins. And then the rest of the segment, let's say it gets to be 55%, 60% of war, it's going to have highest gross margin profile higher than imaging does and it's going to come in with the EBITDA higher than any portion of the enterprise. So it's a hard question to answer and say we'll use to replug, I don't think I'll do that. But it's easy to put a plug-in on a cash performance basis quarter-to-quarter.

componenttext: No. I think we've got like this Mexico City thing, Toronto thing, rollout on those gas and those things, we have just very limited effect on when people take shipments. So it's really hard to say much of that. This year, organic growth like I said before, with the minus 3%, plus 5%, plus 14%, plus 15%. It's going to be a little better next year but it's probably ramps down the same way this year ramped up. So I heard John say 13%, or more, I can understand 13% or more. But I'm frowning at him a little bit. I'd be nice, I don't know. But clearly, first half of the year is going to be in the low-teens organic growth. The second half of the year is going to be more like the average we had for 2010, is my guess. And I think if we have upside of the year, it's probably going to manifest itself in the fourth quarter. I think that our field people are forecasting light in the fourth quarter versus what we would think in -- and I don't really blame them for that. It's hard to envision you could have double-digit organic growth every quarter in 2011, but it's certainly possible.

componenttext: Good day, and welcome to the Roper Industries Fourth Quarter and Full Year Financial Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I will now turn the call over to John Humphrey, Chief Financial Officer. Please go ahead.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, David, and thank you, all for joining us this morning as we discuss the results of the fourth quarter and full year 2010. Joining me this morning is Brian Jellison, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Paul Soni, Vice President
componenttext:
Thank you, David, and thank you, all for joining us this morning as we discuss the results of the fourth quarter and full year 2010. Joining me this morning is Brian Jellison, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Paul Soni, Vice President and Controller.
Earlier this morning, we issued a press release announcing our financial results. The press release also includes replay information for today's call. We prepared slides to accompany today's call, which are available through the webcast and also available on the website at www.roperind.com.
So if you turn to Slide 2, we'll begin with our Safe Harbor statement. During the course of today's call, we'll be making forward-looking statements which are subject to the risks and uncertainties that are described in this page and as detailed in our SEC filings. You should look into today's call in the context of that information.
And now if you'll please turn to Slide 3. I'll turn the call over to Brian Jellison, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer. After his prepared remarks, we'll take some questions from our telephone participants. Brian?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, everyone. We'll start off by just saying the outline for today, we'll talk first about our full year financial results here for 2010 and then go into the enterprise results on a financial basis for the fourth quarter. Then we'll l
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, everyone. We'll start off by just saying the outline for today, we'll talk first about our full year financial results here for 2010 and then go into the enterprise results on a financial basis for the fourth quarter. Then we'll look at the individual segment detail and the outlook for each one of those segments for 2011. I'll talk a little bit about sort of beyond the numbers, things that happened in 2010 that have been learnings for us during the downturn as we come out. And then establish our 2011 guidance and move to Q&A for you.
So next slide. For 2010, our enterprise financial results are just fundamentally in every category, an all-time record whether it's orders, sales, backlog, earnings, EBITDA, cash flow, anything one can think of. Our EBITDA margins for the year reached 26.7%, of course, another all-time high.
Our operating teams performed exceptionally well, and we enjoyed full year EBITDA leverage on the next dollar of incremental sales of 40%. We had a record asset loss, we will have more to talk about there. And for the first time, we were at $500 million in operating cash flow for the calendar year.
Our free cash flow became 20% of sales. We look around it, capital market competitors for us and many of the S&P 500 businesses don't enjoy 20% operating margin, let alone 20% free cash flow to sales. Our free cash flow exceeded net income for the 13th consecutive year. We increased our dividend this year by 16% for 2011 after raising them last year, 15% for 2009.
Our book-to-bill ratio for the full year was 1.06. This has created a record backlog of $785 million, which is up $220 million from our year-end backlog last year, and I think one of the things that's amazing for us is that the excellence that we had really permeated throughout the enterprise with only to or three businesses not participating.
Next slide. Our full year income statement, you can see here bookings reach about $2.5 billion for the first time. Our bookings were up 25% on the year. Our net sales were up 16%, 8% organic for the year but of course, it continued to move up throughout the year starting out the year with a minus 3% and then a plus 5%, and a plus 14% and closing out at a plus 15%. Our gross margin, again, spectacular 53.4% for the year, up 250 basis points over the prior year.
Our income from operations for the year was up 30% at $514 million, and I would like to remind people that we have about $86 million of noncash intangible amortization that depresses those income margin. So our operating profit margins reached 21.6% for the year. If you add back the noncash intangible amortization, you're over 25%.
Our interest expense was up just modestly at $67 million, and the tax rate was slightly down this year at 28.1% versus 29.5% for the prior year. That left us with net earnings of $323 million, up from last year's $239 million, and full year diluted earnings per share of $3.34 versus $2.58 last year.
Next slide. Our full year operating cash flow as we said before was $500 million, that was up 36% from last year's $367 million. And our operating cash flow as a percent of sales, you can see it continues to trend up, it was 16% in '07, 19% in '08, dropped by a point to 18% in the great recession and it's now back to 21% here in 2010. And our cash conversion on an operating cash flow basis was 155% of net income.
Next slide. On a full year free cash flow basis, the $500 million drops to $471 million as we had about $29 million of CapEx. Our free cash flow, as I said, was 20% of revenue, up 300 basis points from last year. 
We had stellar execution, which you'll see in our asset velocity numbers in just a minute. And you could see here, you're gone from 122% free cash flow in 2006 to 128%, and then 143%. I think, the 2008 that was of course a record for us. People expected we'd fall off in the downturn, but we didn't. We held the 143%, and now this year as we start back up, we're at 146%. So really, sustained cash flow performance conversion and despite very difficult economic markets during that five-year period.
Next slide. On asset velocity, this is sort of a slight internal year because we focused so much on it that it kind of takes our breath away. You look here at 12/31/10, and our inventory is down to 6.6% of the revenue, receivables at 14.8%, payables and accruals at 16%. So when you add inventory and receivables and subtract the payables and accruals, which is our core measurement, we are at 5.4% of sales. If you go back to '07 and we were at 10% of sales, and those of you who followed us a long time, those numbers used to dramatically higher than that.
And when you think about 5.4% that support your revenue and you've got 26.7% EBITDA and 20% free cash flow to sales on a 5.4% number, it truly is outstanding performance and speaks volumes about this asset-like business strategy and execution that we put in place.
Next slide. On a balance sheet perspective, we closed the year out with $270 million in cash and $520 million in undrawn revolver, so it's about $800 million of existing capacity. Our net debt to EBITDA is only at 1.7x, and our EBITDA to interest coverage is nearly 10x. We invested $900 million in the last 15 months in transactions. And certainly, we're positioned to capture opportunities at that level in the next 15 days.
Next slide. Well here, we look at the specific Q4 enterprise results. Once again, it's an all-time record, truly remarkable quarter for us. Sales were up 23% to $679 million and organic growth represented 15%. Our backlog at $785 million is up 39% from the prior year. Net earnings were up 49% to $107 million. EBITDA at $200 million in the quarter, kind of breath-taking number, up $53 million from a year ago, and EBITDA margins at 29.4%, I just asked people to compare those to gross margins from your S&P 500 diversified companies. 
Our free cash flow at 22% of sales and up 21% to $147 million, again just very strong, and by closing out the year, the strongest we have, it really gives us a lot of confidence going into 2011 that we'll have another record year in 2011.
Next slide. Our Q4 income statement, you can see here sales and bookings up 23%, both organic at 15%. Book-to-bill closed out at 1.02. Gross profit, 54.7%, up 210 basis points from a year ago. Operating margins at 24.5%. And I'd remind you again about our noncash intangible amortization, about $25 million in the quarter, so another 3.7%. You take the 24.5% and the 3.7%, you get an EBITDA number of 28.2% in the quarter net debt. 
Interest expense, the same in the fourth quarter of '10 as it was last year. Our tax rate dropped to 27.7%. Our guidance was for it to be a little bit above that. We had the benefit of the R&D tax there in the quarter. Net earnings were up 49%, as we said, to $107 million, and earnings per share on a DEPS basis is $1.10 versus $0.77.
Next slide. When we get specifically into each of the segments here, we'll talk a little bit about how the fourth quarter was and more importantly, what we think 2011 looks like. 
Next slide. So if we look at the margin performance in the segments, you can see RF was at 50% gross margins and Industrial, 52%, Energy, 56%, and Medical and Imaging 63%. Just virtually, the same EBITDA performance along the way 31%, 32%, 31%, 32%, which excludes the corporate cost that brings us down to our enterprise number. 
We had really exceptional margins throughout the enterprise with really no segment lagging very much. Of course, the RF is made up of two entirely different kind of entities now, with a little less of half of it being tolling and transportation and administrative activities, which of course carry much lower margins. And then the majority of the business in our Software-as-a-Service and other RF products basis which enjoy the higher margins.
Next slide. In the RF Technology segment, you can see orders were up 4%, sales up 17%, organic sales were up 6%, finally returning to organic growth in the radio frequency. Our CBORD and Horizon software businesses had excellent results with campus security, which is picked back up as people are introducing new systems and integrating them with locks and other technologies on campus. And then the healthcare applications were a little better than we expected given the hospital weakness. 
We got the benefit of the first full quarter of iTradeNetwork in the numbers, and then in a bit of a surprise, we actually shipped the first phase of the Houston METRO Toll project, which actually we switched over now to our United Toll Service system technology, just quite valuable for not only the city but for us as well. That was something that we would have expected much earlier in the year having not had committed earlier the year, we thought it would be a 2011 item. A little bit of that has moved into 2010.
For full year 2011, we expect that the software businesses will grow through expanding subscription basis, new applications that are going to be offered to existing clients and then a roll out of recent wins which is going to benefit us throughout the year and certainly more so in the second half of '11.
Our tolling projects in 2011 as we ship much more of the Houston project will add growth but it does come in at lower margins. And then our organic growth could be expected to reach double digits in the segment in 2011. However, we don't see any improvements to state and local government activities, so we're really not counting for anything incrementally out of that space.
Next slide. In the Industrial Technology arena, you can see organic growth here was 21%. We had double-digit order growth in every business that reports into that segment. Our Oil & Gas businesses that go along with the broker pomp and a few of the other businesses were exceptionally strong. And we had said earlier this year that we thought we'd do a little bit better on our material test equipment sales, well we did a little better. We did 50% better, which was certainly well above anything we would have envisioned. 
We also won Mexico City for Neptune, for products that have been selected for delivery in 2011. And that will add to our Toronto project which is finally underway a little bit in the fourth quarter.
For 2011 full year, we think Neptune will be able to grow driven by the Toronto project ramp-up and the Mexico City shipments, and then modest growth in the U.S. water market. We still have copper cost pressures that could drag down pretax earnings as much as $10 million in 2011 if it keeps going at a rate it's going. But hopefully, we won't have to suffer all of that.
We expect a record year in Fluid Handling. Everyone of these businesses is doing exceptionally well. And we see a continued recovery in industrial end markets which is very important for our Material Analysis business which could have a record here this next year.
Our backlog supports very strong first half in the segment. The DuraTorque products that we're selling for drilling technologies continue to gain share rapidly and our dewatering pump sales are growing very sharply here on 2011.
Next slide. Energy Systems & Controls, it was up organically, 26%. You can see orders up 26% as well. Again, we had double-digit growth in every business in that segment, very strong performance for any global activity that was related to oil and gas and we have several businesses in this segment there are and I know we had very strong continued momentum in our sensors and analytical instrument businesses.
For 2011, we see favorable end markets, particularly in upstream oil and gas, all the process industries in our turbine control business which is performing at a spectacular level. And we see growth and operational execution across the segment in 2011, actually improving the margins from where they are today, and with very solid detailed bridges as to why we think our margins will be better again in 2011.
Next slide. Here, if we look at Medical and our Scientific Imaging technology businesses, just again driven by the Verathon acquisition, orders up 41%, sales up 34%. Verathon just performed in an outstanding way both economically and with the growth that they've demonstrated in the fourth quarter and the full year as a whole. We had very strong sales of our small dosage pump business that really has performed at full-time record levels in 2010 and we would expect more of the same next year. medical consumables have been very strong here in the fourth quarter, and we've had quite strong continued growth in the OEM solutions we provide for videoconferencing, things like telepresence and the like.
Our full year 2011 to us, it looks again like a double-digit growth here. Medical will continue to do really well with the investment we've made on a global basis and adding sales talent. We've got new product launches that will occur midyear in Verathon, with premium products. And we have a better global reach to be able to launch these things around the world instead of just here in North America. 
We've got a record backlog as we enter 2011 for Scientific Imaging, so we really think that that should insulate us from what we would worry about being softness in research funding as the year unfolds on a global basis although we haven't seen that yet.
Next slide. If you go beyond just the quantitative numbers in the businesses, these were some critical things we feel we've learned this year. The recovery really continued throughout the year in almost all of our end markets, which is why we went from negative 3% to plus 5%, plus 14% and plus 15%. The worst-performing end markets we have all seemed to have bottomed. And while some of them are balancing off the bottom much, they're all trending a little bit more favorably.
And we have fewer downside risk concerns going in to 2011 and in '10, or about finished with all of our 2011 through '13 planning, and struck by the confidence level that all of our business leaders have about 2011 compared to where we were last year at the same time. The businesses we thought would do well this year really dramatically outperformed our assumptions. Some of these businesses were up 50% and we would've expected small double-digit growth from them.
Our niche business has held or gained share during the downturn. We had been worried that some of these would be attacked by larger companies that aren't in the space today who would try to enter. I think some of that happened, and they worded our entry barriers proved to be quite significant against anybody trying to enter these markets in which we participate. 
And our growth investments in R&D and product development and sales channel development are really helping drive this organic growth you've seen in the second half of the year and why we have confidence going into 2011 on organic growth.
Our more cyclical business that had variable costs did very well last year in terms of decremental margins, and they've done spectacularly well this year in terms of incremental margins that we've grown. 
Our restructuring benefits from the fourth quarter of '08, the first part of '09, along with this organic growth drive have really brought us to margin expansion to heights that most people thought were never attainable. 
Our United Toll Service technology customer acceptance in the year was really a wonderful development and allowed us to ship a number of projects that would have been supplied by other people to our own UTS technologies, and have created a number of new bid opportunities for us and programs we're working on throughout the country, people to deploy this much improved technology in the tolling arena.
Verathon exceeded our expectations. The integration benefits have been more substantial than we had forecast at the time of the acquisition. The investment in sales coverage and global channel reach and product development, they've been able to churn around immediately into measurable growth.
Next slide. So with that, we'll get into our 2011 guidance. Next slide. Here you'll see we're establishing full year guidance on a diluted earnings per share basis of $3.82 to $4.02. We'll talk a little bit about how we make that up. We see sales up on the year between 11% and 13%, which would be organic growth of 9% to 11% in 2011, and about two points from acquisitions. 
Our iTrade acquisition will roll over in the second half of the year, so we really don't have a lot yet from acquisitions to add to those numbers at the moment. Our foreign exchange rates would be the same as they actually were on January 1 of 2011 as you model what we're doing.
Our tax rate's an important thing. This year in 2011, we think will be in around 30% tax. This past year, we were able to close out at 28.1%. The difference in tax as it gives is about $0.11 a share headwind in 2011 versus '10. When you're looking at $3.82 to $4.02, that's in the face of '11 and headwind. Our diluted share count of 98.5 million is what we would expect throughout the year, is up from the 2010 number of 96.7 million, and our primary share count closed out the year December 31 at 95.1 million shares, probably would reach 97 million shares at the end of the year. And I do think there are some people that have share counts that are lower out there than what's in reality. So again, diluted share count for the year, 98.5 million primary share count, 95 million. 
And still DEPS at $3.82 to $4.2. First quarter, we're seeing $0.83 to $0.87 in the quarter, which represents about 21.5% for the full year, slightly better than normal, usually we're in the sort of 18% to 21% range for Q1. And then full year operating cash flow should exceed $550 million with once again very, very modest CapEx for 2011.
Next slide. So in summary, what we have here is just a wide variety of all-time performance records that were established in 2010. We had the $500 million in operating cash flow, 20% in free cash flow to sales, really quite outstanding margin leverage as the growth continues and then broad-based momentum throughout the enterprise which gives us the belief that we'll have a strong record year at 2011. And with that, I think we can open it up, John, for Q&A.

componenttext: A lot of the Energy businesses have little longer lead time than the rest of our book-and-ship kind of businesses, and we're seeing very strong backlog and lots of activities. So we wouldn't see any falloff during 2011 in terms of our sales. If there was any order softness, we are not seeing anything that would indicate order softness in the upstream area.

componenttext: But Christopher, in terms of the fourth quarter activity where we normally see stronger performance out of a couple of those businesses and their end markets and their customers kind of spend within their budgets, that returned. headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: Brian, I'd be interested in hearing some further color around the comment of that state and local municipalities having a more of a challenging budget outlook, not surprising there. But just in terms of is this affecting tolling bidding projects? And is t
componenttext: Brian, I'd be interested in hearing some further color around the comment of that state and local municipalities having a more of a challenging budget outlook, not surprising there. But just in terms of is this affecting tolling bidding projects? And is there any of the E-ZPass delays involved in that as well?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, this past year, we would've been off in those areas in excess of $30 million, and yet, you can still see the performance we've generated. So it's been a drag throughout the year in terms of actual sales and its been certainly frustrating. The E-ZPas
componenttext: Well, this past year, we would've been off in those areas in excess of $30 million, and yet, you can still see the performance we've generated. So it's been a drag throughout the year in terms of actual sales and its been certainly frustrating. The E-ZPass thing is beyond unbelievable. And I can't say a lot more about it. Some people have written recently that well maybe there'll be a decision in August of 2011. We saw another article from somebody who's talking to somebody saying, "Well, maybe they won't decide then they could rollover to August of 2013." And we have a lot of questions about what's going on there but we have very little influence in it. We just offer them the best technology in the world at the lowest price and continue to pay money to get it tested. And sometimes, somebody will decide something. And now as far as other projects are concerned, the decision making around projects has been very slow. We thought we might get some benefit in 2010 as just the stimulus situation went away. But in fact, there's just very slow decisions. We saw a lot of questions, we got a lot of people who are wanting to convert to our United Toll products and so that's given us kind of a leg up. But we're not assuming any kind of real spike in 2011 on that portion of the business. Now remember in that segment for us, it's now finally less than half of the segment. So we got a lot of other things in the segment that are really driving margin and driving cash and driving economic performance. I do think that our results in terms of revenue have really bottomed on the items in the transportation and traffic arena. We've got a meeting later this week to kind of refresh where we are, I know people are starting to develop a little bit more confidence.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then just a clarification on the copper headwind for Neptune. Does Neptune do advanced purchasing? And how much of that additional copper price can be passed through to the customer?
componenttext: And then just a clarification on the copper headwind for Neptune. Does Neptune do advanced purchasing? And how much of that additional copper price can be passed through to the customer?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, certainly we do some advanced purchasing. We do several things here although we never found it meaningful to hedge because we don't have enough volume. And it's just that the sharp rise in copper, pretty overwhelming and so we model it against our m
componenttext: Well, certainly we do some advanced purchasing. We do several things here although we never found it meaningful to hedge because we don't have enough volume. And it's just that the sharp rise in copper, pretty overwhelming and so we model it against our mix of things and the copper content we have. We've been very successful in reducing the copper content inside the water meters itself but on a residential meter basis, it's not easy to get pass throughs the way we can in our pump businesses. We generally, are maybe six months ahead of what we think consumption is going to look like, so we have a pretty good idea around that. But at the end of the day, we're going to have some leakage. We try to do surcharges on material. We try to certainly do pass through on bids, but it's a challenge.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: And just an observation, I see that the segment is now Medical and Scientific Imaging, and how you present it really reflecting the whole portfolio transformation with Verathon bringing you much more of a medical side of the story. Is that both become an
componenttext: And just an observation, I see that the segment is now Medical and Scientific Imaging, and how you present it really reflecting the whole portfolio transformation with Verathon bringing you much more of a medical side of the story. Is that both become an official reported segment as well?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, the real reason is Medical is over half of the segment. So the Imaging continues to wane as a portion of the total segment, so critically important but it's mostly Medical now.
componenttext: Yes. Well, the real reason is Medical is over half of the segment. So the Imaging continues to wane as a portion of the total segment, so critically important but it's mostly Medical now.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 31, 2011
