componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to today's Roper Quarter and Year End Quarter Results Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded. I will now turn the call over to Mr. John Humphrey, Chief Financial Officer. Please go ahead.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you Melody, and thank you all for joining us this morning as we discussed the record results for our first quarter 2011. Joining me this morning is Brian Jellison, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Paul Soni, Vice President and Co
componenttext:
Thank you Melody, and thank you all for joining us this morning as we discussed the record results for our first quarter 2011. Joining me this morning is Brian Jellison, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Paul Soni, Vice President and Controller.
Earlier this morning, we issued a press release announcing our financial results. The press release also includes a replay information for today's call. In addition, we prepared slides to accompany today's call, which are available through the webcast, and are also available on the website at www.roperind.com.
So if you please turn to Slide 2, we'll begin with our Safe Harbor statement. During the course of today's call, we will be making forward-looking statements which are subject to the risks and uncertainties as described in this page, and as detailed in our SEC filings. You should listen into today's call in the context of that information.
And now if you'll please turn to Slide 3. I'll turn the call over to Brian Jellison, Chairman and President, and Chief Executive Officer. After his prepared remarks, we'll take some questions from our telephone participants. Brian?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John, and good morning, everyone. We'll take you first through the Q1 financial results in detail, and then we'll look at the segment performance, and the outlook for Q2 and the rest of the year. I'll talk about raising our guidance and then so
componenttext:
Thank you, John, and good morning, everyone. We'll take you first through the Q1 financial results in detail, and then we'll look at the segment performance, and the outlook for Q2 and the rest of the year. I'll talk about raising our guidance and then sort of summarize the quarter, and take your questions.
First Slide here is the financial results. You can see we achieved a record, all-time record for Q1, in orders in sales backlog, net earnings and EBITDA and pretty much any measurement you can imagine. and the thing that was particularly gratifying was our book-to-bill ratio was 109%, and generally we're at the sort of 97% to 103%, so to be 109% is very encouraging for the remainder of the year. 
Organic growth was really quite spectacular, we thought 20% of our growth, and all four of the segments had double-digit order growth and revenue growth as you can see organically was 16%.
Gross margins increased to 54.3%, so any fear of input costs creating any difficulty of Roper was not well-founded. EBITDA margins are up 310 basis points to 27.4%. Remember what does that was mostly EBITA there's not much depreciation here. 
Our balance sheet was enhanced, as we continued to pay down our revolver, and we ended the quarter with an all-time record backlog of $851 million in revenue, which is 43% higher than the backlog at the end of the first quarter last year of $257 million. Now we certainly, when we established our guidance for Q1 thought we would have a strong start, but this is even better than our best expectations.
Next slide. Our income statement here you can see the bookings of $702 million up 24% in total, and 20% organically, net sales of $645 million, up 21% in total, and 16% organically. Our gross profit went up from 52.3% the first quarter of last year to 54.3%, here an increase of 200 basis points. 
Our operating income was up 41% and went from 18.8% last year to 22% this year, so that's really quite an outstanding leverage. We'll talk a little bit more about our leverage on the variable contribution here for the revenue.
Our interest expense was basically flat. The tax rate was also quite similar to the prior-year, and that produced net earnings of up 49% to $89 million from $59.7 million last year, and a diluted earnings per share number of $0.91, versus the $0.62 gap number from the prior-year.
On the next slide. On the asset velocity, while the absolute amount of dollars amount of inventory receivables up a little bit as a function of the revenue, it continues to decline. You'll see in the first quarter, our inventory was 7.7% of revenue, down from 8.2% in the prior-year, our receivables were down to 16%, a pickup of 50 basis points from the 16.5% the prior-year, and our payables and accruals or liabilities there actually increased to 16.1% from 15.8%. So when we total it, at the end of last year we were 8.9% of sales in this year, is down 130 basis points to 7.6% of revenues. So year-over-year, we see continued improvement in our asset velocity.
Next slide. We ended the quarter with a really strong balance sheet. Cash was $261 million. We paid down the revolver so there's quite a bit of a role for left when you take the revolver in cash together, we wind up with $813 million of available liquidity and of course, we'll have very strong cash in Q2 and throughout the rest of the year. 
Our net debt is down to $980 million, and you can see that gives us a net debt to EBITDA ratio on a trailing basis of only 1.4x, and our EBITDA will continue to expand rapidly throughout the year on a trailing basis. Our EBITDA to interest coverage is already a 10.2x, so these ratios are extremely strong, and they really enhance our liquidity and our ability to use the balance sheet in the quarters ahead.
Next slide. Here we are going to look at the individual segment performance in the outlook. Next slide. Orders strength as you can see, was really spectacular. Industrial Technology was up 30%, RF Technology was up 30%, Energy systems and controls, 16%, and Medical and Scientific up 15%. The book-to-bill ratios were very strong all the way across, anywhere from 118%, and Industrial at 103% and Medical and Imaging we had in organic growth in all four segments in revenue as well.
Next slide. If you look at the RF Technology, you can see that orders rich $270 million in the quarter, up 30% from the prior-year and 18% organically. Our sales were $200 million which was up 23% year-over-year, and up more than 10% organically. 
Our gross margin expanded to 51.4% which was up 170 basis points, and our operating margin was up 270 basis points. We finished the quarter with an EBITDA margin of 30.7%, which was up 450 basis points from the first quarter of 2010. So you see very strong EBITDA performance with our iTrade business contributing a substantial amount of non-cash amortization to the EBITDA measure here.
In the first quarter of 2011, we had very strong pack sales for both Florida, Oklahoma and Dubai. In fact our Amtech business was up over 40%. A significant growth in our gas automated meter reading business with the Gaz de France project, and a quite substantial increase in the U.K. our water network metering and motoring business was up well in excess of 40% as well. 
And in CBORD, we've got an expanded subscriber base we've won another University of Miami University in Ohio, a big security win there displacing a long time occupant in that role.
In Q2, what we've seen is that the Gaz de France AMR project continued at similar levels to Q1. We'll have very strong seasonal Q2 because CBORD winds up with their annual renewals following into the second quarter, so we should see double-digit growth there. 
Our Houston METRO project appears to be on schedule, and we ought to see what we have in, or forecast for the second quarter. And iTrade has won a very, very significant opportunity to launch a system for a major European food retailer that we can't yet announce. But the launch is underway, and the integration will begin within the year.
It's very encouraging for us to see the direction that our technology, because last year in 2010's first quarter our organic revenue was down 12%, the second quarter was down 7%, third quarter was down 1%, the fourth quarter was up 6%, so we're out of the gate year with more than 10% organic the here in the first quarter, and we expect the balance of the year is going to give us double-digit growth throughout the next three quarters.  Q2 a little lighter, Q3 much stronger, and Q4 similar to this quarter.
Next slide. In Industrial Technology, is absolutely is a spectacular performance here. Our orders were up 30% to $201 million of course, that's all organic. Our sales were up 26% aided by about 60 basis points of FX, so you can round organic that to 25%. 
Gross margins were 50.4%, so they continue to expand, and their operating margin was up 370 basis points to 27.2%. EBITDA and Industrial Technology finished the quarter at 30.6%. 
Virtually, everyone there had a very strong quarter. Our Fluid Handling businesses that deal with gas exploration with the new products we've launched in the last year and half, just are having extraordinary performance. These businesses are nearly up 50%. The material testing business that we have as you can to you to get better capacity utilization around the country's growing very rapidly. 
And we actually had double-digit growth in our U.S. business in Neptune, and that is still more growth earnings per share result of Canada continuing shift Mexico City order we announced in the fourth quarter. So Neptune had a very strong Q1, and we expect that to continue.
In Q2 the backlog at our Fluid Handling businesses Cornell pump will assure double-digit growth in the second quarter. The Toronto project installation phase of that's going to actually ramp up in Q2, although because there's a lot of labor in that it comes in at the expected lower margins that we have there. 
End markets remain very strong always in all these Industrial categories, and the operating leverage do we have is continuing to drive margin performance. You can really see just how effective we are when you look at the spot price for copper in the first quarter last year, was $3.55 this year, spot price this year is $4.30 and yet our gross margin expanded across the board gross margin operating margins or EBITDA margins.
Our next slide. The Energy systems and control segment it continues to perform well here orders were up 16% all organic, sales were up 23%. Gross margin expanded quite a bit from up 350 basis points to 54.1% and the operating profit margin increased 450 basis point. You might remember we were somewhat disappointed in Q1 2010 where the operating margin got that corrupted in the second quarter, and this shows the kind of firm disciplined approach to what you need to do of the first quarter last year. And that certainly supports this quarter's 50-basis point improvement in OP. EBITDA margins year was 26%. 
Again, you can say exactly the same thing, the same words that apply to Industrial Technology broad-based strength across all businesses and end markets. Everything here is really doing exceptionally well, very dramatic growth in our diesel engine search protection business. We almost called that explosive growth, but that might scare people. But that business is up nearly 40% this year. Industrial end market growth continues to drive our sensors business, capacity utilization back in the latex or rubber industry looks very good and equipment sales ensure output this things are up sharply. And all of our Energy lab equipment businesses are doing okay, as we've finally got a little bit improvement both at refining and petrochem markets.
In the second quarter, the end market dynamics we think will continue to be strong. Our backlog is really quite substantial, and our Compressor Control business which will start to drive better this year in Q2 and particularly, in the second half of the year. And the margin expansion, we think will continue to be driven just by the operating leverage as sales increased throughout the year.
Next slide. Here's the Medical and Imaging segment. Orders were up 15%, tiny bit of FX there, so organic it was 14%, sales were up 12%, the gross margins here was 62.8%, up another 330 basis points, and our OP was up to 24.1%. EBITDA in this segment is 29.1% so EBITDA margins increased by 110 basis points. 
We've done quite a bit of investing in the first quarter in our Verathon business. We're launching two new products, one is called Veraport, and that has had as increase of growth expense in Q1, and that will continue a little bit into Q2, as we launch all of that collateral literature and the various programs held sales meeting in Q1 to kick that product off along with some other things we're doing as well. 
Medical remains a strong on consumables, double-digit growth in all these businesses, and our kidney dialysis application for our dosage delivery pump business continued to be a double-digit grower. Very significant order growth in our higher-end imaging cameras and filtering technology, it was the broad start of the quarter, as we look at the filters for electron microscopy of being up very dramatically.
In the second quarter of 2011, we see Medical continuing to grow at double digits, as we get continuing adoption rates regards opened to report new products must in this year. And the Scientific Imaging has a really quite substantial backlog as they will support a strong Q2. 
The Japanese supply risks have proven to be less difficult than what we've feared on certain higher-end chips that are made very specifically for us. We've kind of dealt with all these issues, and felt quite good about it. The only thing for Japan is a substantial portion of our camera business goes into the Japanese market. It represents disproportionate of share compared to the rest of Roper. 
Our total sales into Japan are in the neighborhood of 3% of revenues, so it's not something that's overly difficult for us that could depress revenue growth for the camera portion of the business in the next quarter or two. But then still backlog, that will be good news for us later.
Next slide. Here as we look at the guidance, we're going to raise the guidance. Next slide. We were at $3.82 to $4.2 when we went into the year. We raised the base by $0.15. On the top end by $0.10 to take us to $3.97 to $4.12. The midpoint is more than a 20% increase over last year's $3.34 depth space. And in the second quarter were at $0.95 to $1, which is a quite sharp increase over last year's future performance. 
Basically, the sales we expect to have in the mid-teens organic growth in the second quarter and the second half of the year, are probably in the kind of high single-digit, 8% to 10% or 11%, so the full year will be double-digit organic growth. 
The next slide would be the we are still reaffirming that the cash flow will be in excess of $550 million, so that you can imagine the next three quarters will be quite substantial in terms of operating cash flow would generate.
In quarter one summary, the next slide, all-time record there in Q1 for orders sales backlog net earnings and EBITDA, gross margin demonstrated that we didn't have any difficulty with input costs, 54.3%. Operating margins up 320 basis points to 22% that's leverage of 37%, by the way, on the OP line. And our EBITDA margins up 310 basis points to 27.4%, gives us a leverage of 43%.  As 43% leverage of course, benefits from iTrade we its amortization. 
Organic growth was 20% on orders, and 16% on sales. The $151 million backlog, I can remember were the total sales of the year, was $500 million. So being up 43% over the prior-year gives us a lot of optimism for the rest. Most importantly, as everything really performed well and if you look around, you can only find two or three things, which are quite small in our scope that are really doing exceptionally well. So we raised our guidance up to $3.97 to $4.12, and certainly, our position for another record year of Roper. And with that, let's open it up to questions, John.

componenttext: Just a couple of questions. Brian, the tone of your press release sounds a little bit more optimistic on kind of the availability of deals, or maybe reasonable properties at reasonable prices. Could you elaborate on that a little bit, and kind of talk about the pipeline?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I would say that there are a lot of opportunities, there are fewer that are reasonable. There are quite a lot that are relatively reasonable. So we're pretty encouraged by the transactions we have and the people we're talking with on these. On the s
componenttext: Well, I would say that there are a lot of opportunities, there are fewer that are reasonable. There are quite a lot that are relatively reasonable. So we're pretty encouraged by the transactions we have and the people we're talking with on these. On the same vein, somebody called me last night from Europe about a transaction that people think we should be interested in, which we never would be, but bragging that they would going to get a debt staple, of 6.75 on this transaction. So I mean the and lack of discipline around debt being applied to sales processes is pretty much back to the status that it's ever been. So you do want to be careful about what it is that you're doing. But we have more than enough really outstanding opportunity to execute over the next 12 months, so we're very encouraged. I would say that the things that we're doing, we like it as much as the transactions we've done recently with United Toll and with iTrade, and with Verathon, so I think there's exciting days ahead.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: And to go to iTrade, if you wouldn't mind, you said you couldn't elaborate too much on this possibly, European project, so it sounds like it's not possible, it sounds like you've booked it. Could you just speak a little bit to, is the scope of that job di
componenttext: And to go to iTrade, if you wouldn't mind, you said you couldn't elaborate too much on this possibly, European project, so it sounds like it's not possible, it sounds like you've booked it. Could you just speak a little bit to, is the scope of that job different than what they've done before? Really, the essence of my question, is you've bought you brought iTrade into the portfolio, are you finding ways to coordinate with some of the capabilities elsewhere in RF? And even if it doesn't apply to this particular deal, maybe you could give us a little color on that.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, those are kind of certainly two different things. So let's first, to start of the liberty to name names but it would have such a compelling name, but you're thinking of it domestically, you're like saying, Kroger, or Wal-Mart, or something like that
componenttext: Well, those are kind of certainly two different things. So let's first, to start of the liberty to name names but it would have such a compelling name, but you're thinking of it domestically, you're like saying, Kroger, or Wal-Mart, or something like that, it's a very, very large significant pan-European opportunity. And it will take us a couple of years to do everything we're going to be able to do with them, and lots to build that opportunity and then later, analytic opportunity with that. So we're really excited about that, that's one of the things we are really hoping with able to bring to that to the wheelhouse. And we have, we're making some growth investments in that, because we have to increase our server space. We have to have specific things in Europe for these people to access. In terms of other opportunities within the Roper, we have opportunities both in trade patching and in CBORD around menu planning and nutrition information, which we continue to work on. We've had some -- they're not cross-selling, they're technology sure opportunities for applications and we have important household names in the food industry. And just recently in Miami Florida extensive program, and we're going to continue to do that throughout the year. So yes, I think we will see some -- I think most of the sales will accrete to iTrade, but some may accrete to other things within that software the service platform we're building within RF.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: And just one other if I could do, and I'll pass it on. Neptune did some very strong, and you sited U.S. Is that some fresh penetration in places, or is that this is becoming mature enough now that you're seeing replacement activity, just a little color th
componenttext: And just one other if I could do, and I'll pass it on. Neptune did some very strong, and you sited U.S. Is that some fresh penetration in places, or is that this is becoming mature enough now that you're seeing replacement activity, just a little color there, please?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, it was up 20% in the U.S., so we thought we were just kind of comment on that, because other people were wondering about other people gaining share at our expense, it never happen, it didn't going to happen. What you've got to do is look at the othe
componenttext: Well, it was up 20% in the U.S., so we thought we were just kind of comment on that, because other people were wondering about other people gaining share at our expense, it never happen, it didn't going to happen. What you've got to do is look at the other people in Q1 and look at us. So this is the best premier business in the world than what it does. I would say the markets are fairly mature, certainly held back dramatically by the lack of housing starts, might and housing starts did think of much more growth we could get back in this business. It's just well-positioned with the right sort of hybrid ability to deal with, fixed network so were mobile, and any form of integration and migration. There's another thing that's emerging that people haven't paid enough attention to, and that is that we have the only U.S. lead-free water, period end of discussion. If anybody here who reinforces Buy American, or says I want lead-free water meters, which is a mandated requirement in the coming years, we're the sole sourceability to do that. Somebody's making lead-free in same factory in Mexico, I hardly think it would qualify as it's buying leadfree-only American meter. So we're very proud of Neptune, it's a wonderful management team. They're very dedicated in their work, and a lot on forward technologies. And that we will make further investments in that space to help them.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. Let me speak to that.  The adoption rates, particularly for Glasgow, continues to be very strong, with a lot of product enhancements and other things that we're doing there to make it a more mobile, so more people are able to have access to tha
componenttext: Yes, sure. Let me speak to that.  The adoption rates, particularly for Glasgow, continues to be very strong, with a lot of product enhancements and other things that we're doing there to make it a more mobile, so more people are able to have access to that in a hospital setting. So continued product refinements are continuing the adoption rate on the Glasgow side. And then on the bladder scan side, continue to take that core technology of the ultrasound and be able to make that apply into other areas, that's so what we do the orders can that's what we're going to do is delta port also, in order to make it easier to basically, have an IV needle inserted into someone's arm, when the vein may be very difficult to find, or difficult to see. So taking that same basic technology and making new products and new applications out of it, it's one of the things that surrounded Jerold and the team are just fabulous and being able to do out there a Verathon. And we continue to see lots of opportunities for that going forward, and in addition, don't forget that we did acquire product line called Heartscape about this time last year, and we expect that to have some product introductions into the marketplace late in 2011, and that will also add to the growth in 2012. So we're excited about what we see and the investments that we're making in Verathon will pay off.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, it's really helpful. And then in the RF mix of the businesses, just looking if RF tolling orders are really kind of a dam breaking, maybe a lot of pent-up demand projects coming through. We have a mix impact on operating margins this year, and als
componenttext: Thanks, it's really helpful. And then in the RF mix of the businesses, just looking if RF tolling orders are really kind of a dam breaking, maybe a lot of pent-up demand projects coming through. We have a mix impact on operating margins this year, and also the double-digits growth guidance, was that organic?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Oh, yes, yes, yes. All of that guides are organic. The situation in Q1, we had a good mix because we had tag shipments volume in Florida and Oklahoma and we continue somewhat in the quarter but unfortunately, the tag shipments are always lumpy, you can't
componenttext: Oh, yes, yes, yes. All of that guides are organic. The situation in Q1, we had a good mix because we had tag shipments volume in Florida and Oklahoma and we continue somewhat in the quarter but unfortunately, the tag shipments are always lumpy, you can't do much about those. And so within the next three quarters there'll be different results based on the mix of just the normal service work we do and product shipments. Since this is a huge variance there, both from gross margin basis and on cash contribution.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Brian, you used to be hearing your comments about some of the competitor actions in your space very recently, and I loved to your comments about how that is either an opportunity, or a threat, or not meaningful. And then the two, I'd like to either commen
componenttext: Brian, you used to be hearing your comments about some of the competitor actions in your space very recently, and I loved to your comments about how that is either an opportunity, or a threat, or not meaningful. And then the two, I'd like to either comment on if you could, the first would be the joint venture between 2 of your competitors in the tolling space, and the new owner of Mark 4 KTC, and the other would be the development of Blackboard, which is in a space with you, I think there's always misperception about what the actual overlap is. But if anything, it's a validation that this is an attractive space, considering the put yourselves up for sale. But where's the overlap?  Where's the adjacencies within Blackboard?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: We'll only take the Blackboard first. The blackboard really have 2 businesses, they have a business which is like CBORD, which we feel we continue to gain share against them in that space. That for them may be viewed for them as a legacy business, you'd h
componenttext: We'll only take the Blackboard first. The blackboard really have 2 businesses, they have a business which is like CBORD, which we feel we continue to gain share against them in that space. That for them may be viewed for them as a legacy business, you'd have to ask them. That's their university business. And then they have their business which is really education software that's have not being involved with University, the same traditional teaching setting we are familiar with. That we have nothing to do with them in that space, that's the largest portion of their revenue how profitable it this is something you have to talk to them about. So there's a small group of competitors like CBORD and Blackboard that are driving what's happening from an abduction viewpoint from universities. We've got we think, the best offerings in this space. So if Blackboard and does transact, then someone else takes it over, we wouldn't see that if anything other than what you said, which is validating the quality of the space. If you look at the kind of trading models that Blackboard had even before these 35% premium jack-up, you get, why sometimes we get frustrated about people thinking about us as a multi-industry company, as opposed to a diversified growth company, because so many of our assets today in the SaaS platform space just hinder values our extraordinary compared to the industry multiples and we think people should focus on the light of the assets we hold in that space. And secondary, as far as -- sure it was basically, unprofitable trading dollars business in Canada that was acquired by Federal Signal, so we do think we think of the now was Federal Signal, which is selling to municipal aspects of stuff. The series kind of the low end of technology, certainly. And then if you go over to which is in Australia company publicly-traded, they bought the Mark 4 assets out of that transaction around Mark 4 and bankruptcy and things were tangential to that. We haven't seen any resurgence of anything under Federal Signal, and we certainly haven't seen any resurgence of anything, other than Mark 4 is just continuing the sale of products in the E-ZPass. They didn't win anything new. We have been winning business in California with platforms that one of those peoples used to be involved with. It's certainly doesn't -- it doesn't hurt us in anyway. We wind up with Canadians and the Austrians and once again, we're the only American company have people focus in the Buy American provisions. We be getting even more of the business that those businesses used to enjoy, it hasn't happened yet. But we do think that people ought to focus on that. We have a wide range of technologies, we can do anything that those competitors can do at the bottom end or the high end, so we're kind of one-stop shop. I don't see that really changing.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011

componenttextpreview: Well, several of our businesses are not in the U.S. and the Industrial platform, our largest business space is based in Scotland, and our business is based in Denmark but the vast majority of our revenues are not in the U.S. and they are growing substanti
componenttext: Well, several of our businesses are not in the U.S. and the Industrial platform, our largest business space is based in Scotland, and our business is based in Denmark but the vast majority of our revenues are not in the U.S. and they are growing substantially. Our businesses is a German-based business, and it has a sure a record Q1, order make up for that business, which is very different than the domestic U.S. Flow Control businesses we have. And then the Roper Pump business is mostly a domestic expense which is doing exceptionally well now, because of the drilling in our technology which allows the frac-ing you've heard so much about. And then our Cornell business primarily domestic pump business will shift back to the Middle East but for the most part, it's designed to be a North American business for North American agriculture and municipal water handling. The scale of this business is such, that we would not invest a lot of money and sales outside the United States for these businesses other than things we have just unique niche applications. So the mix of Industrial is not disimilar outside of the U.S. 50% versus in the U.S.

componenttext: No. I think that people in the flow control industries have about 25x and more assets that are needed around the globe. There are confident players everywhere, we just select markets that we have unique competency in, and wouldn't be making dramatic new capital investments to make more pumps for the world.

componenttext: I just think the next five years will be harder than the last five years it's been. componenttext: Yes. Toronto is ramping up as expect. Of course, first quarter installations are always slow, as the ground is usually frozen there, and we're still in the kind of the build-out phase of the system that captures and collects and analyzes all the data. So we're doing couple of things there, not only the meter insulation, as well as the network, but also we're helping on the data management side. And then as we move forward through the year, we'll be ramping up as far as the installations are concerned. Now remember, Toronto is the unique situation where we will be overseeing the installation in addition to selling meters. So we'll have a mixed impact, and as we do the installation, it actually obviously, comes from lower margin than the more technology that's embedded than the meter does. And that, that of course, is roughly $200 million project that will ramp up to the market kind of a rate within the $35 million to $40 million range at it's peak as we get there in 2012 and '13, and then look to have this project completed and moving into replacement and ongoing data services beyond kind of the 2014, '15 timeframe.

componenttext: Well, we're always thinking we ought to be able to capture quite a bit, you've got gross margins that are above 50, so we would tend to think that we ought to be in that 25% to 35% range on a regular ongoing basis. headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: What I think what I going I'm going to look at the leverage when you got 37% OP leverage and 43% on EBITDA leverage, this demonstrate the discipline everybody has about keeping their fixed expense really quite low and reactive creatively to whatever varia
componenttext: What I think what I going I'm going to look at the leverage when you got 37% OP leverage and 43% on EBITDA leverage, this demonstrate the discipline everybody has about keeping their fixed expense really quite low and reactive creatively to whatever variable output that they have. We haven't had to do anything to ramp up to meet the increased demand. And with the book-to-bill of 109%, we ought to be able to do pretty well on revenue in the second quarter and the rest of the year. So when we started the year we thought gee, we probably will have a pretty good Q1, and Q2 will be okay, and will trail off. We don't think that way anymore. So Q1 is really quite good, Q2 is quite good, and the rest of the year will ought to be really good, but not trailing off as much we originally thought.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: If I can just to chime into that, remember, what we do with a breakeven analysis that we have a mandate to always lower that, but we always want to make sure to look at our businesses, and they look at their performance in terms of what their fixed costs
componenttext: If I can just to chime into that, remember, what we do with a breakeven analysis that we have a mandate to always lower that, but we always want to make sure to look at our businesses, and they look at their performance in terms of what their fixed costs and their variables, so they understand what the dollars of revenue should contribute in terms of leverage. And that wouldn't they make investment decisions but those are conscious thoughtful, prudent decisions to invest for growth opportunities. So we always want to make sure that we separate out the fixed costs infrastructure from the leverage on the incremental growth, so our business leaders are able to make smart decisions about how the growth is going forward.

componenttext: No. I wouldn't say that there was a mix benefit, there was clearly no mix downside from the additional installation revenue, that we do expect at some point in the future with Neptune in Toronto ramping up. componenttext: I think this point is probably a little bit early for us to be able to forecast of the incremental growth that we're seeing and probably a little bit much harder than what we had thought, maybe three months ago, how that will translate into year and working capital balances. If you can think about the net income impact of say, raising a $0.15 in the bottom for us, that's about $15 million of net income, and $15 million of after-tax cash. But like I said, it's a little early to forecast exactly what those year end balances will be. So we're comfortable still at $550 million or more, of operating cash flow. And as we get closer to the end of the year, we will have a better view of what some of those working capital balances will look like.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, Brian, I'm wondering if you could just put a little more color on your M&A comments from the standpoint of size of transactions, whether that might require some, or given the opportunity, to do some equity there. And in terms of the platfo
componenttext: Okay. And then, Brian, I'm wondering if you could just put a little more color on your M&A comments from the standpoint of size of transactions, whether that might require some, or given the opportunity, to do some equity there. And in terms of the platforms where you're seeing the better opportunities, can you provide will be could comment there, too?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that we can all -- there is more things to do than we would be willing to do with our capital structure, I mean we're going to remain an investment grade performer, and so you don't want to really have much more than say, 3x debt to EBITDA.
componenttext: Well, I think that we can all -- there is more things to do than we would be willing to do with our capital structure, I mean we're going to remain an investment grade performer, and so you don't want to really have much more than say, 3x debt to EBITDA. And if you look at our trailing EBITDA, it's going to ramp up quite dramatically here in the next quarter and third quarters. So we're going to have well in excess of $1 billion capacity with our existing structure without having to issue equity. I can't imagine issuing equity. You will have to be one heck of a breathtaking opportunity for us, and I just don't see that happening. I mean I wouldn't rule it out, if you have some kind of nirvana opportunity. But what we continue to just reinvest our cash flow, we think $500 million, $600 million a year is probably, where you go when you lever it up at 3x, could be more, we've got a lot of capacity now and exceptionally low. So maybe it goes up, but I wouldn't think we'd be doing some $2 billion transaction, I think we'd do $1 billion first.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011

componenttext: And platforms where pipelines are most robust, Energy, Industrial, Medical, RF across the board, any color there?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Every Industrial assets in the world for sale, we're not overly excited but the stuff we're seeing in that space or the lack of discipline that people have in what they're paying. So we continue to think that the talk in the service arena and the medical
componenttext: Every Industrial assets in the world for sale, we're not overly excited but the stuff we're seeing in that space or the lack of discipline that people have in what they're paying. So we continue to think that the talk in the service arena and the medical arena remain quite attractive businesses and there's plenty of growth in those businesses in terms of investments, acquisitions, and they really crowd out most of the other investment opportunities in terms of their cash and cash returns over time. So that remains our sharp focus. Maybe there'll be some niche thing along the way that we think is particularly good, but other than that pretty much, we're focused on those 2 areas. And I would just say, Terry, I think we had $87 million of operating cash flow in the quarter, not unusual for Q1. So with $550 million for the full year, we're talking about generating $463 million of operating cash flow in the next three quarters. And that $463 million in operating cash flow will be quite substantial is a function of revenue for the balance of the year. And when you already got $800 million in available liquidity, and you know you're going to create another $400-plus million of free cash flow between now and the end of the year, that gives us all the power we're going to need to make real by high-quality transactions.

componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to today's Roper Quarter and Year Financial Results Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded. I will now turn the call over to Mr. John Humphrey, Chief Financial Officer. Please go ahead.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Melanie, and thank you all for joining us this morning as we discussed the record results for our first quarter 2011. Joining me this morning is Brian Jellison, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Paul Soni, Vice President and
componenttext:
Thank you, Melanie, and thank you all for joining us this morning as we discussed the record results for our first quarter 2011. Joining me this morning is Brian Jellison, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Paul Soni, Vice President and Controller.
Earlier this morning, we issued a press release announcing our financial results. The press release also includes a replay information for today's call. In addition, we've prepared slides to accompany today's call, which are available through the webcast and also available on our website at www.roperind.com.
Now if you'll please turn to Slide 2. We begin with our Safe Harbor statement. During the course of today's call, we will be making forward-looking statements, which are subject to the risks and uncertainties as described on this page and as detailed in our SEC filings. You should listen to today's call in the context of that information.
And now if you'll please turn to Slide 3. I'll turn the call over to Brian Jellison, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer. After his prepared remarks, we'll take questions from our participants. Brian?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John, and good morning, everyone. We'll take you first through the Q1 financial results in detail, and then we'll look at the segment performance and the outlook for Q2 and the rest of the year. I'll talk about raising our guidance and then sor
componenttext:
Thank you, John, and good morning, everyone. We'll take you first through the Q1 financial results in detail, and then we'll look at the segment performance and the outlook for Q2 and the rest of the year. I'll talk about raising our guidance and then sort of summarize the quarter and take your questions.
First slide here is the financial results. You can see we achieved a record, all-time record for Q1, in orders and sales backlog, net earnings, EBITDA and pretty much every other measurement you can imagine. The thing that was particularly gratifying was our book-to-bill ratio was 109%. Generally, we're at the sort of 97% to 103%, so to be at 109% is very encouraging for the remainder of the year. 
Organic growth was really quite spectacular, we thought with 20% order growth. And all 4 of the segments had double-digit order growth and revenue growth, which you can see organically was 16%.
Gross margins increased to 54.3%, so any fear of input costs creating any difficulty at Roper was not well founded. EBITDA margins are up 310 basis points to 27.4%. Remember with us that's mostly EBITA. There's not much depreciation here. 
Our balance sheet was enhanced as we continued to pay down our revolver, and we ended the quarter with an all-time record backlog of $851 million in revenue, which is 43% higher than the backlog at the end of the first quarter last year, up $257 million. Now we certainly, when we established our guidance for Q1, thought we would have a strong start, but this is even better than our best expectations.
Next slide. Our income statement. Here you could see the bookings at $702 million, up 24% in total and 20% organically. Net sales of $645 million, up 21% in total and 16% organically. Our gross profit went from 52.3% at first quarter of last year to 54.3% here, an increase of 200 basis points. 
Our operating income was up 41%, that went from 18.8% last year to 22% this year, so that's really quite outstanding leverage. In fact, we'll talk a little bit more about our leverage on the variable contribution here for the revenue.
Our interest expense was basically flat. The tax rate was also quite similar to the prior year and that produced net earnings, up 49% to $89 million from $59.7 million last year and a diluted earnings per share number of $0.91 versus the $0.62 GAAP number from the prior year.
On the next slide. On the asset velocity, while the absolute amount -- the dollar amount of inventory receivable was up a little bit, as a function of the revenue it continues to decline. You'll see in the first quarter our inventory was 7.7% of revenue, down from 8.2%. In the prior year, our receivables were down to 16%, a pickup of 50 basis points from the 16.5% the prior year. And our payables and accruals or liabilities there actually increased to 16.1% from 15.8%. So when we total it, at the end of last year, we were 8.9% of sales, and this year it's down 130 basis points to 7.6% of revenues. So year-over-year, we see continued improvement in our asset velocity.
Next slide. We ended the quarter with a really strong balance sheet. Cash was $261 million. We paid down the revolver, so there's quite a bit of the revolver left. When you take the revolver and the cash together, we wind up with $813 million of available liquidity. And of course, we'll have very strong cash in Q2 and throughout the rest of the year. 
Our net debt is down to $980 million, and you can see that gives us a net debt-to-EBITDA ratio on a trailing basis of only 1.4x, and our EBITDA will continue to expand rapidly throughout the year on a trailing basis. Our EBITDA-to-interest coverage is already at 10.2x. So these ratios are extremely strong and they really enhance our liquidity and our ability to use the balance sheet in the quarters ahead.
Next slide. Here we're going to look at the individual segment performance and the outlook. 
Next slide. Order strength, as you can see, was really spectacular. Industrial Technology was up 30%, RF Technology was up 30%, Energy systems & Controls at 16% and Medical & Scientific up 15%. The book-to-bill ratios were very strong all the way across, anywhere from 118% in Industrial down to 103% in Medical & Imaging. We had double-digit organic growth in all 4 segments for revenue as well.
Next slide. If you look at the RF Technology, you can see that orders reached $217 million in the quarter, up 30% from the prior year and 18% organically. Our sales were $200 million, which was up 23% year-over-year and up more than 10% organically. Our gross margin expanded to 51.4%, which was up 170 basis points, and our operating margin was up 270 basis points. We finished the quarter with an EBITDA margin of 30.7%, which was up 450 basis points from the first quarter of 2010. So you see very strong EBITDA performance with our iTrade business contributing a substantial amount of noncash amortization to the EBITDA measure here.
In the first quarter of 2011, we had very strong tag sales for both Florida, Oklahoma and Dubai. In fact our Amtech business was up over 40%. A significant growth in our Gas Automated Meter Reading business with the Gaz de France project and quite substantial increase in the U.K., our Water Network Metering and Motoring business as those were up well in excess of 40% as well. And in CBORD, we had an expanded subscriber base. We won in another major University of Miami, university in Ohio, a big security win there, displacing a longtime occupant in that role.
In Q2, what we'd see is that the Gaz de France AMR project ought to continue at similar levels to Q1. We'll have a very strong seasonal Q2 because CBORD winds up with their annual renewals following into the second quarter, so we should see a double-digit growth there. 
Our Houston METRO project appears to be on schedule, and we ought to see what we have in our forecast for the second quarter. And iTrade has won a very, very significant opportunity to launch a system for a major European food retailer that we can't yet announce, but the launch is underway and the integration will begin within the year.
It's very encouraging for us to see the direction at RF Technology because last year in 2010's first quarter, our organic revenue was down 12%, the second quarter was down 7%, third quarter was down 1%, the fourth quarter was up 6%. So we're out of the gate here with more than a 10% organic gain here in the first quarter, and we expect the balance of the year is going to give us double-digit growth throughout the next 3 quarters.  Q2 a little lighter, Q3 much stronger and Q4 similar to this quarter.
Next slide. In Industrial Technology, just absolutely spectacular performance here. Our orders were up 30% to $201 million. Of course, that's all organic. Our sales were up 26%, aided by about 60 basis points of FX, so you could round organic down to 25%. Gross margins were at 50.4%, so they've continued to expand, and their operating margin was up 370 basis points to 27.2%. EBITDA in Industrial Technology finished the quarter at 30.6%. 
Virtually, everyone there had a very strong quarter. Our Fluid Handling businesses that deal with gas and exploration with the new products we've launched in the last year and half just are having extraordinary performance. These businesses are nearly up 50%. The Material Testing business we have as we can to get better capacity utilization around the country is growing very rapidly. 
And we actually had double-digit growth in our U.S. business in Neptune and then still more growth as a result of Canada continuing to shift in the Mexico City order we announced in the fourth quarter. So Neptune had a very strong Q1, and we expect that to continue.
In Q2, the backlog at our Fluid Handling businesses that are offering Cornell Pump will assure double-digit growth in the second quarter. The Toronto project installation phase is going to actually ramp up in Q2, although because there's a lot of labor in that it comes in at the expected lower margins that we have there. 
End markets remain very strong always in all these Industrial categories, and the operating leverage that we get is continuing to drive margin performance. You can really see just how effective we are when you look at the spot price for copper. In the first quarter last year, it was $3.55. Spot price this year is $4.30 and yet our margins expanded across the board whether they're gross margins, operating margins or EBITDA margins.
Next slide. The Energy Systems & Control segment. It continues to perform well. Here, orders were up 16%, all organic. Sales up 23%. Gross margin expanded quite a bit from up 350 basis points to 54.1%. And the operating profit margin increased 450 basis point. You might remember we were somewhat disappointed in Q1 2010 where the operating margin got that corrected in the second quarter, and this shows the kind of firm, disciplined approach to what we needed to do after that first quarter of last year. And that certainly supports this 450 basis point improvement in OP. EBITDA margins here were about 26%. 
Again you can say exactly the same thing, the same words that apply to Industrial Technology: broad-based strength across all businesses and end markets. Everything here is really doing exceptionally well. Very dramatic growth in our Diesel Engine Surge Protection business. We almost called it explosive growth, but thought that might scare people. That business is up nearly 40% this year. Industrial end market growth continues to drive our Sensors business as capacity utilization back in the latex or rubber industry looks very good and then equipment sales to measure the output of those things were up sharply. And all of our Energy Lab Equipment businesses are doing okay as we've finally got a little bit improvement in both refining and petrochem markets.
In the second quarter, the end market dynamics we think will continue to be strong. Our backlog is really quite substantial in our Compressor Control business, which will start to drive better Vs here in Q2 and particularly in the second half of the year. And the margin expansion we think will continue to be driven just by the operating leverage as sales increased throughout the year.
Next slide. Here's the Medical & Imaging segment. Orders were up 15%. Tiny bit of FX there, so organic it was 14%. Sales were up 12%. The gross margins here, 62.8%, up 330 basis points. And our OP was up to 24.1%. EBITDA in this segment is 29.1%, so EBITDA margins increased by 110 basis points. 
We've done quite a bit of investing in the first quarter in our Verathon business. We're launching 2 new products, one is called Velaport [ph] and that has had us incur some growth expense in Q1 and that will continue a little bit into Q2 as we launch all that collateral literature and the various programs and held a sales meeting in Q1 to kick that product off along with some other things we're doing as well. 
Medical remains a strong on consumables, double-digit growth in all these businesses in our kidney dialysis application for our Dosage Delivery Pump business continued to be a double-digit grower. Very significant order growth in our high-end imaging cameras and filtering technology. It was the growth star of the quarter as we look at the filters for electron microscopy being up very dramatically.
In the second quarter of 2011, we see Medical continuing to grow at double digits as we get continuing adoption rates for GlideScope and Velaport [ph]. Those new products have been launched within this year. And the Scientific Imaging has a really quite substantial backlog. They will support a strong Q2. 
The Japanese supply risks have proven to be less difficult than what we feared on certain high-end chips that are made very specifically for us. We've kind of dealt with all those issues and feel quite good about it. The only thing for Japan is that a substantial portion of our Camera business goes into the Japanese market. It represents a disproportionate share compared to the rest of Roper.  
Our total sales into Japan are in the neighborhood of 3% of revenues, so it's not something that's overly difficult for us that could depress revenue growth for the camera portion of the business in the next quarter or 2. But then that will just fill the backlog. It will be good news for us later.
Next slide. Here, as we look at the guidance, we're going to raise the guidance. 
Next slide. We were at $3.82 to $4.2. When we went into the year, we've raised the base by $0.15 and the top end by $0.10 to take us to $3.97 to $4.12. The midpoint of that is more than a 20% increase over last year's $3.34 on a GAAP basis. And in the second quarter, we're at $0.95 to $1, which is quite a sharp increase over last year's Q2 performance. 
Basically, the sales we expect to have, kind of mid-teens organic growth in the second quarter and the second half of the year. Probably in the kind of high single digit, 8% to 10% or 11%, so the full year will be double-digit organic growth. 
Just the next slide would be the -- well, we're still reaffirming that the cash flow would be in excess of $550 million, so that -- you can imagine the next 3 quarters will be quite substantial in terms of operating cash flow will generate.
In quarter 1 summary, the next slide. All-time record there in Q1 for order sales backlog, net earnings and EBITDA. Gross margin demonstrated that we didn't have any difficulty with input costs at 54.3%. Operating margin is up 320 basis points to 22%. That's leverage of 37%, by the way, on the OP line. And our EBITDA margin is up 310 basis points to 27.4%. It gives us a leverage of 43%.  At 43% leverage, of course, benefits from iTrade with its amortization. 
Organic growth was 20% on orders and 16% on sales. The $851 million backlog -- boy, I can remember when our total sales for the year were $500 million. So being up 43% over the prior year gives us a flood of optimism for the rest. 
Most importantly, as everything really performed well. If you look around, you can only find 2 or 3 things, which are quite small in their scope that aren't really doing exceptionally well. So we raised our guidance up to $3.97 to $4.12 and certainly our position for another record year at Roper. 
And with that, let's open it up to questions, John.

componenttextpreview: Just a couple of questions. Brian, the tone of your press release sounds a little bit more optimistic on kind of the availability of deals or maybe reasonable properties at reasonable prices. Could you elaborate on that a little bit, and kind of talk abou
componenttext: Just a couple of questions. Brian, the tone of your press release sounds a little bit more optimistic on kind of the availability of deals or maybe reasonable properties at reasonable prices. Could you elaborate on that a little bit, and kind of talk about the pipeline?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I would say that there are a lot of opportunities. There are fewer that are reasonable. But there are quite a lot that are relatively reasonable. So we're pretty encouraged by the transactions we have and the people we're talking with on these. In t
componenttext: Well, I would say that there are a lot of opportunities. There are fewer that are reasonable. But there are quite a lot that are relatively reasonable. So we're pretty encouraged by the transactions we have and the people we're talking with on these. In the same venue -- somebody called me last night from Europe about a transaction that people think we should be interested in, which we never would be, but bragging that they were going to get us debt staple of 6 3/4 on this transaction. So I mean the frothiness and lack of discipline around debt being applied to sales processes is pretty much back to the status it's ever been. So you do want to be careful about what it is you're doing. But we have more than enough really outstanding opportunity to execute over the next 12 months. So we're very encouraged. I would say that the things that we're doing, we like it as much as the transactions we've done recently with United Toll and with iTrade and with Verathon, so I think there's exciting days ahead.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: And to go to iTrade, if you wouldn't mind, you said you couldn't elaborate too much on this possibly European project, or it sounds like it's not possible. It sounds like you've booked it. Could you just speak a little bit to -- is the scope of that job d
componenttext: And to go to iTrade, if you wouldn't mind, you said you couldn't elaborate too much on this possibly European project, or it sounds like it's not possible. It sounds like you've booked it. Could you just speak a little bit to -- is the scope of that job different than what they've done before? Really, the essence of my question is as you've brought iTrade into the portfolio, are you finding ways to coordinate with some of the capabilities elsewhere in RF? And even if it doesn't apply to this particular deal, maybe you could give us a little color on that.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, those are kind of 2 totally different things. So let's first, just on this European thing. We just aren't at liberty to name a name, but it would have such a compelling name that you're thinking of it domestically. It'll be like saying we got Kroger
componenttext: Well, those are kind of 2 totally different things. So let's first, just on this European thing. We just aren't at liberty to name a name, but it would have such a compelling name that you're thinking of it domestically. It'll be like saying we got Kroger or we got Wal-Mart or something like that. It's a very, very large significant pan-European opportunity. And it will take us a couple of years to do everything we're going to be able to do with them and lots to build that opportunity and then later analytic opportunity with that. So we're really excited about that. It's 1 of the things we're really hoping we'd able to bring into the wheelhouse. And we have -- we're making some growth investments in that because we have to increase our server space. We have to have specific things in Europe for these people to access. In terms of other opportunities within the Roper, we have opportunities both in freight matching and in CBORD around menu planning and nutrition information, which we continue to work on. We've had some -- they're not cross-selling, they're technology-sharing opportunities for applications. And we had important household names in the food industry. And just recently in Miami, Florida extensive program, and we're going to continue to do that throughout the year. So yes, I think we will see some -- I think most of the sales will accrete to iTrade, but some may accrete to other things within the "software as a service" platform we're building within RF.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: And just 1 other if I could, and I'll pass it on. Neptune did some like it was very strong and you cited U.S. Is that some fresh penetration in places, or is that business becoming mature enough now that you're seeing some replacement activity? Just a lit
componenttext: And just 1 other if I could, and I'll pass it on. Neptune did some like it was very strong and you cited U.S. Is that some fresh penetration in places, or is that business becoming mature enough now that you're seeing some replacement activity? Just a little color there, please.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, it was up about 20% in the U.S., so we thought we would just kind of comment on that because other people were wondering about people gaining share at our expense. It never happened. Isn't going to happen. And all you got to do is look at the other
componenttext: Well, it was up about 20% in the U.S., so we thought we would just kind of comment on that because other people were wondering about people gaining share at our expense. It never happened. Isn't going to happen. And all you got to do is look at the other people in Q1 and look at us. So this is the best premier business in the world than what it does. I would say the markets are fairly mature, certainly held back dramatically by the lack of housing starts. My goodness, if we hadn't any housing starts, you'd think how much more organic growth we would get back in that business. It's just well positioned with the right sort of hybrid ability to deal with fixed network, so we're mobile in any form of integration and migration. There's another thing that's emerging that people haven't paid enough attention to and that is that we have the only U.S. lead-free water meter. Period. End of discussion. If anybody ever reinforces buy American or says I want lead-free water meters, which is a mandated requirement in the coming years, we're the sole sourceability to do that. Somebody is making lead-free and lead in the same factory in Mexico, I hardly think it would qualify as buying American lead-free-only water meter. So we're very proud of Neptune. It's a wonderful management team. They're very dedicated to their work and a lot on forward technologies. And you know, we may make further investments in that space to help them.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011

componenttext: Thanks. Brian, just wondering on the Imaging trends. The Verathon seemed to be in a pretty strong ramp throughout last year. Just wondering if those initial product lines are more approaching run rate? And if you could add any color on what the commercial opportunity might look like for some of the new product launches there?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me ask John to talk to that. I guess John really focused on Verathon here.
componenttext: Yes, let me ask John to talk to that. I guess John really focused on Verathon here.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure, yes. I'll go ahead and speak to that.  The adoption rates, particularly for GlideScope continues to be very strong, with a lot of product enhancements and other things that we're doing there to make it a more mobile, so more people are able to have
componenttext: Sure, yes. I'll go ahead and speak to that.  The adoption rates, particularly for GlideScope continues to be very strong, with a lot of product enhancements and other things that we're doing there to make it a more mobile, so more people are able to have access to that in a hospital setting. So continued product refinements or continuing the adoption rate on the GlideScope side. And then on the BladderScan side, continuing to take that core technology of the ultrasound and be able to make that applied in other areas. That's what we've done with AortaScan. That's what we're going to do with Velaport [ph] also in order to make it easier to basically have an IV needle inserted into someone's arm when the vein may be very difficult to find or difficult to see. So taking that same basic technology and making new products and new applications out of it is one of the things that Gerald and the team are just fabulous at being able to do out there at Verathon. And we continue to see lots of opportunities for that going forward. And in addition, don't forget we did acquire product line called Heartscape about this time last year, and we expect that to have some product introductions into the marketplace late in 2011, and that'll also add to growth in 2012. So we're excited about what we see and the investments that we're making in Verathon will pay off.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, it's really helpful. And then in the RF mix of the businesses, just looking if RF -- the tolling orders are really kind of a dam breaking, maybe a lot of pent-up demand and projects coming through. We have a mix impact on operating margins this ye
componenttext: Thanks, it's really helpful. And then in the RF mix of the businesses, just looking if RF -- the tolling orders are really kind of a dam breaking, maybe a lot of pent-up demand and projects coming through. We have a mix impact on operating margins this year and also the double-digits growth guidance, was that organic?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Oh, yes, yes, yes. All of that guides we're talking about was organic. The situation in Q1, we had a good mix because we had tag shipments to Dubai and Florida and Oklahoma and that'll continue somewhat in the second quarter. But unfortunately, the tag sh
componenttext: Oh, yes, yes, yes. All of that guides we're talking about was organic. The situation in Q1, we had a good mix because we had tag shipments to Dubai and Florida and Oklahoma and that'll continue somewhat in the second quarter. But unfortunately, the tag shipments are always lumpy. We can't do much about those. And so within the next 3 quarters, there'll be different results based on the mix of just the normal service work we do and product shipments. Since there's a huge variance there both from gross margin basis and cash contribution.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Deane Dray with Citi.
componenttext: We'll go next to Deane Dray with Citi.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, everyone. Brian, we're used to be hearing your comments about some of the competitor actions in your space very recently and love to hear your comments about how that is either an opportunity or a threat or not meaningful. And the
componenttext: Thank you. Good morning, everyone. Brian, we're used to be hearing your comments about some of the competitor actions in your space very recently and love to hear your comments about how that is either an opportunity or a threat or not meaningful. And the 2, I'd like to either comment on, if you could, the first would be the joint venture between 2 of your competitors in the tolling space, Sirit, and the new owner of Mark IV KTC. And the other would be the development at Blackboard, which is in a space with you. I think there's always misperceptions about what the actual overlap is. But if anything, it's a validation that this is an attractive space, considering they put themselves up for sale. But where's the overlap?  Where's the adjacencies within Blackboard?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: We'll only take the Blackboard. First, the blackboard really has 2 businesses. They have a business, which is like CBORD which we feel we continue to gain share against them in that space. That for them may be viewed more as a legacy business. You'd have
componenttext: We'll only take the Blackboard. First, the blackboard really has 2 businesses. They have a business, which is like CBORD which we feel we continue to gain share against them in that space. That for them may be viewed more as a legacy business. You'd have to ask them. That's their university business. And then they have their business, which is really education software that's -- had it not be involved with the university in the same traditional teaching setting we're familiar with. We have nothing to do with them in that space. That's the largest portion of their revenue. How profitable it is, is something you have to talk to them about. So there's a small group of competitors like CBORD and Blackboard that are driving what's happening from an adoption viewpoint with universities. We've got a, we think, the best offering in this space. So if Blackboard, in fact does transact, then someone else takes it over we wouldn't see that as anything other than what you said, which is validating the quality of the space. If you look at the kind of trading mobiles that Blackboard had even before this 35% premium jack-up, you get why sometimes we get frustrated about people thinking about us as a multi-industry company as opposed to a diversified growth company because so many of our assets today in the SaaS platform space are just [indiscernible] values are extraordinary compared to the multi-industry multiples. And we think people should focus on all of the assets we hold in that space. And secondary, as far as -- I mean, Sirit was basically unprofitable or bad trading dollar business in Canada. That was acquired by Federal Signal, so we do think of Misure it now. We think of it as Federal Signal, which is primarily business selling to different municipal aspects of stuff. Sirit is at kind of the low end of technology, certainly. And then if you go over to Kapsch, which is an Austrian company publicly traded, they bought the Mark IV assets out of that transaction around Mark 4 and bankruptcy and all those things that were tangential to that. We haven't seen any resurgence, of anything under Federal Signal, and we certainly haven't seen any resurgence of anything other than Mark IV as just continuing the sale of products in the E-ZPass. They don't win anything new. We have been winning business in California with platforms that one of those people used to be involved with. It's certainly doesn't -- it doesn't hurt us in anyway. We wind up with Canadians and the Austrians and once again we're the only American company. If people focus on the Buy American provisions, we'd be getting even more of the business that those businesses used to enjoy. It hasn't happened yet. But we do think people ought to focus on that. We have a wide range of technologies. We can do anything that those competitors can do at the bottom end or the high end, so we're kind of one-stop shop. I don't see that really changing.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Great. And just a follow-up for me would be on the E-ZPass. Any new development there and expectations, and how long this takes to play out?
componenttext: Great. And just a follow-up for me would be on the E-ZPass. Any new development there and expectations, and how long this takes to play out?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: I guess whatever the long side is, Deane, you take back. I mean there are people who claim that a decision would be made in August. We're encouraged to hear that whereas I was wondering what kind of decision would that be. But the testing is completed on
componenttext: I guess whatever the long side is, Deane, you take back. I mean there are people who claim that a decision would be made in August. We're encouraged to hear that whereas I was wondering what kind of decision would that be. But the testing is completed on everything, I believe. And what's happened is that we enjoy as North Carolina completed their testing for all of our products and have started to take deliveries. And in North Carolina, we've got a ubiquitous solution that allows a whole lot of freedom for people using various tags that has never been in the marketplace before. So we know from a technology viewpoint we have a winning formula, and then it's just a matter of what kind of decision ever gets made by these New York and New Jersey people and the rest of the consortium which makes up the interagency group.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011

componenttext: Great. Thank you.
