componenttext: Couple of questions. First, Brian, given the overall size of the Toronto project and the significance of that, can you give us a little more granularity and kind of what that contributed to revenue in '10 and how that ramp looks in '11 and '12? And would you say -- I know it got delayed, but would you say relative to where you expected it to be today, is it sort of back on track in that regard?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. The Toronto ramp. I'm going to let John handle that because I think -- I'm not sure exactly what he said there, but if we could have you verify it.
componenttext: Yes. The Toronto ramp. I'm going to let John handle that because I think -- I'm not sure exactly what he said there, but if we could have you verify it.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure. Yes. Toronto is ramping up as expected. Of course, first quarter installations are always slow as the ground is usually frozen there. And we're still in the kind of the build-out phase of the system that captures and collects and analyzes all the da
componenttext: Sure. Yes. Toronto is ramping up as expected. Of course, first quarter installations are always slow as the ground is usually frozen there. And we're still in the kind of the build-out phase of the system that captures and collects and analyzes all the data. So we're really doing a couple of things there, not only the meter installation as well as the network, but also helping on the data management side. And then as we move forward through the year, we'll be ramping up as far as installations are concerned. Now remember, Toronto is the unique situation where we will be overseeing the installation in addition to selling meters. So we'll have a mixed impact, that as we're doing the installation, that actually obviously comes at lower margin than the more technology that's embedded than the meter does. And that, of course, is roughly a $200 million project that will ramp up to -- or it may end up at a kind of a run rate within the $35 million to $40 million range at its peak as we get there in 2012 and '13 and then look to have this project completed and moving into replacement and ongoing data services beyond kind of the 2014, '15 time frame.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: And I think, Matt, that last year in our base data it's less than $10 million, I think we've got $5 million, $6 million, $7 million. And then this year, maybe it'll be 5x that or something like that. So the real expansion is in '13 and '14. This year, we'
componenttext: And I think, Matt, that last year in our base data it's less than $10 million, I think we've got $5 million, $6 million, $7 million. And then this year, maybe it'll be 5x that or something like that. So the real expansion is in '13 and '14. This year, we'll get some improvement in revenue less than 1% of our total growth attributed to that in the -- at the enterprise level. Not a lot.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then just overall, when you look across your businesses, Brian, are you concerned about municipal spending, municipal budgets or lack thereof? How do you sort of -- how do you reconcile those trends with how you're kind of guiding your busines
componenttext: Got it. And then just overall, when you look across your businesses, Brian, are you concerned about municipal spending, municipal budgets or lack thereof? How do you sort of -- how do you reconcile those trends with how you're kind of guiding your businesses right now?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, we are worried about that. We worry about that from a state and municipal spending level. We worry about it from Department of Transportation funding and the like. One of the reasons that we were really pleased with Q1, getting 20% organic growth, w
componenttext: Well, we are worried about that. We worry about that from a state and municipal spending level. We worry about it from Department of Transportation funding and the like. One of the reasons that we were really pleased with Q1, getting 20% organic growth, was that we didn't see any kind of slowness or holdbacks on the things that we've been working with people. They're -- and we've done a very deep dive in looking at how much of our spending on the water meter side is really related to municipalities versus related to the other facilities that are funded in different ways. We're actually much more optimistic about what's happening in how we distribute and go to market and create revenue. We wouldn't have anything good to say about municipal spending or state spending. But the DOTs and the people that we work with in those arenas are really outside of that list because everything we do in these spaces is revenue generation. It's not -- we don't need a budget or a muni bond to fund the activity that is going to happen with us. So the growth that we've got in Q1 and that we expect throughout the year is certainly ahead of our fears, which is really part of the reason we were willing to raise guidance as much as we did.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then lastly, Brian, I think 1 of your last prepared remarks talked about your incremental operating margins being somewhere in the range of 37% in the quarter, which is obviously very good. How do you feel about sustainability of that type of number g
componenttext: And then lastly, Brian, I think 1 of your last prepared remarks talked about your incremental operating margins being somewhere in the range of 37% in the quarter, which is obviously very good. How do you feel about sustainability of that type of number given some of the mix dynamics that have come out on this call?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, we're always thinking we ought to be able to capture quite a bit. You got gross margins that are above 50%, so we would tend to think that we ought to be in the 25% to 35% range on a regular ongoing basis. And really could do better than that. What'
componenttext: Well, we're always thinking we ought to be able to capture quite a bit. You got gross margins that are above 50%, so we would tend to think that we ought to be in the 25% to 35% range on a regular ongoing basis. And really could do better than that. What's happening right now is that we're -- we've got intangible amortization associated with iTrade, which confuses the world on a -- if you only look at GAAP, you can get really confused, as we all know. iTrade's a phenomenal business. It's given us a lot more so the OP was 37%. Maybe much more importantly, the EBITDA was 43%. So I think this idea that Roper will do 25% to 30% is exceptionally conservative. So we're probably going to do 30% to 35%, and that might even be conservative.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks a lot, Brian.
componenttext: Thanks a lot, Brian.

componenttext: No. I think what was unusual was how broad based it was. I mean with -- you can't find anybody to beat up. It's just spectacular.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And speaking of beating people up, your breakeven lowering mandate for the company, can you kind of talk about whether there's anything specific this year that we should be looking for in terms of particular projects to lower breakeven at various bu
componenttext: Okay. And speaking of beating people up, your breakeven lowering mandate for the company, can you kind of talk about whether there's anything specific this year that we should be looking for in terms of particular projects to lower breakeven at various businesses?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think all you got to do is just look at the leverage. When you get that 37% OP leverage and 43% on EBITDA leverage, it demonstrates the discipline everybody has about keeping their fixed expense really quite low and reacted creatively to whatever
componenttext: Well, I think all you got to do is just look at the leverage. When you get that 37% OP leverage and 43% on EBITDA leverage, it demonstrates the discipline everybody has about keeping their fixed expense really quite low and reacted creatively to whatever variable output needs they have. We haven't had to do anything to ramp up to meet the increased demand. And with a book-to-bill of 109%, we ought to be able to do pretty well on the revenue in the second quarter and the rest of the year. So when we started the year we thought, gee, we'll probably have pretty good Q1 and Q2 will be okay. It ought to trail off. We don't think that way anymore. So Q1 is really quite good, Q2 should be quite good and the rest of the year ought to be really good, but not trailing off as much as we originally thought.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: And Wendy, if I can just chime in on that. Remember, what we do with the breakeven analysis, it's not that we have a mandate to always lower that, but we always want to make sure that we look at our businesses and that they look at their performance in te
componenttext: And Wendy, if I can just chime in on that. Remember, what we do with the breakeven analysis, it's not that we have a mandate to always lower that, but we always want to make sure that we look at our businesses and that they look at their performance in terms of what their fixed costs and their variable, so they understand what the next dollar of revenue should contribute in terms of leverage. And that when they make investment decisions, that those are conscious, thoughtful, prudent decisions to invest for growth opportunities. So we always want to make sure that we separate out the fixed costs infrastructure from the leverage on incremental growth, so our business leaders are able to make smart decisions about how to grow going forward.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And finally, given your -- just the comments you just made, Brian, and your -- in the slides, it says expected strong start and did even better. Can you give us some sense of what were the 2 or 3 things that really impressed you in the first quarter
componenttext: Okay. And finally, given your -- just the comments you just made, Brian, and your -- in the slides, it says expected strong start and did even better. Can you give us some sense of what were the 2 or 3 things that really impressed you in the first quarter that changed your view for the full year?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: I would just say the breadth of everything. Every business in Industrial, every business in Energy outperformed really our expectations and their own expectations. And so it isn't that 1 business had a blowout. I mean, certainly, our Cornell and Roper bus
componenttext: I would just say the breadth of everything. Every business in Industrial, every business in Energy outperformed really our expectations and their own expectations. And so it isn't that 1 business had a blowout. I mean, certainly, our Cornell and Roper businesses had all-time record performance, which is good. But again, the scale of those is not enough to really drive the enterprise.  So it's really just the breadth of things that drove the enterprise.

componenttext: Okay, thank you so much.

componenttext: Yes. 2 quick follow-ups. I mean just on the Industrial Technology side platform, the EBIT margin, did that benefit significantly from mix in that segment? I mean, we talked about maybe Toronto ramping slowly, a little slower here in terms of meter sales. Was there any mix issue there, the Pumps and Materials business being much stronger?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: No. I really wouldn't say that there was a mix benefit. There was clearly no mix downside from the additional installation revenue, that we do expect at some point in the future with Neptune in Toronto ramping up. But the nice thing about these businesses
componenttext: No. I really wouldn't say that there was a mix benefit. There was clearly no mix downside from the additional installation revenue, that we do expect at some point in the future with Neptune in Toronto ramping up. But the nice thing about these businesses is that they have similar operating characteristics and similar margins. And even on the equipment side versus the aftermarket, obviously the aftermarket parts will be a little bit higher margin, but it's not a dramatic change, it's not like an aerospace business where maybe you don't make anything on the OE and you make it all on the aftermarket. That's not all what we're seeing in Industrial. Our new equipment revenue, we love to see it because it not only generates more spare parts in the future, but it generates more cash today. So really, there's not a huge mix impact there.

componenttext: But the pumps and material handlings piece there versus, say, Neptune, I would think the contribution margin there would have been above that total platform level.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then Brian, could I -- just real quickly, has there been any uptick in interest and perhaps orders at Zetec given what happened in Japan and kind of the forced global kind of inspection requirements maybe on the nuclear industry or elsewhere out
componenttext: Okay. And then Brian, could I -- just real quickly, has there been any uptick in interest and perhaps orders at Zetec given what happened in Japan and kind of the forced global kind of inspection requirements maybe on the nuclear industry or elsewhere outside of Japan?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Great question, Rick. We haven't included anything in terms of Zetec growth at all in our pathway. We've had lengthy calls on that with people and we're doing a lot. We have volunteered a lot of resources for people to do various testing things, and we al
componenttext: Great question, Rick. We haven't included anything in terms of Zetec growth at all in our pathway. We've had lengthy calls on that with people and we're doing a lot. We have volunteered a lot of resources for people to do various testing things, and we also have this robotic testing technology, which is really quite an important technology called, Robospec [ph]. But we could, we would like to believe we would see a spike in the second half on inspections in the U.S., 104 plants. When the thing initially happened and people started talking about it, we felt we might get a 25% spike in half 2, but remember, it's not a real large business. But we're not seeing that scheduled in any way, which is really sort of interesting. So I think everybody has kind of actually stopped the work and is thinking about what it is they need to do and what's the prioritization of that. And our stuff is just measuring the structural integrity of the cooling towers. So it may well be that'll have a bigger impact in 2012 then it'll have in 2011 for us.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011

componenttext: Okay. And then just a last question. componenttextpreview: Thanks. Brian, we're seeing a lot of company's raise earnings guidance for the year, but leave cash flows unchanged as you have done. I'm just wondering what the message in the Roper context is there. Is it just the practical realities of the strong growt
componenttext: Thanks. Brian, we're seeing a lot of company's raise earnings guidance for the year, but leave cash flows unchanged as you have done. I'm just wondering what the message in the Roper context is there. Is it just the practical realities of the strong growth at this point of the cycle? Is it the right investment trade-off to be making? Or are you just being a little conservative there?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think this point it's probably a little bit early for us to be able to forecast how the incremental growth that we're seeing and probably a little bit stronger than what we had thought, maybe 3 months ago, how that will translate into year-end wor
componenttext: Well, I think this point it's probably a little bit early for us to be able to forecast how the incremental growth that we're seeing and probably a little bit stronger than what we had thought, maybe 3 months ago, how that will translate into year-end working capital balances. If you kind of think about the net income impact of, say, raising $0.15 on the bottom for us, that's about $15 million of net income and $15 million of after-tax cash. But like I said, it's a little early to forecast exactly what those year-end balances will be. So we're comfortable still at $550 million or more of operating cash flow. And as we get closer to the end of the year, we'll be able to have a better view on what some of those working capital balances will look like.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, Brian, I'm wondering if you could just put a little more color on your earlier M&A comments from the standpoint of size of transactions, whether that might require some or give you an opportunity to do some equity there. And in terms of th
componenttext: Okay. And then, Brian, I'm wondering if you could just put a little more color on your earlier M&A comments from the standpoint of size of transactions, whether that might require some or give you an opportunity to do some equity there. And in terms of the platforms where you're seeing the better opportunities, can you provide a little bit of comment there, too?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that we can all -- there's more things to do than we would be willing to do with our capital structure always. I mean we're going to remain an investment-grade performer and so you don't want to really have much more than, say, 3x debt to EB
componenttext: Well, I think that we can all -- there's more things to do than we would be willing to do with our capital structure always. I mean we're going to remain an investment-grade performer and so you don't want to really have much more than, say, 3x debt to EBITDA. And if you look at our trailing EBITDA, it's going to ramp up quite dramatically here in the next quarter and third quarter. So we're going to have well in excess of $1 billion capacity with our existing structure without having to issue equity. I can't imagine issuing equity. It would have to just be 1 heck of a breathtaking opportunity for us, and I just don't see that happening. I mean I wouldn't rule it out if you had some kind of nirvana opportunity. But what we -- we continue to just reinvest our cash flow. We think $500 million, $600 million a year is probably where you go when you lever it up at 3x. It could be more. We got a lot of capacity now and responses are exceptionally low. So maybe it goes up, but I wouldn't think we'd be doing some $2 billion transaction. I think we'd do $1 billion one first.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: And your platforms where pipelines more robust, Energy, Industrial, Medical, RF across the board, any color there?
componenttext: And your platforms where pipelines more robust, Energy, Industrial, Medical, RF across the board, any color there?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Every Industrial asset in the world are for sale. So we're not overly excited with the stuff we're seeing in that space or the lack of discipline that people have in what they're paying. So we continue to think that the Software-as-a-Service arena and the
componenttext: Every Industrial asset in the world are for sale. So we're not overly excited with the stuff we're seeing in that space or the lack of discipline that people have in what they're paying. So we continue to think that the Software-as-a-Service arena and the medical arena remain quite attractive businesses and there's plenty of growth in those businesses in terms of an investment acquisitions, and they really crowd out most of the other investment opportunities in terms of their cash and cash returns over time. So that remains our sharp focus. Maybe there'll be some niche thing along the way that we think is particularly good. But other than that, pretty much we're focused in those 2 areas. And I would just say, Terry, I think we had $87 million of operating cash flow in the quarter. Not unusual for a Q1. So with $550 million for the full year, we're talking about generating $463 million of operating cash flow in the next 3 quarters. And that $463 million operating cash flow, it'll be quite substantial as a function of revenue for the balance of the year. And when you already got $800 million in available liquidity, and you know you're going to create another $400-plus million of free cash flow between now and the end of the year, that gives us all the powder we're going to need to make real high-quality transactions.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jennifer, and thank you all for joining us this morning as we discuss the results of our second quarter. Joining me this morning is Brian Jellison, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Paul Soni, Vice President and Controller.
componenttext:
Thank you, Jennifer, and thank you all for joining us this morning as we discuss the results of our second quarter. Joining me this morning is Brian Jellison, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Paul Soni, Vice President and Controller.
Earlier this morning, we issued a press release announcing our financial results. The press release also includes a replay information for today's call. We've prepared slides to accompany today's call, which are available through the webcast and also available on our website at www.roperind.com.
If you'll turn to Slide 2, we'll begin with our Safe Harbor statement. During the course of today's call, we will be making forward-looking statements which are subject to the risks and uncertainties that are described in this page and as detailed in our SEC filings. You should listen to today's call in the context of that information as well as the filings.
And now if you'll please turn to Slide 3. I'll turn the call over to Brian Jellison, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer. After his prepared remarks, we'll take questions from our participants. Brian?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John, and good morning, everybody. We'll start here with the Slide 3 on my deck. We'll go through the second quarter financial results for the enterprise as a whole and then we'll dissect how the segments performed and what the outlook appears for
componenttext:
Thanks, John, and good morning, everybody. We'll start here with the Slide 3 on my deck. We'll go through the second quarter financial results for the enterprise as a whole and then we'll dissect how the segments performed and what the outlook appears for each of the segment for the second half of the year. We'll talk about raising our guidance and then sort of summarize the quarter and its implications for the future and take your questions.
Next slide. The key chief financial results here are really spectacular quarter for us. We achieved a series of all-time company historical results around orders and sales and backlog and operating cash flow and then in the quarter, our net earnings EBITDA and free cash flow were outstanding. Total sales for the quarter were up 23% and 16% of that was organic. We enjoyed again double-digit sales growth in each one of the 4 segments, which frankly was a little bit better than we expected going into the quarter. Our book-to-bill ratio is still above one for the eighth straight quarter, so that's resulting in continuing backlog. We've got record backlog at the end of the second quarter of $872 million, which is up $230 million from last year's second quarter.
Gross margins were very sold in the quarter, they hit 53.9%. And our EBITDA margins, when you exclude this remeasurement gain, which is a required to be included here on a GAAP basis but we've excluded it for looking at our leverage. So the EBITDA margin was up 280 basis points to 28.5%, without that remeasurement gain, of course, [indiscernible] the margin will even be better. NDI's acquisition was completed in the quarter that's off to a good start we've already begun the financial integration and had some marketplace meetings with our various people in medical and look actually at some other acquisitions in that area with them. And then we were pleased to see the Moody's upgrade that we received in the quarter on all of our debt that structure to be AA, too. 
Next slide. On the income statement, there's just not much to say about this, except we achieved another amazing great quarter. Bookings, you can see book-to-bill of $708 million it's 1.01 eight straight quarter. Net sales were $700 million in the quarter, first time we've done that, 23% increase, gross profit up 70 basis point, operating income was up 240 basis points from 21%. Second quarter of last year to 23.4% here. Our interest rate expense was flat. Tax rate in the quarter was actually headwind for us. We came in at 31.4% Q2 this year versus 29.6% last year and that caused us a couple of pennies. Net earnings again, that's [indiscernible] to show the net earnings number without the foreign currency remeasurement gain in the quarter was up 43% and diluted earnings per share was $1.03 versus 70% on a GAAP basis had to be reported at $1.08.
Next slide. The free cash flow in Q2 got back to where we expect with like to be. Terrific results, 21% of sales. Free cash flow was up 41% over the same quarter a year ago with a move up from $103 million to $145 million.
Next slide. If you look at the asset velocity performance in the quarter it's one of the things I know everybody's very happy with inside the company despite having a 23% gain in revenue, actually inventories as a function of revenue improved by 10 basis points. So inventory last year was 7.6% of sales. Here we are up 23% and inventory has dropped to 7.5% of sales. So we're very pleased with our results. Payables about 5.5% with inventory at 7.5% we're not having to invest very much to continue to maintain our growth which is great news.
Next slide. If we look at the balance sheet of the company, we can honestly say the balance sheet has never been in better shape. We ended the quarter with $196 million in cash and that's after acquiring Northern Digital for $200 million by the way. Our available liquidity, including the [indiscernible] revolver at the end of quarter was $753 million but it will continue to move up here as we add cash rapidly now. That gives a net debt of $1,050,000,000. And our net-debt-to-net-cap, you can see as 26%. We reported here debt-to-EBITDA, meaning gross debt-to-EBITDA because not all of that $196 million immediately available without repatriation. So the gross debt-to-EBITDA number is 1.7x. If you look at the net debt, which includes all the cash it drops that ratio to 1.4. Our interest expense coverage is about 11x and despite investing $725 million in the last 12 months we're really in wonderful shape going forward and by the way our trailing EBITDA now on a 12-month basis is up to $739 million. So as the trailing EBITDA grows rapidly, if you look at the debt situation being held constant the balance sheet gets better and better.
Next slide. Now we want to take a look at the individual performance of the 4 segments and what we think they'll look like in the second half. Next slide. Here we're looking at the sort of consolidated segment-by-segment approach on gross margins and EBITDA in the quarter. Everybody at 50% or higher. The Industrial EBITDA margin is again are just breathtaking at 31%. Just terrific results in the water, including handling portion of our Industrial business as we'll talk more about.
Next slide. We start with RF Technology with the largest portion of reported sales in the quarter at 31% of revenue. You can see orders for RF were up 13%, sales were up 26% and operating margin was up 410 basis points to 24.1%. EBITDA in the quarter for RF by the way was 31% as we have a good deal of amortization in RF.
The second quarter, we wound with organic sales of 13%. We had particularly strong growth in the U.K. with our water network monitoring products from [indiscernible] and continued growth in gas fronts installation projects with catalog in France. We had very strong double-digit sales increases out at CBORD which was driven by deployments of business we won earlier out of college and university environments and that portion of the business is continuing to do really quite well, despite what some people might think.
Very strong North American tag sales for transport throughout the second quarter and then if we look to the second half of the year, we're going to have continued growth in both Toll & Traffic operations with more tags shipments out of transport but also several traffic projects that we're putting in, in the United States. And then we have significant expansion of electronic tolling in Puerto Rico where we're going to be converting from coin-operated technologies to electronic collection.
CBORD's backlog is very strong, so it's assuring ourselves a double-digit growth throughout the rest of the staff the year and very strong Q3 cash. And iTrade is continuing to do well. We've been encouraging them and investing in them to focus really on their core business on a global basis and that is going well, although we had to continue to beef up the nimbleness of our operations in Europe which we're doing.
Next slide. In Industrial Technology, you can see we had again spectacular performance, orders were up 15%, sales up 26%, operating margin increased 160 basis points to 28.2%, EBITDA was 31% for them as well. We had exceptional growth in all of our pump and water Fluid Handling businesses, largely driven by oil and gas and irrigation projects. Our materials are used in all the shale activity that you see and we're doing a lot of dewatering and we're doing a lot of drilling support mechanisms for those projects. We had very strong demands for our material test business in Denmark and then we had double-digit growth again at Neptune, which was kind I wouldn't say a surprise, but it was pleasant to see because all of the indicators around those businesses would be less than exciting.
The next generation residential water meter that we develop at Neptune that some people have seen are and has been introduced and it's beginning to ship, it does lower material content than our previous water meter for residential applications and it's a very easy product to install and incorporate our reading technology. Neptune already meets the 2014 federal lead-free standard associated with the Safe Water Drinking Act. I think this is something that is not talked about enough in the marketplace around just how important and critical that will be. And we will encourage our investors to go online on YouTube, you'll see at [indiscernible]. You'll see a 4 to 4.5 minute think we put together basically for municipalities to help them try to understand what's going on and while there was this one standard now there is better standard that has to be lead-free. Neptune is the only really producer of lead-free water meters here in the United States. A significant development for us it's not something we've been working on throughout the last 10 years and we're going to get wide market acceptance going forward.
In the second half of the year, we expect Neptune's momentum to continue which we would think we would at least as well as the revenue the half of the year as we did in the first half, even though in the third quarter for Neptune we have extremely difficult comp because last year we had a blowout there were about third quarter.
Our order trends and backlog continue to support all of our Fluid Handling businesses. The weather [indiscernible] and Cornell and [indiscernible] or any of these are all doing spectacularly well. New product introductions and strong Q4 seasonality we think we'll continue to drive our [indiscernible] large [indiscernible] businesses also in the fourth quarter.
Next slide. When we look at the Energy Systems & Controls business, here you can see orders up 19%, sales up 22%. The operating margin here was 25.9%, which is up 150 basis points. EBITDA came in at the quarter at 29%. In the quarter, virtually all of our end markets were very strong. The diesel engine safety systems that we continue to advertise and push into the marketplace have had continuing growth and their adoption rate with the diesel engine manufacturers. They're going to reach record levels here in the third quarter coming up. The refining and petrochem market is doing much better for us again, instruments sales have taken off. And as then when we look at the sort of global industrial production and capacity utilization around the latex entire manufacturing and analytics that we do in the rubber industry, those are all doing exceptionally well and perhaps most importantly, we haven't seen any signs of any slow down in that business, which along with material test, have been kind of 2 leading indicators for us about if there's any softness anywhere. They both continue to grow.
In the second half of 2011, we've got a very strong backlog in energy, which assures our Q3 growth and all the indicators which suggest that seasonally strong Q4 which is usually our best quarter in that segment. The control systems business activity is certainly should drive our second half record performance here. That activity and backlog has grown at a very fast days and shipments ought to start to manifest themselves here in the second half. And we expect continued margin expansion with great leverage throughout the segment in the second half of the year.
Next slide. The Medical & Scientific Imaging segment, you can see was up 11% on orders and up 18% on revenue. Operating margin was up 180 basis points to 23.4%. There's quite a bit of noncash amortization here, so EBITDA was 29%. If you look at the medical in the second quarter, pretty much across the line performed very well. We've got faster adoption rates again in Bladderscan and GlideScope, we think GlideScope is intervention and product Bladderscan is the product that helps avoid [indiscernible] in the hospital and that is the can of again this year. Very strong ultrasound consumables sales for [indiscernible]. In Northern Digital, we completed the acquisition in the quarter. We'll talk a lot more about that in a second. And then our high-end products that we're driving for [indiscernible] that's really around our filters up for proprietary technology for [indiscernible], are performing as well.
In the second half of the year, if we look at the backlog that we go into, again, we're kind of assured a very strong second half. We don't have to rely much on book and ship here. Continued strength throughout the medical platform. We've got the product introductions that Verathon has been working on with Velaport [indiscernible] and other products are basically on trend where we want them to be for our 2012 launches. We take those products will carry our growth soundly into next year. And in Northern Digital will have income growth in the second half of the year it's a pretty and our nominee maybe $0.01 in Q3 and then stronger in Q4 with $0.03 or so. That acquisition we thought we can kind of introduced the product to you since we have the chance today and so the next slide here is really detailed explanation about what Northern Digital does and I've asked John to explain that to you.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure. Thanks, Brian. Northern Digital acquisition that really adds to our growing medical platform using both Sensors as well as cameras as leading provider for both optical and electromagnetic tracking systems and then minimally invasive surgery, where y
componenttext:
Sure. Thanks, Brian. Northern Digital acquisition that really adds to our growing medical platform using both Sensors as well as cameras as leading provider for both optical and electromagnetic tracking systems and then minimally invasive surgery, where you really had to have very precise application of treatment in a nonline of sight situation. You really need to know exactly where the treatment is being applied. And Northern Digital provides the technology and the systems that allow the doctor to be able to do that and this is really going into a part of the medical market that is growing very quickly around the image-guided and minimally invasive surgery and it really has a couple of different parts to it you can see it's about 90% medical and it's about 50% systems and 40% consumables. The consumables are the spears, these very hiGh-tech optical spheres that really provide the 3D location information back to the doctor. It's a unique technologies it has [indiscernible] business model as all of our acquisitions do. Really comes with a very strong and experienced management team led by Jimmy Frazier and it once again a very nice addition to our growing medical platform and really in the image-guided part of our medical platform. You'll hear us talk about ultrasound applications with Verathon ultrasound type of applications with Cisco. This is another situation where the image-guided surgery is building on that ultrasound technology. So it's a very nice addition for us. 
And with that, I'll turn it back over to Brian to talk about the new guidance for the year.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. We turn that page. We're raising guidance most importantly our cash flow we [indiscernible] that operating cash flow should exceed $575 million for the full year. Our full year [indiscernible] number now is going to be $4.20 to $4.30, which
componenttext:
Thanks, John. We turn that page. We're raising guidance most importantly our cash flow we [indiscernible] that operating cash flow should exceed $575 million for the full year. Our full year [indiscernible] number now is going to be $4.20 to $4.30, which includes the GAAP $0.05 from Q2 and that's up from $3.97 to a $4.12 last quarter. in the third quarter to earn between $1.05 to $1.09 which was up about 25% from the $0.87 we earned from the third quarter last year and I'll remind you third quarter last year was an exceptionally strong quarter. So we think that's quite good performance around the guidance going forward given the strength of last third quarter.
Next slide. If we look at how Q2 shapes up in terms of the summary, we wound up with all-time historical quarter performance for any quarter in our history, even better than the fourth quarter last year for order sales, backlog and operating cash flow. The very broad-based momentum throughout the enterprise we have a number of small niche P&L's and all a, so of the more of. Total sales grew to 23%, the gross margin up 70 basis point. Operating margin where you can really see the leverage was up 240 basis point so on an incremental operating margin against the incremental sales, our leverage the quarter was 34%. EBITDA because of the noncash amortization that hits [indiscernible] margin, EBITDA was higher at 280 basis points to 28.5% and that excludes the remeasurement gain of course we kept that in there under GAAP with even higher leverage. So the leverage on EBITDA was 40% of the new revenue.
Record backlog ended the quarter at $872 million. We raised the guidance to $4.20 to $4.30 and I think most importantly, when you see what's happening here is that our niche business focus continues to deliver this outstanding results when so many people concentrate what are you going to do about at the BRICS? What are you doing about that? What are you doing Chenard? Our sales BRICS was about 5% of revenue in the second quarter this year and they were about 5% of revenue in the second quarter last year, maybe a little less. So that's helpful but that's not what's absolutely required for us to continue to grow. It was just another terrific quarter and will position of course for a record year. 
And with that, think we can open up to Q&A.

componenttext: No, we just continue to migrate people to smaller and easier to apply sticker tags and those tend to replace the hard case tag technologies at a relatively fast pace. So this is more growth in our core markets, Texas, Oklahoma, Florida. We have the benefit of North Carolina rolling out second half of the year. And then we'll have some international development in the Middle East that will improve shipments. So all this things helped. So I think one thing that's really been sort of encouraging is counterintuitive to how we think about municipal spending is that we've got a number of design projects that we're doing, some in the Far West important one we just one around Pennsylvania on a conversion projects. So our traffic business is actually doing pretty well and I think we probably commented relative to -- we wouldn't have expected it to be a headwind it's been certainly neutral to modest upside for us.

componenttext: I want to follow-up in the RF segment, with a couple of questions. First on CBORD, it was interesting that your recognizing higher sales for the college and universities. It was my sense that maybe it's the timing of when you actually do the installations during the summer months. So maybe it's a revenue recognition on these orders but is the understanding that you're doing most of the deployments during the summer months?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Deane, it is true we do most of the deployments in the summer months, however, because of the software recognition rules that we have and the fact that we really sell the software on a 1-year license basis, we actually defer that revenue over a 12-month p
componenttext: Deane, it is true we do most of the deployments in the summer months, however, because of the software recognition rules that we have and the fact that we really sell the software on a 1-year license basis, we actually defer that revenue over a 12-month period. So there's a little bit of benefit during the installation phase associated with the products but by and large, CBORD is a software business. it accounts well over 2/3 of the revenue is software and that naturally spread ratably over the year. So the growth we are seeing there is not because of installations, it's because of new wins. And the continued deployment of the software into other areas like security applications in a campus environment.

componenttext: Well I think it's a valid not everybody has picked up on how valuable all of our software as a service solution businesses are. Eventually, I think somebody will catch up to us on that, so we see a lot of upside for recognition of what we're doing and how we're doing it.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011

componenttext: That's a problem having products that are really mature products and looking for geographic expansion with those mature products versus ourselves, which are primarily solution providers with a lot of application engineering and very few standard products and so in order for us to take India for instance where our bid activity and channel development is expanding most rapidly, again our markets are pretty small, all right. So it's really hard to make a major investment in India that might drive $10 million in growth for 3 other pump companies. So it's not pragmatic and the things that we do are so application-specific that you probably got to have to rely on local distribution for what happens and we're probably the most conservative people you'll meet on how we look at distribution channels and assuring that we're very comfortable with all the activity that creates revenue in these countries.

componenttext: Brian, you mentioned the shale projects in the U.S. driving a lot of at least the pump businesses and Industrial tech. Is energy systems also seeing a net benefit from that activity? Has it been a material contributor to your end market demand?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, it's different in the 2 cases. In the case of Roper, it affects growing operations. In the case of Cornell, it's dewatering pumps. When you get to energy, it's more around our what we call DSS business, which is these all control technologies to ens
componenttext: Well, it's different in the 2 cases. In the case of Roper, it affects growing operations. In the case of Cornell, it's dewatering pumps. When you get to energy, it's more around our what we call DSS business, which is these all control technologies to ensure that the diesel engine shutoff and we continue to work both with Ocean here in the U.S. and various agencies around the world about the importance of the shutoff valves and the recognition continues to grow and we've got the best mousetrap in that world. So that's helping us a lot. So certainly, anyplace you're going to have a selectivity, we are going to get benefited and Energy and real directly in our food and handling business.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011

componenttext: I've looking at Industrial tech, continues to impress margin lines, is 20% is the thinking kind of over at sustainable level over the next cycle here or 100 the [indiscernible] you said your reducing the raw material content and your water meters which obviously [indiscernible] big portion of that segment, do you still see upside there are your recovering costs from the copper spikes?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'd say that we've done a great job in managing through the cost increases in copper. I mean, I can remember what it used to be $0.74 a pound or something, here it is toward $4.39 and almost 2 pounds of copper for every meter is we've got a big deal
componenttext: Yes, I'd say that we've done a great job in managing through the cost increases in copper. I mean, I can remember what it used to be $0.74 a pound or something, here it is toward $4.39 and almost 2 pounds of copper for every meter is we've got a big deal sells for $20 or something. So we would give them great credit for how they're performing. Now we continue to make a commitment that we're will have lead-free water meters that are broad-based technologies as opposed to some people looking at plastic, which we think is a long way from being a safe installation project for people. In the pump businesses, we generally have enough pricing power that if we got cost push inflation on materials side that we can pass that through and not market up, it's almost just as separate side for things are. Surpassed it doesn't really hurt us in any event. I think we continue to get leverage as revenue goes up so on the OP line you can see we've got 30% leverage in the quarter and in both industrial and energy, we don't have very much noncash amortization that's coming off of those. So that kind of 30%, 35% leverage I think continues with us. That ought to be a perpetual opportunity as long as revenue is expanding.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: We think about 2 different things maybe, I'm not sure we understand your question. CBORD is primarily focused on college and university environments, so it wouldn't matter if that was a state school or a private institution. Horizon is focused on elementa
componenttext: We think about 2 different things maybe, I'm not sure we understand your question. CBORD is primarily focused on college and university environments, so it wouldn't matter if that was a state school or a private institution. Horizon is focused on elementary education and K-12 and most of that business is public business. It's really driven by nutrition management and by sorting out how much the free lunch program is going to be paid for individual people and the proof of that. And so Horizon has very large public institution contracts like Dallas, Philadelphia, Los Angeles, things like that and bids large contracts in that arena. And then also does somewhat smaller domain places as well.

componenttext: Second half tax rate, we're expecting to be in the range of 30%, bringing the full year to also in the range of 30%. So kind of through the first half with 30.4% and then just timing related, we probably expect Q3 to be a little bit better than that and Q4 we'll have to see.

And then you can maybe remind this Software-as-a-Service as a percent of the total company is today and where do you see that going over the next 3 to 5 years?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, let's say from a software that we continue to see a lot of opportunities and what we call network technologies and it's a very ironic thing about as we look at our businesses on a niche basis and we want to keep focused on the P&L basis and customer
componenttext: Well, let's say from a software that we continue to see a lot of opportunities and what we call network technologies and it's a very ironic thing about as we look at our businesses on a niche basis and we want to keep focused on the P&L basis and customer profitability basis. So I think we're doing a great job in that arena. And as a result of there kind of customer, they don't lend themselves to a forced synergies from a physical asset basis. So our pump, we great recent pump this company went you can't put those factors together they fundamentally 2 different kinds of things. In the network arena, that's actually not true. I mean it's very ironic but in fact they're doing a lot of data storage, they've got a lot of things that are really quite similar in the backend of an enterprise that you can you believe that a lot of the synergies around. So absolutely positive to get cost synergies out of software is service business that we can get out of the Industrial businesses. So that makes them pretty attractive and as long as these small network opportunities are available, we think it's an attractive place to invest. Now we're not trying to turn Roper into a single-use software network application company. So we believe our focus around that has been opportunistic. They generate more cash than the other businesses do and they require less assets and they virtually never have anything that depreciates and their assets go home at night and as long as you're motivate them, they've got wonderful cash and cash return over the long period of time. Today, John, I don't know if you provided much guidance around the overall revenue, but that it's getting to be certainly a very significant portion of the RF business at some point you're in a split so that you see tolling business completely separate from all the rest of the RF business. That's something I expect we would probably do for 2012 so it's easier for everybody to see the variance in the 2 because you do have this terribly lumpy TransCore order input situation that's up terrifically in Q1 and down a little bit in Q2 but over the first half the year it's double-digit growth but it certainly makes it confusing. We just have to do a few things to get that in place to be able to respond to your question clearly which we'll do for next year.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011

componenttext: Okay, and on the M&A landscape?

componenttext: On the M&A landscape, we think people that are doing company deals continue to generally over pay for them. We've had ended up a lot of stuff in the pipeline. I think that it's not necessarily that we're focused on the medical product arena and the networks software arena but that's what we are seeing more of that other assets. We have seen energy assets other than a very small bolt-on type things that we think that have been priced at a level that we'd be comfortable with. And the industrial asset arena, we continue to grow internally for the most part as opposed to looking at asset acquisitions. So I think that the next acquisitions you'll see from us are likely to be in network technology or additional medical build out.

Q2 was better than we certainly expected. So both Q3 and Q4 very difficult comps. We just had a blowout in quarter last year it's going to be tough to do substantially better than that. But we've had another tough challenges too.

componenttext: Sure. I mean what we said about that, that revenue should we in the $50 million to $60 million range for the next 12 months. It's been growing substantially as more image-guided surgery utilizes the equipment and the consumables that they have and so we expect there double-digit rate rose to continue at least for the next years. We'll have to look at it beyond that. But all of the trends at technology and the trends in the marketplace around having less invasive more image-guided surgery are favorable for them.

componenttext: No, it's not actually around how much activities running through their network. It's really around how many people are subscribed. So it's really around how quickly the customers are able to bring their suppliers on to the network, which is not huge technical challenge, it's really a business process challenge for the customer, not really for iTrade. So our growth is a, dependent on getting new customers which we continue to do and then how quickly those customers roll this solution out to their supply base.

componenttext: Well, the worst margins are always going to be in the transport traffic segment, which is heavy administrative activity violation processing and lane expansion and moving traffic lights and those of things. Whenever we have growth in the other portions of the activity, much faster rate in those business grow, then we get a whole lot better contribution because, I mean, you're looking at order of magnitude several times the difference there. So the other thing that's happening of course we get more that the growth out of the software businesses at the expense of the TransCore tolling and traffic is that's and so as you get that, you can't higher margin capture and better cash. And then lastly, when the tag shipments occur then that tends to be better than the administrative margin activity does. So the administrative activity hasn't grown. In fact it was down a little bit in the second quarter year-over-year and so that's bad news on revenue, good news on margins.

So it's definitely gaining share. I think it's so focused rather than being somebody that in a diverse area a. I think were really proud of the team we have been customer obviously they have any follow-up they have with their customers and the ability to do things integrated online. I think they will continue to gain share and I think is the same with Horizon now the Horizon activities very better than we would have hoped for given the difficulty with educational spending. I think if you ever gotten any relief in the K-12 arena which you may or may not get, if you get it is probably because of the attrition was a lot of build out where we see new platform of what happens in K-12 education around data-gathering and we have a number of software development that we are putting in place around school it can manage its kind of inflow of cash from families take class program how we run 2 new avenues and they're working hard on that now.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jennifer, and thank you all for joining us this morning as we discuss the results of our second quarter. Joining me this morning is Brian Jellison, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Paul Soni, Vice President and Controller.
componenttext:
Thank you, Jennifer, and thank you all for joining us this morning as we discuss the results of our second quarter. Joining me this morning is Brian Jellison, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Paul Soni, Vice President and Controller.
Earlier this morning, we issued a press release announcing our financial results. The press release also includes a replay information for today's call. We've prepared slides to accompany today's call, which are available through the webcast and also available on our website at www.roperind.com.
Now if you'll turn to Slide 2, we'd begin with our Safe Harbor statement. During the course of today's call, we will be making forward-looking statements, which are subject to the risks and uncertainties as described on this page and as detailed in our SEC filings. You should listen to today's call in the context of that information as well as the filings.
And now if you'll please turn to Slide 3. I'll turn the call over to Brian Jellison, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer. After his prepared remarks, we'll take questions from our participants. Brian?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John, and good morning, everybody. Let me start here with the Slide 3 on my deck. We'll go through the second quarter financial results for the enterprise as a whole and then we'll dissect how the segments performed and what the outlook appears fo
componenttext:
Thanks, John, and good morning, everybody. Let me start here with the Slide 3 on my deck. We'll go through the second quarter financial results for the enterprise as a whole and then we'll dissect how the segments performed and what the outlook appears for each of the segment in the second half of the year. We'll talk about raising our guidance and then sort of summarize the quarter and its implications for the future and take your questions.
Next slide. The Q2 financial results here are really a spectacular quarter for us. We achieved a series of all-time company historical results around orders and sales and backlog and operating cash flow. And then in the quarter, our net earnings, EBITDA and free cash flow were outstanding. 
Total sales for the quarter were up 23% and 16% of that was organic. We enjoyed again double-digit sales growth in each one of the 4 segments, which frankly was a little bit better than we expected going into the quarter. Our book-to-bill ratio is still above 1 for the eighth straight quarter, so that's resulting in continuing backlog. We've got record backlog at the end of the second quarter of $872 million, which is up $230 million from last year's second quarter.
Gross margins were very solid in the quarter. They hit 53.9%. And our EBITDA margins, when you exclude this remeasurement gain, which is required to be included here on a GAAP basis, but we've excluded it for looking at our leverage. So the EBITDA margin was up 280 basis points to 28.5%. Without that remeasurement gain, of course, if we left it, the margin will even be better. 
NDI's acquisition was completed in the quarter that's off to a good start. We've already begun the financial integration and had some marketplace meetings with our various people in medical and look actually at some other acquisitions in that area with them. And then we were pleased to see the Moody's upgrade that we received in the quarter on all of our debt structure to be AA, too. 
Next slide. On the income statement, there's just not much to say about this, except we achieved another amazingly great quarter. Bookings, you can see book-to-bill at $708 million, it's 1.01 up, our eighth straight quarter. Net sales were $700 million in the quarter. First time we've done that. 23% increase. Gross profit up 70 basis points. Operating income was up 240 basis points from 21%. Second quarter of last year to 23.4% here. Our interest expense was flat. Tax rate in the quarter was actually headwind for us. We came in at 31.4% in Q2 this year versus 29.6% last year and that caused us a couple of pennies. Net earnings again, that's asterisked to show the net earnings number without the foreign currency remeasurement gain in the quarter. It was up 43%. And diluted earnings per share, $1.03 versus $0.74. On a GAAP basis, it had to be reported at $1.08.
Next slide. The free cash flow in Q2 got back to where we expect it -- we'd like to be. We had terrific, terrific results, 21% of sales. Free cash flow was up 41% over the same quarter a year ago with a move up from $103 million to $145 million.
Next slide. If you look at the asset velocity performance in the quarter, it's one of the things I know everybody's very happy with inside the company. Despite having a 23% gain in revenue, actually inventory as a function of revenue improved by 10 basis points. So inventory last year was 7.6% of sales. Here, we are up 23% and inventory has dropped to 7.5% of sales. So we're very pleased with our results. Payable is about 5.5% with inventory at 7.5%. We're not having to invest very much to continue to maintain our growth, which is great news.
Next slide. If we look at the balance sheet of the company, we can honestly say the balance sheet's never been in better shape. We ended the quarter with $196 million in cash and that's after acquiring Northern Digital for $200 million, by the way. Our available liquidity, including the undrawn revolver at the end of quarter was $753 million, but it'll continue to move up here as we add cash rapidly now. That gives us a net debt of $1,050,000,000. And our net debt-to-net cap, you can see as 26%. We reported here debt-to-EBITDA, meaning gross debt-to-EBITDA because not all of that $196 million is immediately available without repatriation. So the gross debt-to-EBITDA number is 1.7x. If you look at the net debt, which includes all the cash, it drops that ratio to 1.4. Our EBITDA-to-interest expense coverage is about 11x. And despite investing $725 million in the last 12 months, we're really in  a wonderful shape going forward. And by the way, our trailing EBITDA now on a 12-month basis is up to $739 million. So as the trailing EBITDA grows rapidly, if you look at the debt situation being held constant, the balance sheet gets better and better.
Next slide. Now we want to take a look at the individual performance of the 4 segments and what we think they'll look like in the second half. Next slide. Here we're looking at the sort of consolidated segment-by-segment approach on gross margins and EBITDA in the quarter. Everybody at 50% or higher. The industrial EBITDA margins again are just breathtaking at 31%. Just terrific results in the quarter, including handling portion of our industrial businesses we'll talk more about.
Next slide. We start with RF Technology with the largest portion of reported sales in the quarter at 31% of revenue. You can see orders for RF were up 13%, sales were up 26% and operating margin was up 410 basis points to 24.1%. EBITDA in the quarter for RF, by the way, was 31% as we have a good deal of amortization in RF.
The second quarter, we wound up with organic sales of 13%. We had particularly strong growth in the U.K. with our water network monitoring products from Technolog and continued growth in gas fronts installation project with Technolog in France. We had very strong double-digit sales increases out of CBORD, which was driven by deployments business we won earlier out of college and university environments, and that portion of the business is continuing to do really quite well despite what some people might think.
Very strong North American tag sales for transport throughout the second quarter. And then if we look to the second half of the year, we're going to have continued growth in both toll and traffic operations with more tags shipments out of TransCore, but also several traffic projects that we're putting in, in the United States. And then we have a significant expansion of electronic tolling in Puerto Rico where we're going to be converting from coin-operated technologies to electronic collection.
CBORD's backlog is very strong, so it's assuring ourselves a double-digit growth throughout the rest of this half of the year and very strong Q3 cash. And iTrade is continuing to do well. We've been encouraging them and investing in them to focus really on their core business on a global basis and that is going well, although we have to continue to beef up the nimbleness of our operations in Europe, which we're doing.
Next slide. In industrial technology, you can see we had again a spectacular performance. Orders were up 15%, sales up 26%, operating margin increased 160 basis points to 28.2%. EBITDA was 31% for them as well. We had exceptional growth in all of our pump and water fluid handling businesses, largely driven by oil and gas and irrigation projects. Our materials are used in all the shale activity that you see and we're doing a lot of dewatering and we're doing a lot of drilling support mechanisms for those projects. We have very strong demands for our material test business in Denmark and then we had double-digit growth again at Neptune, which was kind of, I wouldn't say, a surprise but it was pleasant to see because all of the indicators around those businesses would be less than exciting.
The next generation residential water meter that we developed at Neptune that some people have seen has been introduced and it's beginning to ship. It has a lower raw material content than our previous water meter had for residential applications, and it's a very easy product to install and incorporate our reading technology. Neptune already meets the 2014 federal lead-free standard associated with the Safe Water Drinking Act. I think this is something that's not talked about enough in the marketplace around just how important and critical that'll be. And we would encourage our investors to go online on YouTube, you'll see at www.shedthelead.com\video\. You'll see a 4 to 4.5 minute thing we put together basically for municipalities to help them try to understand what's going on and while there was this one standard now, there's another standard that has to be lead free. Neptune is the only really producer of lead-free water meters here in the United States. Quite a significant development for us. It's something that we've been working on throughout the last 10 years and feel that it's going to get widespread market acceptance going forward.
In the second half of the year, we expect Neptune's momentum to continue, which we would think will do at least as well on revenue in the second half of the year there as we did in the first half, even though in the third quarter, for Neptune, we have extremely difficult comp because last year we had a blowout favorable third quarter.
Our order trends and backlog continue to support all of our fluid handling businesses. They -- whether it's Roper or Cornell or Abel or Hansen, any of these are all doing just spectacularly well. New product introductions and a strong Q4 seasonality, we think, will continue to drive or stir us into Logitech [indiscernible] businesses also in the fourth quarter.
Next slide. When we look at the energy systems and controls business, here you can see orders up 19%, sales up 22%. The operating margin here was 25.9%, which is up 150 basis points. EBITDA came into the quarter at 29%. In the quarter, virtually all of our end markets were very strong. The diesel engine safety systems that we continue to advertise and push into the marketplace have had continuing growth in their adoption rate with the diesel engine manufacturers. They're going to reach record levels here in this third quarter coming up. The refining and petrochem market is doing much better for us again. Instruments sales have taken off. And then when we look at the sort of global industrial production and capacity utilization around the latex and tire manufacturing and analytics that we do in the rubber industry, those all are doing exceptionally well. And perhaps most importantly, we haven't seen any sign of any slowdown in that business, which, along with material test, have been the kind of 2 leading indicators for us about if there's any softness anywhere. They both continue to grow.
In the second half of 2011, we've got a very strong backlog in energy, which assures our Q3 growth and all the indicators, which suggest that seasonally strong Q4 which is usually our best quarter in that segment. 
The control systems business activity certainly should drive our second half record performance here. That activity and backlog has grown at a very fast pace, and shipments ought to start to manifest themselves here in the second half. And we expect continued margin expansion with great leverage throughout this segment in the second half of the year.
Next slide. The medical and scientific imaging segment, you can see was up 11% on orders and up 18% on revenue. Operating margin was up 180 basis points to 23.4%. There's quite a bit of noncash amortization here, so EBITDA was 29%. If you look at the medical in the second quarter, pretty much across the line performed very well. We've got faster adoption rates again in Bladderscan and GlideScope. We think -- GlideScope is the intubation product. Bladderscan is the product that helps avoid catheterization in the hospital, and that has taken off again this year. Very strong ultrasound consumables sales for CIVCO. In Northern Digital, we completed that acquisition in the quarter. We'll talk a little bit more about that in a second. And then our high-end products that we're driving for photonics that are really around our filters up for Gatan and proprietary technology for Princeton are performing well as well.
In the second half of the year, if we look at the backlog that we go into, again we're kind of assured a very strong second half. We don't have to rely much on book and ship here. Continued strength throughout the medical platform. We've got the product introductions that Verathon has been working on with Velaport [ph], Heartscape and other products are basically on trend for where we want them to be for our 2012 launches. We think those products will carry our growth soundly into next year. 
In Northern Digital, we'll have a little bit of income growth in the second half of the year. It's accretive nominally, maybe $0.01 in Q3 and then stronger in Q4 with $0.03 or so. That acquisition we thought we kind of introduce the product to you since we have that chance today and so the next slide here is really a detailed explanation about what Northern Digital does and I've asked John to explain that to you.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure. Thanks, Brian. The Northern Digital acquisition that really adds to our growing medical platform using both sensors as well as cameras is the leading provider for both optical and electromagnetic tracking systems and in minimally invasive surgery wh
componenttext:
Sure. Thanks, Brian. The Northern Digital acquisition that really adds to our growing medical platform using both sensors as well as cameras is the leading provider for both optical and electromagnetic tracking systems and in minimally invasive surgery where you really had to have very precise application of treatment in a nonline-of-sight situation. You really need to know exactly where the treatment is being applied. And Northern Digital provides the technology and the systems that allow the doctor to be able to do that. And this is really going into a part of the medical market that is growing very quickly around image-guided and minimally invasive surgery. And it really has a couple of different parts to it. You can see it's about 90% medical, and it's about 60% systems and 40% consumables. The consumables are the spheres, these very high-tech optical spheres that really provide the 3D location information back to the doctor. It's a unique and patented technology. It has asset light business model as all of our acquisitions do. Really comes with a very strong and experienced management team led by Jamie Frazier. And it's once again a very nice addition to our growing medical platform and really in the image-guided part of our medical platform. You'll hear us talk about ultrasound applications with Verathon, ultrasound type of applications with CIVCO. This is another situation where the image-guided surgery is building on that ultrasound technology. So it's a very nice addition for us. 
And with that, I'll turn it back over to Brian to talk about the new guidance for the year.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. We turn that page. So we're raising guidance, most importantly, on our cash flow. We now think that operating cash flow should exceed $575 million for the full year. Our full year DEPS number now is going to be $4.20 to $4.30, which includes
componenttext:
Thanks, John. We turn that page. So we're raising guidance, most importantly, on our cash flow. We now think that operating cash flow should exceed $575 million for the full year. Our full year DEPS number now is going to be $4.20 to $4.30, which includes the GAAP $0.05 from Q2, and that's up from $3.97 to $4.12 last quarter. In the third quarter, we expect to earn between $1.05 and a $1.09, which is up about 25% from the $0.87 that we earned in the third quarter last year. And I'd remind you actually that third quarter last year was an exceptionally strong quarter. So we think that's quite good performance around the guidance going forward given the strength of last third quarter.
Next slide. If we look at how Q2 then shapes up in terms of a summary, we wound up with all-time historical quarter performance for any quarter in our history, even better than the fourth quarter last year for order sales, backlog and operating cash flow. The very broad-based momentum throughout the enterprise, we have a number of small niche P&L's and almost all of them were up. Total sales growth at 23%, the gross margin up 70 basis points. Operating margin, where you can really see the leverage, was up 240 basis points. So on the incremental, operating margin against the incremental sales, our leverage in the quarter was 34%. EBITDA, because of the noncash amortization that hits the OP margin, EBITDA was higher at 280 basis points to 28.5% and that excludes the remeasurement gain. Of course, we kept that in there under GAAP without even higher leverage. So the leverage on EBITDA was 40% of the new revenue.
Record backlog ended the quarter at $872 million. We raised the guidance to $4.20 to $4.30. And I think most importantly, when you see what's happening here is that our niche business focus continues to deliver these outstanding results. When so many people concentrate on what are you going to do about the BRICS? What are you doing about that? What are you doing this? Our sales into the BRICS were about 5% of revenue in the second quarter this year and they were about 5% of revenue in the second quarter last year, maybe a little less. So that's helpful, but that's not what's absolutely required for us to continue to grow. It was another just terrific quarter and will position the course for a record year. 
And with that, I think we can open up to Q&A.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Jeffrey Sprague with Vertical Investment Research.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Jeffrey Sprague with Vertical Investment Research.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Brian, I'm wondering if you could give us a little more color on the tag and traffic opportunities that you're referring to in the second quarter. Obviously, there's some basic municipal secrecy around that. We understand that, but if there's some additio
componenttext: Brian, I'm wondering if you could give us a little more color on the tag and traffic opportunities that you're referring to in the second quarter. Obviously, there's some basic municipal secrecy around that. We understand that, but if there's some additional color you could give us there would be helpful.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, we just -- we continue to migrate people to small and easier to apply sticker tags and those tend to replace the hard case tag technologies at a relatively fast pace. So this is more growth in our core markets: Texas, Oklahoma, Florida. We have the be
componenttext: No, we just -- we continue to migrate people to small and easier to apply sticker tags and those tend to replace the hard case tag technologies at a relatively fast pace. So this is more growth in our core markets: Texas, Oklahoma, Florida. We have the benefit of North Carolina rolling out in the second half of the year. And then we'll have some international development in the Middle East that will improve shipments. So all these things help. So I think one thing that has really been sort of encouraging, it's counterintuitive to how we would think about municipal spending is that we've got a number of design projects that we're doing, some in the Far West, important one that we just won around Pennsylvania on a conversion project. So our traffic business is actually doing pretty well. And I think we probably commented in here relative to -- we would have expected it to be a headwind. It's been certainly neutral to modest upside for us.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Great. And just for John. John, you gave us the organic for RF. Could you give us just kind of high-level kind of the organic level? The organic sales reach of the other segments?
componenttext: Great. And just for John. John, you gave us the organic for RF. Could you give us just kind of high-level kind of the organic level? The organic sales reach of the other segments?

componenttext: Sure. Yes, I can do that. The organic growth by segment for industrial technology was 23%. For the medical and imaging, it was 12%. For RF Technology, it was 13% and for our energy systems and controls at 18%.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
