headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Matt Summerville with KeyBanc.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Matt Summerville with KeyBanc.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions I want to talk about the RF Tech business for a minute. The operating margins performance you had in Q2 was probably the best you've had in the last 10 or 12 quarters. I now it's a mix-sensitive business. So can you talk a little bit
componenttext: A couple of questions I want to talk about the RF Tech business for a minute. The operating margins performance you had in Q2 was probably the best you've had in the last 10 or 12 quarters. I now it's a mix-sensitive business. So can you talk a little bit about the mix dynamics that you encountered in Q2 and kind of what the project activities that's on the board for the back half of the year? How should we think about RF Tech margins proceeding from here?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, the worst margins are always going to be in the transport traffic segment, which is heavy administrative activity, violation processing and lane expansion and moving traffic lights and those type of things. Whenever we have growth in the other porti
componenttext: Well, the worst margins are always going to be in the transport traffic segment, which is heavy administrative activity, violation processing and lane expansion and moving traffic lights and those type of things. Whenever we have growth in the other portions of the activity at much faster rate than those business grow, then we get a whole lot better contribution because, I mean, you're looking at an order of magnitude several times the difference there. So the other thing that's happening, of course, is we get more embedded growth out of the software businesses at the expense of the TransCore tolling and traffic business, and so as you get that, you get a higher margin capture and better cash. And lastly, when the tag shipments occur, then that tends to be better than the administrative margin activity does. So the administrative activity hasn't grown. In fact, it was down a little bit, I believe, in the second quarter year-over-year and so that's bad news on revenue, good news on margins.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then just in the medical life sciences-related area, specifically with Verathon, you talk about kind of the new product pipeline for 2012 and moving forward with Heartscape. And now that you're kind of few quarters into that process, have you thought
componenttext: And then just in the medical life sciences-related area, specifically with Verathon, you talk about kind of the new product pipeline for 2012 and moving forward with Heartscape. And now that you're kind of few quarters into that process, have you thought about it or can you give us some sort of parameter around what you think these next-generation products out of Verathon can add incrementally to revenue next year?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think you probably got to wait for another quarter or 2. I mean we're finished with the -- the trials are completed and done and accepted on Heartscape, but it takes a while to get that into the marketplace. The reaction has been very favorable to peopl
componenttext: I think you probably got to wait for another quarter or 2. I mean we're finished with the -- the trials are completed and done and accepted on Heartscape, but it takes a while to get that into the marketplace. The reaction has been very favorable to people as we explain it to them and demo it at hospitals. But we're not going to provide guidance on that for another probably 2 quarters.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: We'll move next to Wendy Caplan of SunTrust Robinson Humphrey.
componenttext: We'll move next to Wendy Caplan of SunTrust Robinson Humphrey.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: If we look at CBORD and Horizon and Neptune and TransCore and iTrade, have there been any meaningful market share shifts in any of those businesses as far as you can tell at this point?
componenttext: If we look at CBORD and Horizon and Neptune and TransCore and iTrade, have there been any meaningful market share shifts in any of those businesses as far as you can tell at this point?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, each one will be a bit different, right? I mean Neptune clearly has been up double digits in the first half of the year. Some of the other public companies, they either have debt or publicly traded have reported degradation in numbers. So whether th
componenttext: Well, each one will be a bit different, right? I mean Neptune clearly has been up double digits in the first half of the year. Some of the other public companies, they either have debt or publicly traded have reported degradation in numbers. So whether that's project related or us gaining share is always hard to answer, but we've certainly been outperforming people this year, so I'd say they're gaining share. But I think, for us, what we're encouraged by is we ought to gain more share in the future because I think we've got a clearly superior lead-free technology to people. On the Technolog front, I mean that's something that certainly gains share, but it's like a turnkey thing and then you fill it out right, so it's doing fine. On CBORD, it's certainly -- I believe most people would agree that it has gained share at the expense of people with universities that it's taken over that used to be covered by different folks. So it's definitely gaining share. I think it's so focused rather than being somebody that's in a diverse area. I think we're really proud of the team we have and the customer intimacy they have and the follow-up they have with customers and their ability to get things integrated online. So I think they'll continue to gain share. And I'd say the same with Horizon. The Horizon activity is very better than we would have hoped for given the difficulty with educational spending. I think if you ever got any relief around funding in the K through 12 arena, which you may or may not get, if you get it, it's probably because of nutrition. We see a lot of build-out opportunities where we can do things beside the meal platform of what happens in K through 12 education around data gathering, and we have a number of new software developments that we're putting in place around how a school can manage its kind of inflow of cash from families. Our MealpayPlus program, it's a homerun, but it can get applied to a lot of new avenues, and they're working hard on that now.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: And finally an update on Freight Matching?
componenttext: And finally an update on Freight Matching?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Freight Matching continues to be a spectacular business. It's doing well. It's got growth this year. It's certainly having all of its normalized renewals that continue, so not a massive revenue number but a fantastic cash-on-cash growth number and we're v
componenttext: Freight Matching continues to be a spectacular business. It's doing well. It's got growth this year. It's certainly having all of its normalized renewals that continue, so not a massive revenue number but a fantastic cash-on-cash growth number and we're very glad to own it.

componenttext: The Roper Industries' Third Quarter 2011 Financial Results Conference Call will now begin. Just a reminder, today's presentation is being recorded. At this time, I would the turned over to Mr. John Humphrey, Chief Financial Officer. Please go ahead.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Vicki, and thank you all for joining us this morning as we discussed the results of our record third quarter. Joining me this morning is Brian Jellison, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Paul Soni, Vice President and Controll
componenttext:
Thank you, Vicki, and thank you all for joining us this morning as we discussed the results of our record third quarter. Joining me this morning is Brian Jellison, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Paul Soni, Vice President and Controller.
Earlier this morning, we issued a press release announcing our financial results. The press release also includes a replay information for today's call. We have prepared slides to accompany today's call, which are available through the webcast and also available at our website at www.roperind.com.
Now if you'll please turn to Slide 2. We begin with our Safe Harbor statement. During the course of today's call, we'll be making forward-looking statements, which are subject to risks and uncertainties as described on this page and as detailed more fully in our SEC filings. You should listen to today's call in the context of that information.
And now if you'll please turn to Slide 3. I'll turn the call over to Brian Jellison, Roper's Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer. After his prepared remarks, we'll take questions from our telephone participants. Brian.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. Good morning, everybody. We'll start off with a quick overview of the Q3 financial results and then talk specifically about the segment performance and outlook for the fourth quarter, update you on our guidance summary and then open it up
componenttext:
Thank you, John. Good morning, everybody. We'll start off with a quick overview of the Q3 financial results and then talk specifically about the segment performance and outlook for the fourth quarter, update you on our guidance summary and then open it up to questions and answers. 
So first slide. If we look at the Q3 financial results, once again, they're an all-time record for any quarter in the history of the company, not just a record third quarter. Orders were at the highest level in history, sales the same. Backlog, the highest level, net earnings our highest level, and operating and free cash flow in the quarter set a standard for the company. Our total sales in the quarter were up 18%, and organic sales were up 13%, which was frankly better-than-expected. 
Our book-to-bill was greater than 1 for the 9th straight quarter and our record backlog of $876 million is up $106 million from the third quarter a year ago. Operating margins were terrific throughout the enterprise, they were up 230 basis points, so that operating margin was 23.5% of revenue in the quarter. Our EBITDA was $203 million in the quarter, just truly an astonishing number by any standard and EBITDA margin was 28.6%. Our operating cash flow was 23% of sales at $167 million and our free cash flow was 22% of sales at $157 million.
Next slide. If you look at the income statement, you should see that bookings again were above 1.01. Net sales were as we said, up 13% organically. Gross profit picked up 50 basis points from a year ago. Our operating income was up 30% from $128 million, the $167 million in margins at 23.5%, up from 21.2% in the third quarter a year ago. Our tax rate was actually a headwind in the quarter year. In the third quarter last year come it's only 25.9. As most of you would know, third quarter results tend to have whatever rollover there is in that 104A [ph] calculation for filing tax returns. This year, our tax rate was 27.7%, 180 basis points increase over the prior year, which took a couple of pennies out of our results. 
Net earnings were $110 million, up 31% from the prior year and our diluted earnings per share were $1.12 versus $0.87.
Next slide. Free cash flow in the quarter was truly spectacular. 22% of revenue and 142% of net earnings, so it'd be the 14th consecutive year that our free cash flow has exceeded net earnings. And really, we had very strong execution throughout the family of businesses. And you can see the comparisons to prior her on the graph.
Next slide. We had quite substantial EBITDA growth. I'm not sure people caught to just how much our trailing EBITDA continues to grow. We're up 33% in EBITDA over the prior year and our trailing 12 months EBITDA now ending the third quarter is $779 million. That's up from $585 million in the corresponding trailing 12-month period ended in the third quarter of '10 and up from $507 million in 2009. Part of the reason for that is continued margin expansion. Our EBITDA margins in 2009 were 24.5% for that TTM period. In 2010, they were up 140 basis points to 25.9% and this year they skyrocketed to 28.5% from 25.9.
Next slide. Our asset philosophy performance continues to be best-in-class. You can see inventory has actually dropped to 7.4% from 8.9% just 2 years ago. Our receivables are down 200 basis points to 14.7% from 16.7%. Just a terrific performance by all our field operating units around receivables and payables and accruals have actually come down, our numbers would even be spectacular. So in total, when we look at the inventory plus receivables, minus payables and accruals, we finished the quarter at 6.5%. That's 240 basis points better than just 2 years ago. So our exceptional performance in that category continues.
Next slide. Here we look at sort of our strong balance sheet and financial position. We ended the quarter with $246 million in cash. Our trailing 12 months EBITDA is $779 million. Our gross that number is $1,174,000,000. If you take that $246 million and cash away, you got net debt at $928 million. Shareholder equity continues to be strong there, in excess of $3 billion, meaning our net debt-to-net cap number is about 23%. Our gross debt-to-EBITDA is about 1.5x, so we have very ample capacity inside anything we'd like to do. And our EBITDA to the rest coverage is over 2x. The last 2 years, we invested $1.1 billion in transactions. But as you can see, the balance sheet is stronger than ever.
Next slide. So here we'll take a look at our segment performance and the outlook for the rest of the year. 
Next slide. Our Q3 segment performance was remarkably similar. You can see EBITDA margins and industrial RF are up and medical over 31% and energy, they were 29%. The OP margins continue to march forward as we have revenue growth and we capture leverage associated with that and throughout the enterprise, we're very happy with the margin performance.
Next slide. If we go to the largest segment in the quarter was RF Technology. It had sales up 19%, operating profit was up 41% and the operating profit margin reached 23.8%, up 380 basis points from the corresponding period in the prior year. Orders exceeded revenue. If you look at the specific commentary here, by the way, the leverage on incremental revenue was about 44%. So we had very strong growth throughout the segment, organic sales, up 15%. The software businesses had double-digit organic growth, with particular tribute to CBORD, who continues to have quite spectacular performance around integrated security solutions that we provide the universities. That business has nearly doubled this year compared to last. Our Freight Matching business grew at a double digits rate as we got more new subscribers and their very favorable dynamics occurring in the spot market due to volatility of gasoline prices and driver shortages and truck shortages. 
Our Toll & Traffic solutions business, which is [indiscernible] half of the segment we remind people, did well as a result of an upgrade where we're converting Puerto Rico from a coined-base technology to an electronic technology and we have strong tag shipments in several locations around the world.
In the fourth quarter, looking forward, we're going to continue to benefit from this electronic tolling project in Puerto Rico. Our iTrade business enters with a strong backlog and we expect double-digit growth and it will finally be showing up as organic growth here in the fourth quarter for us. The CBORD backlog remains strong enough to assure double-digit growth in the fourth quarter. We expect to get continued margin improvement even given what we had here in the third quarter. We think we'd even do better in the fourth quarter. And our Technolog operations in France, where we've been installing system, we would hope that, that gets completed in the fourth quarter and then in 2012, that will allow us to get our data services revenue which comes in at lower revenue but much higher margins.
Next slide. Here, looking at the industrial technology segment, while we often focus on Neptune because it's traditionally been about half the segment, growth in the other areas is nothing short of spectacular. Here, our orders were up substantially above the sales revenue of $185 million. The sales were up 15% from the prior year. Operating profit was up 16% and operating profit margin in the industrial businesses was 28.2%. 
Fluid handling continues to perform just in a very strong manner, driven really by all the shale, gas and oil activity that's occurring in Canada and the U.S. Lots of new customers and a lot of new applications. New products and strong end markets are also helping our material test business, which is off to a record year by a considerable margin. 
And then in Neptune in North American meter revenue was relatively flat, but we had strong growth in Mexico and Canada. Surprisingly, the U.S. order flow in the third quarter was up more than 10% in the U.S. We had a very successful launch of our low-profile, lead-free residential water meter. A lot of people currently haven't checked the shared video that we have been and it certainly created a lot interested in our water meter business. 
So we look at Q4, we expect strong seasonality. Generally speaking, we had year-end buys from people in both this and the energy business and we haven't seen any trends that would indicate that would not occur again this year. Neptune is going to get double-digit growth, led by the Toronto installation activity, which is going to start to pickup in the fourth quarter and be substantially stronger in 2012. 
And then our favorable end markets are pretty much generally true in [indiscernible] not doing well in the 30-plus percent leverage we got in Q3, we would hope to improve even a bit more in the rest of the year and next.
If we go next slide. If you look here at the medical and scientific imaging segment, it was up 16% in revenue. Orders actually exceeded sales and orders were up sequentially from the second quarter. Operating profit was up 24% compared to the sales increase of 16%. So we had strong leverage here, about 34%. And the OP margin increased 150 basis points to 24.7%. Our high-end imaging solutions driven largely by continued [indiscernible] quantum and direct detection camera lines are continuing performer, a fantastic way and we have a new product out there that's processing frame speeds at 83 gigabytes a second. I'm not sure that anybody could relate to just exactly how fast that is, but it's leading-edge technology for the most supreme applications in the research area and has added substantially to our growth this year. 
The medical platform continues to perform well. The adoption rates for both Bladderscan and GlideScope continue to escalate. We continue to gain ground internationally in terms of consumables and our ultrasound business and our [indiscernible] positioning technology for the MRI processes is beginning to gain momentum. There's a lot of favorable papers, write-ups and comments about this, so we think it will be a long-term winning proposition for the enterprise. 
In the third quarter, on a order comparison basis, that very tough comps because of 2 things that happened last year. We do report our record Mobile business in here, which is certainly not key to the enterprise but it had a particularly strong Q3 order for long-term delivery last year, which, of course, wouldn't have been repeated in any one quarter. Is it a new initiation of an order. And then we had very strong dosage delivery business last year and this year was more normalized. So both have created a bit a headwind in terms of comps. But if you must take that the way, the book-to-bill was above one, sequentially higher than the second quarter and our backlog stong, so we don't expect any difficulty here.
In the fourth quarter, we wind up, of course, with record backlog entering the quarter. So that kind of assures our shipment pattern should be fine. We expect to have continued growth in medical because the patient treatment of technologies that were involved and our continuing to grow. We have a higher fourth quarter because Northern Digital, which was acquired will begin to kick in. It has traditionally strong seasonality in the fourth quarter and we haven't seen anything that wouldn't suggest that will occur here.
Next slide. Here when we get to energy systems and controls, you can see once again very strong performance, sales were up 22%. Orders were just slightly ahead of sales, up 12%. Operating profit was up 35% and our OP margins expanded 250 basis points to 25.7%. Growth again is led by the continued development of the diesel engine safety system technology and that continues to get this U.S. and North American shale activity. We've got some new engine OEMs that are building the technology into their platforms and that helps us well. We had a record Q3 in terms of our instruments sales around the refinery business, so that seems to be picking up steam. It had been slowed at a much better this year, but still relatively to slow. One of the very few businesses that's not back to the 2008 results and now that's largely there. 
We had an expansion in our alfa [ph] and [indiscernible] Genesco [ph] family of businesses around Sensor Technologies. They've been up over 30% here for instrumentation to measure composites and process manufacturing. And just excellent execution throughout the segment with the exception of our nuclear [indiscernible] business, which has been very soft due to the nuclear plant shutdowns around the world. But for fortunately, it's not a big piece of the total. 
In the fourth quarter, we will benefit from an acquisition that we made right at the end of the third quarter for United Controls. United Controls is a small business in the Midwest, which has a large OEM component with Rolls-Royce. It's got great field service, technical support and its technologies is very complementary to our compressor control business. We've done very little historically [indiscernible], so this gives us a new partner in effect to provide field service and aftermarket application for technology improvements. And it certainly expands our OEM channel access. 
In the oil and gas area, the trends just continue to perform exceptionally well and there's no downturn of any kind, I think expected this year or early next year ago. And seasonality here has always been very important in the fourth quarter. There's a lot of MRO purchases that than to get that in the fourth quarter [indiscernible] residual budgets but do expect that will continue this year and also think margins in the segment will expand in the fourth quarter over where they were reported in the third.
Given all that, we look now to guidance update, next slide. The guidance were increasing our full year guidance from $4.20 to $4.30 to $4.29 to $4.33. Now we started out this year with guidance at $3.82 to $4.02. We increased our load when guidance be $0.47. So at $4.29 to $4.33, that results in Q4 at $1.18 to $1.22 and our full year operating cash flow will exceed $575 million on that revenue.
Next slide. If you look at a summary here before we get into the Q&A period. What we have is the best quarter in the history of the company. It's the highest level of sales, orders, backlog, net earnings, operating and free cash flow ever. Organic sales came in at plus 13%, largely driven by new products and new applications to existing customers and then favorable niche markets. We're really not seeing any slowdown in any activity and any of things that we might consider to be bellwether items that would say things are getting slower. We're just not seeing that. Very broad-based momentum us we entered the fourth quarter, which has allowed us to increase our guidance. Our gross margins at 53.7%, certainly best-in-class. Operating margin at 23.5%, with 36% over leverage and new revenue, I think, again probably best-in-class. Operating cash flow at 23% of sales is nothing short of spectacular. And really, a new milestone for us, it's just as we said, I don't think people are focused how much our EBITDA is growing. But our cash flow, operating cash flow, in the last 2 years has exceeded $1 billion for the first time in our history and if you think about those acquisitions in the last 2 years at $1.1 billion, cash flow were over $1 billion, and we give you some idea about our capacity and transactions looking forward and the cash machine that we've created here. So with that, I think we're ready for questions, John.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of questions. First, Brian, how are you think the businesses whether it be in imaging or RF tag or industrial technology that bit touch areas that are at least in part funded by public sources, municipal sources. How are you feeling about th
componenttext: Just a couple of questions. First, Brian, how are you think the businesses whether it be in imaging or RF tag or industrial technology that bit touch areas that are at least in part funded by public sources, municipal sources. How are you feeling about those businesses heading into 2012? And I guess, what risks or conversely opportunities do you see in those businesses?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, it certainly industrial, you got Neptune is selling product to Municipal Water facilities but we're not really seeing any slowness at all in that arena. As we said orders in the U.S. for them are up over 10% in the third quarter. So that's really no
componenttext: Well, it certainly industrial, you got Neptune is selling product to Municipal Water facilities but we're not really seeing any slowness at all in that arena. As we said orders in the U.S. for them are up over 10% in the third quarter. So that's really not a problem area for us at the moment. And in fact, I think municipal people funding has started to pick up a little steam [indiscernible] but maybe we of were worried about that going into the year and certainly outperformed our peers. It's not as a robust as it was in the past but new products and applications and selling some software along with data collection helps that. In the image area, you have the NIH situation in the U.S. and then similar situation in Japan. Total which, people fear will slow but it technologies we launched for the research sciences are so compelling that they really [indiscernible] through any of that risk. We're not seeing anything that would be measured as softness. It would be driven by the National Institute of Health Funding or really the Japanese. You see a that little more of that in Europe actually than here. But nothing that's much of a headwind. That's actually better than we would have expected in the rate of frequency RF radio frequency rent. The their cash distressed for people. So they are not really viewed as capital spending. I think if they weren't delivering sort of immediate paybacks for people, we'd be more worried than they are. We certainly performed better in the third quarter on an order-end sales basis than we would have expected because we do occasionally listen to the news and manage if you look at the externalities should be scared to death. But fortunately, our businesses are so [indiscernible] and value added that externalities have added an effect on us at this time. So we're not seeing nor does anybody feel fearful about the fourth quarter or frankly next year.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, Brian, just one more follow-up. Can you talk bigger picture about what you guys are seeing from an M&A standpoint? It sounded like you closed on sounded like a relatively small transaction here within the last couple of weeks. How are you thinking a
componenttext: Okay, Brian, just one more follow-up. Can you talk bigger picture about what you guys are seeing from an M&A standpoint? It sounded like you closed on sounded like a relatively small transaction here within the last couple of weeks. How are you thinking about M&A activity kind of over the near to intermediate term? How are multiples trending? What size transactions or businesses are you looking out? How healthy is your pipeline?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, if there's a lot of questions in there, Matt. the United Controls is small deal to us and it's about $25 million, but strategic. And then the [indiscernible] strategic for investment controls, so material to them. Pipeline remains very full. We have
componenttext: Well, if there's a lot of questions in there, Matt. the United Controls is small deal to us and it's about $25 million, but strategic. And then the [indiscernible] strategic for investment controls, so material to them. Pipeline remains very full. We have continuing activity and a lot going on in there. I think [indiscernible] a little breakdown in Europe where the European banks are offering very much support for not too long ago you were seeing 6.5x debt [indiscernible] from those folks. And now you're not seeing any debt [indiscernible] from those folks. So that has an effect both on the reality and the attitude of people. Debt stables in the U.S. have dropped. I think it's hard for most people to get a debt funding towards transaction more than 5x EBITDA and so that trends the multiple [indiscernible] down. They're going to put a lot more equity than they would have before when the debt stable was much higher. Furthermore, the spreads for them and the blended cost of their interest to get a deal done are higher now than they were if spreads have gone up a bit and the mentioned portion of the that. So we're seeing multiples come down a little bit. [indiscernible] their expectations throughout the year, our highest it's [indiscernible] of the reason with our disciplined approach we have a large transaction but we continue to look at a number of large transactions and in some time at it in the foreseeable future, we'll execute on something. Most of the deals we're looking are relatively large and. I would not expect there's always this kind of United full situation we could have 2 or 3 of those but we're kind of patiently waiting for the right balance here. People still are worried about CMS reimbursement and medical, so that's an area you we have to be actually carefully in and in the software side, we've got things going that we like a lot. And it's just price gap kind of discussion. And we're patient and ultimately it's better to be patient. We don't need to do a deal because a deal is available. We got do a deal because it makes sense for our institutional holders and shareholders.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: First question for price/cost in the quarter, can you take us through that? And be very interested how much of that 13% organic was helped by price?
componenttext: First question for price/cost in the quarter, can you take us through that? And be very interested how much of that 13% organic was helped by price?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll take that one. We always look at the price cost equation rather than looking at each of those in isolation. Those always have to be looked in combination with each other. And so what we always track is our gross profit margin. And the fact that
componenttext: Well, I'll take that one. We always look at the price cost equation rather than looking at each of those in isolation. Those always have to be looked in combination with each other. And so what we always track is our gross profit margin. And the fact that gross profits came in at 53.7% and up 50 basis points from where we were at this point last year. It gives us confidence that our businesses are doing the right things with respect to pricing and heading off any material cost for inflation. As you know, the only real exposure that we have in this type of raw material inputs cost is in copper and it goes into our Neptune business. And Neptune we've done a couple of smart things. One, with the redesign of the residential water meter, which reduces the amount of material content as well as improves the quality for the customers which is real positive thing for that. That mitigate some of that exposure. And then we also just entered into supply agreements that are usually 6 to 9 months out, which gives us a little bit better visibility at what the cost structure is going to look like on the input side which allows us to still be able to manage the price equation in no way this doesn't really try of the customers around all the time in that end market. So those are the things that we look, so we're confident that our business have than the right things on price/cost as long as we continue to have the gross profit margins where we see them.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then just over to the businesses. Brian, I hope you can expand on the point regarding the shale gas opportunity and trust this includes the frac-ing phenomenon that's going on. And if I'm not mistaken, this opportunity crosses bo
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then just over to the businesses. Brian, I hope you can expand on the point regarding the shale gas opportunity and trust this includes the frac-ing phenomenon that's going on. And if I'm not mistaken, this opportunity crosses both the industrial business, as well as the energy business, the dewatering pumps and the diesel engines shut offs per share. So what are the opportunities for Roper in aggregate and do these 2 businesses within Roper combined to have more of a one go-to-market strategy or it just individual selling of components?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, it's all of our businesses [indiscernible] Roper have different reasons to be involved with frac-ing and movement. And in addition, out of those a lot of other things that are related to Municipal Water, it's a German company largely involved in Ind
componenttext: Well, it's all of our businesses [indiscernible] Roper have different reasons to be involved with frac-ing and movement. And in addition, out of those a lot of other things that are related to Municipal Water, it's a German company largely involved in India and Australasia for the most part. Our Cornell and Roper businesses are dewatering and also directional drilling and support for the speed in which you can move the drill through the Geological issues that are in front of that. Then the diesel shut off valve is really making sure that all of these diesel engines in fact do shut off instead of continue to run after somebody turned it off. We also have a couple of other businesses [indiscernible] by in New York, which is a sensor-related business that goes into oil and gas and supports some of the technology they need to know about reading information on sensors. So there's really about 6 different businesses. They don't go-to-market under one common sales force because it's not how that business works. So they share customers and talk about things with people with general different influences are making buying decisions about it. So you have to call [indiscernible] channel, mostly direct to the end user or mine itself. And it does get closer and closer to mining applications, which is increasing interesting too.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: The thing to keep in mind in that Dean is this family of businesses is truly $200 million more. But of course, not everything that they do is solely related to the oil and gas shale activity. It's been the key driver, it's been a key driver for each of th
componenttext: The thing to keep in mind in that Dean is this family of businesses is truly $200 million more. But of course, not everything that they do is solely related to the oil and gas shale activity. It's been the key driver, it's been a key driver for each of them but none of them are solely focused on that. These are niche applications that often time that often times will have other types of end-uses. But as we have gone through into detail that we do each quarter with our businesses, the shale activity and the frac-ing activity continue to come up as one of the drivers for each of them.

componenttextpreview: Can't be a lot left because ratio, years ago, what we said to everybody it to throw [indiscernible]. You've got to have your payables equally [indiscernible] inventory and receivables is really a function of pricing and investment with your customer and n
componenttext: Can't be a lot left because ratio, years ago, what we said to everybody it to throw [indiscernible]. You've got to have your payables equally [indiscernible] inventory and receivables is really a function of pricing and investment with your customer and nobody believed it. And everybody believes it now. And so when you look at where we are, that getting the receivables down to 14.7% of sales is really a level performance that is with us never been enough but pretty spectacular. When you got 40% of your business not in the U.S., to get receivables to these kind of level is comforting. I think we've got better quality people doing that work down in the clinical and administrative arena. I think there's a real [indiscernible] knowledge about where you want to invest in collections and the software and technology use to keep realtime data on the customers and all of that has paid big dividends for us. At 6.5% of sales, we're pretty happy. We were happy at 6, 8 ph] but we only like things to improve.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Brian, could you elaborate on what's going on in CBORD? You said the security offering has kind of doubled. Is that the comment over the last year? And could you give us a little more color on what you're doing there to integrate some of your other RF app
componenttext: Brian, could you elaborate on what's going on in CBORD? You said the security offering has kind of doubled. Is that the comment over the last year? componenttext: Well, a couple of things. Year-to-date, this year come it's about double what was the same year-to-date period of a year ago. Got a major job at Miami University that we just completed the installation on there. There's a whole lot of publicity, white papers that have been written about this. We worked both with Schwab [ph] and [indiscernible] different deployment strategies. So there's a lot of revenue that comes through the locking piece. We generally are at the front of the whole system solution, so we're providing a lot of different things to different people. and I'll John have talk a bit about the overall integration. We bring in [indiscernible] in here with sensor technology and we do things with parkings [indiscernible] that comes out of -- so it is a leading-edge solution to people we love at the university level but not everybody can work with us people. It's not easy as sale as a lot of spread equity and a lot of customer service post sale.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: And in fact integration the right word, that's really what CBORD provides for the customers is a single integrated across a diversed campus [indiscernible] Software solutions. So if you have access control, you also have the ability to have payments in fo
componenttext: And in fact integration the right word, that's really what CBORD provides for the customers is a single integrated across a diversed campus [indiscernible] Software solutions. So if you have access control, you also have the ability to have payments in foodcourt, et cetera and all of that ties back to a single database, single integrated realtime database about what a student or a doctor or a nurse has success to in any given time. In fact, we have had some opportunities to bring together a variety of the businesses, one of them at a major university in the big 10 area, both for, and in fact health care solutions. So using CBORD as well as our Cisco [ph] business as well as avionics in a way that allows all of those to talk collaboratively together, which is a future opportunity which we may be able to do more of. But it really gets to the heart of what CBORD does so efficiently and we would look forward to being able to grow that going forward.

componenttext: Is there a way you can give us just some idea to get our head around the scale of the opportunity on, if you think about maybe your most holistic complete application, whether it's at Miami or somewhere else, kind of what your potential value per student per year or some kind of framework of reference so we can kind of think about how to model this or get our head around the element [indiscernible]?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: [indiscernible] think about that in a way give more crisp answer. The problem in answering that question is that if you look at where we get -- I wouldn't think of this as a revenue per student because let's say you're doing Michigan State University, whi
componenttext: [indiscernible] think about that in a way give more crisp answer. The problem in answering that question is that if you look at where we get -- I wouldn't think of this as a revenue per student because let's say you're doing Michigan State University, which is a big application for a variety of things at CBORD you've got it's a be school with thousands of that but it's not -- the incremental cost of the student is exceptionally low. And the dollar that we gain per incremental student is very low. So it's really how much of a suite of services and data collection technologies they buy that's critical. So if it's a turnkey installation where somebody is putting in electronic locking mechanisms and parking control and crude management and nutrition management, they're generally going start at a portion of the activity or try it an area as opposed to putting in at the entire university. So the system grows over time into a full mature of suite of applications and it becomes valuable. So it's really  how many things you can win to sort of get your foot in the door with these people as they build it out. And now we've been very fortunate in the last 2 years to displaces another competitors in other locations and we look forward to continuing to do that. And we have an awful lot of [indiscernible] equity activity and Obama. We just finished a CBORD conference within the last couple of weeks with hundreds and hundreds of people in attendance. And there's 500 different kinds of people who attend this conference that are thinking about ways to use our software and system data collection technologies in a variety of ways around the campus. So it's a mind share of thing that drives the growth sort of more than, gosh I the largest university in the country. I mean, it could be that the smallest one will get you more revenue than a large one because the amount of c activity their purchasing and the number of cards types of applications that they are applying it to if it's long-winded answer but it's the truth.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: We just acquired this company called United Controls and that will be married up with Compressor Controls. So United Controls has been doing significant work for Rolls-Royce for some time. And Rolls-Royce and United Controls was available for sale. Rolls-
componenttext: We just acquired this company called United Controls and that will be married up with Compressor Controls. So United Controls has been doing significant work for Rolls-Royce for some time. And Rolls-Royce and United Controls was available for sale. Rolls-Royce had a great deal to do with whether or not it could be sold and who were allowed to buy it. So we were able to do that on and that gives us a venue to work with Rolls-Royce, which is fundamentally different than what we had from Compressor Controls or we've had some work with them and some fieldwork but nothing quite [indiscernible]. So that's going to give us very interesting build-out around things in 2012 there already, [indiscernible] United Controls and then the field service following to that will be quite significant to from a recurring revenue viewpoint. So it's really, really very material transactions for Compressor Controls.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, yes, and could you just give us a little more perspective on that because when you acquired Compressor Controls in 1992, it was doing almost all its business in the aftermarket. Upgrading compressors, that had been sold by OEMs with the OEMs control
componenttext: Well, yes, and could you just give us a little more perspective on that because when you acquired Compressor Controls in 1992, it was doing almost all its business in the aftermarket. Upgrading compressors, that had been sold by OEMs with the OEMs controls on them. And it was at the time where there was a very large market for Compressor Controls and actually working with OEMs to put the controls on initially rather than retrofitting them later. But never really developed because most of these compressor makers wanted to make their own controls and sell their own controls and it was only 1% or 2% of the cost of the compressor. Anyways, so I think Compressor Controls continue to operate in the aftermarket. Now is this a change, is this a wedge into the OEM putting the controls directly under compressors when they're shipped from the factory?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, it wouldn't -- there's that possibility but that's not the core of the activity. Basically, United Controls has been doing for Rolls-Royce what we do for other people we can't name. So their primarily an aftermarket business, but they can provide an
componenttext: Well, it wouldn't -- there's that possibility but that's not the core of the activity. Basically, United Controls has been doing for Rolls-Royce what we do for other people we can't name. So their primarily an aftermarket business, but they can provide an OEM technology. We provide more OEM technology today than we ever had in the past [indiscernible] large companies that can't be named. But I think, over time, who knows, but at the core, these are really aftermarket upgrades for people that get dedicated algorithms that are meaningful to the end-user of the product where they lower the speed or increased the speed, manage energy much more efficiently with a use of a turbine and get more throughput at the end. And United Controls has, I wouldn't say had a total lock on Rolls-Royce but, certainly been a significantly player for them. But so like acquiring them, we get actually some additional algorithm and specific controls that are for Rolls applications just like the other wins we do for many other people.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, it's really been not bad at all. The situation is if you look at the life science CapEx type companies out there from those reported, they've been up about 4% in the third quarter. We're doing better than that. The reality is that we had a very larg
componenttext: Well, it's really been not bad at all. The situation is if you look at the life science CapEx type companies out there from those reported, they've been up about 4% in the third quarter. We're doing better than that. The reality is that we had a very large order for [indiscernible] mobile, which reports in this segment. That was a turnkey situation and if you take that out in both equations, and then we have one particular customer in medical that buys our dosage pumps, normally, this is not -- it's a lumpy business but every once in a while, you get an exceptional order for multiple months and that happened in the third quarter last year. That's masking the strength there. The strength in medical is really a bit better than you're able to see in the aggregate numbers. So we also have really important family of products around [indiscernible], which we have been launching throughout the year. And they're in a bunch of different trial applications. People are quite bullish about that for 2012. So it's a little slower than it was. It's consistently been in the low double-digit arena. Now, it's closer to sort of 10% growth. But it's nothing that -- we're not seeing any megatrend that would say there's a real problem in medical. The camera businesses grew modestly, so they also had a pull back a little bit to [indiscernible] business that was spectacular.

componenttextpreview: On the industrial tech side, just to clarify your comments about Neptune. We had -- the business was flat in the U.S. but strong in Canada and Mexico in the quarter and the orders were plus 10% in the U.S. Is there a reason that you saw for the flatness i
componenttext: On the industrial tech side, just to clarify your comments about Neptune. We had -- the business was flat in the U.S. but strong in Canada and Mexico in the quarter and the orders were plus 10% in the U.S. Is there a reason that you saw for the flatness in the third quarter in the U.S.? I mean, it sounds like is this a funding issue where orders were better than sales in the quarter or. . .

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: No I don't think it is a funding issue. I think it's just a question of timing and the comparison to the prior year. If you kind of take a little bit at a sort of a wider lens to this, I mean Neptune, just if you excludes -- we've got a few nice winds bot
componenttext: No I don't think it is a funding issue. I think it's just a question of timing and the comparison to the prior year. If you kind of take a little bit at a sort of a wider lens to this, I mean Neptune, just if you excludes -- we've got a few nice winds both with the Canada project, which is continuing which will give us in the neighborhood of $15 million maybe a little bit more million dollars next year and double that next year. So that will continue to ramp up. We also had a nice with some Mexico meters. Those maters, more standard meters, going into Mexico, which have a slightly different margin profile but still a nice win for us. But if you take a wider lens and look at just the U.S. for Neptune, really on the year-to-date basis, revenue was up at a mid-single digit range and the orders continue to outpace sales. So, I mean, it's the question of the confidence they have against the very strong third quarter last year but on the wider lens, looking year-to-date basis, we're still in a pretty good position there.

componenttextpreview: Oh, yes. We generally don't have contracts for people. We have long-term compensation programs for people. They're all involved with different forms of stock option [indiscernible] stock criteria and then there's cash bonus programs are related to improve
componenttext: Oh, yes. We generally don't have contracts for people. We have long-term compensation programs for people. They're all involved with different forms of stock option [indiscernible] stock criteria and then there's cash bonus programs are related to improvement year-over-year and operating income. So if you think about to going into a slow environment, one of the reasons our people are so nimble in our opinion is the only way they earn a bonus to drive continued performance is to get better in the new year than they were in the prior year. There's no sort of forgiveness for the fact that the markets difficult. So all these guys are prepared to be quite nimble. They have very strong operating people in all of those units and those people are -- they understand their compensation better than any of us do and I think we understand it quite well. So they're highly motivated about that and they have a very strong view of how stuff happens. And in enterprise-level, we're somewhat compensated the same way on a cash basis. So that sort of focuses attention here. We continue to add modestly to our orbit staff. We've got strengthened our legal area and tax area. We added a couple of executives this year that are dedicated to corporate development activity in software and medical orientation. So we really have the strongest team of people that we've ever had. For myself, I got a long-term besting program from equity so that continues out to idle no, 2014 or '15 or something. And I would expect that my program of one year updates will continue with [indiscernible] for quite some time.

componenttext: Well, I think you wouldn't be surprised to learn that when you're a technology company like we are, we're providing OEM technology the people, people have no interest in us, telling Intel inside unless they want to do that.
