headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Vicki, and thank you all for joining us this morning as we discuss the results of our record third quarter. Joining me this morning is Brian Jellison, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Paul Soni, Vice President and Controller
componenttext:
Thank you, Vicki, and thank you all for joining us this morning as we discuss the results of our record third quarter. Joining me this morning is Brian Jellison, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Paul Soni, Vice President and Controller.
Earlier this morning, we issued a press release announcing our financial results. The press release also includes replay information for today's call. We have prepared slides to accompany today's call, which are available through the webcast and also available at our website at www.roperind.com.
Now if you'll please turn to Slide 2. We begin with our Safe Harbor statement. During the course of today's call, we'll be making forward-looking statements, which are subject to risks and uncertainties as described on this page and as detailed more fully in our SEC filings. You should listen to today's call in the context of that information.
And now if you'll please turn to Slide 3. I'll turn the call over to Brian Jellison, Roper's Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer. After his prepared remarks, we'll take questions from our telephone participants. Brian?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. Good morning, everybody. We'll start off with a quick overview of the Q3 financial results and then talk specifically about the segment performance and outlook for the fourth quarter, update you on our guidance summary and then open it up
componenttext:
Thank you, John. Good morning, everybody. We'll start off with a quick overview of the Q3 financial results and then talk specifically about the segment performance and outlook for the fourth quarter, update you on our guidance summary and then open it up to questions and answers. 
So first slide. If we look at the Q3 financial results, once again, they're an all-time record for any quarter in the history of the company, not just a record third quarter. Orders were at the highest level in history, sales, the same. Backlog, highest level, net earnings, a highest level, and operating and free cash flow in the quarter set a new standard for the company. Our total sales in the quarter were up 18% and organic sales were up 13%, which was frankly better than expected. 
Our book-to-bill was greater than one for the 9th straight quarter and our record backlog of $876 million is up $106 million from the third quarter a year ago. Operating margins were terrific throughout the enterprise, they were up 230 basis points so that operating margin was 23% of revenue in the quarter. Our EBITDA was $203 million in the quarter, a fairly astonishing number by any standard, and EBITDA margin was 28.6%. Our operating cash flow was 23% of sales at $167 million and our free cash flow was 22% of sales at $157 million.
Next slide. If you look at the income statement, you should see that bookings again were above 1, at 1.01. Net sales were, as we said, up 13% organically. Gross profit picked up 50 basis points from a year ago. Our operating income was up 30% from $128 million to $167 million, and margin at 23 %, up from 21.2% in the third quarter a year ago. Our tax rate was actually a headwind in the quarter year. In the third quarter last year, it's only 25.9%. As most of you would know, third quarter results tend to have whatever rollover there is in that 104A calculation for filing tax returns. This year, our tax rate was 27.7%, a 180 basis points increase over the prior year, which took a couple a pennies out of our results. 
Net earnings were $110 million, up 31% from the prior year and our diluted earnings per share were $1.12 versus $0.87.
Next slide. Free cash flow in the quarter was truly spectacular. 22% of revenue and 142% of net earnings, so it'd be the 14th consecutive year that our free cash flow has exceeded net earnings. And really, we had very strong execution throughout the family of businesses. And you can see the comparisons prior year here on the graph.
Next slide. We had quite substantial EBITDA gross. I'm not sure people caught up to just how much our trailing EBITDA continues to grow. We're up 33% in EBITDA over the prior year and our trailing 12 months EBITDA now ending the third quarter is $779 million. That's up from $585 million in the corresponding trailing 12-month period ended in the third quarter of '10, and up from $507 million in 2009. Part of the reason for that is continued margin expansion. Our EBITDA margins in 2009 were 24 % for that TTM period. In 2010, they were up 140 basis points to 25.9% and this year they've skyrocketed to 28 % from 25.9%.
Next slide. Our asset velocity performance continues to be best-in-class. You can see inventory has actually dropped to 7.4% from 8.9% just 2 years ago. Our receivables are down 200 basis points to 14.7% from 16.7%, just a terrific performance by all our field operating units around receivables. And payables and accruals have actually come down, or our numbers would be even more spectacular. So in total, when we look at the inventory plus receivables minus payables and accruals, we finished the quarter at 6 %. That's 240 basis points better than just 2 years ago. So our exceptional performance in that category continues.
Next slide. Here we look at our sort of balance sheet and financial position. We ended the quarter with $246 million in cash. Our trailing 12 months EBITDA is $779 million. Our gross debt number is $1,174,000,000. If you take that $246 million and cash away, you got net debt at $928 million. Shareholder equity continues to be strong there, in excess of $3 billion, meaning our net debt-to-net cap number is about 23%. Our gross debt-to-EBITDA is about 1.5x, so we have very ample capacity inside anything we'd like to do. And our EBITDA-to-interest coverage is over 12x. Now in the last 2 years, we invested $1.1 billion in transactions. But as you can see, the balance sheet is stronger than ever.
Next slide. So here we'll take a look at our segment performance and the outlook for the rest of the year. 
Next slide. Our Q3 segment performance was remarkably similar. You can see EBITDA margins in industrial, RF and medical all were 31%, and energy, they were 29%. The OP margins continue to march forward as we have revenue growth and we capture leverage associated with that and throughout the enterprise, we're very happy with the margin performance.
Next slide. If we go to the largest segment in the quarter was RF Technology. It had sales up 19%, operating profit was up 41% and the operating profit margin reached 23.8%, up 380 basis points from the corresponding period in the prior year. Orders exceeded revenue. If you look at the specific commentary here, by the way, the leverage there on incremental revenue was about 44%. So we had very strong growth throughout the segment, organic sales, up 15%. The software businesses had double-digit organic growth, with particular tribute to CBORD, who continues to have quite spectacular performance around Integrated Security Solutions that we provide the universities. That business has nearly doubled this year compared to last. Our Freight Matching business grew at a double-digit rate as we've got more new subscribers and their very favorable dynamics occurring in the spot market due to volatility in gasoline prices and driver shortages and truck shortages. 
Our Toll & Traffic Solutions business, which is less than half of the segment, we remind people, did well as a result of an upgrade where we're converting Puerto Rico from a coin-base technology to an electronic technology and we had strong tag shipments in several locations around the world.
In the fourth quarter, looking forward, we're going to continue to benefit from this electronic tolling project in Puerto Rico. Our iTrade business enters with a strong backlog and we expect double-digit growth and it will finally be showing up as organic growth here in the fourth quarter for us. The CBORD backlog remains strong enough to assure double-digit growth in the fourth quarter. We expect to get continued margin improvement, even given what we had here in the third quarter. We think we'll even do a bit better in the fourth quarter. And our Technolog operations in France, where we've been installing a system, we would hope that, that gets completed in the fourth quarter and then in 2012, that'll allow us to get our data services revenue, which comes in at lower revenue but much higher margins.
Next slide. Here, looking at the industrial technology segment, while we often focus on Neptune because it's traditionally been about half the segment, growth in the other areas is nothing short of spectacular. Here, orders were up substantially above the sales revenue of $185 million. Sales were up 15% from the prior year. Operating profit was up 16% and operating profit margin in the industrial businesses was 28.2%. 
Fluid handling continues to perform just in a very strong manner, driven really by all the shale, gas and oil activity that's occurring in Canada and the U.S. Lots of new customers and a lot of new applications. New products and strong end markets are also helping our material test business, which is off to a record year by a considerable margin. 
And then in Neptune in North American meter revenue was relatively flat, but we had strong growth in Mexico and Canada. Surprisingly, the U.S. order flow in the third quarter was up more than 10% in the U.S. We had a very successful launch of our low-profile, lead-free residential water meter. A lot of people have gone out and checked the Shed The Lead video that we have and it certainly created a lot of interest in our water meter business. 
So we look to Q4, we expect strong seasonality. Generally speaking, we had year-end buys from people in both this and the energy business and we haven't seen any trends that would indicate that would not occur again this year. Neptune is going to get double-digit growth, led by the Toronto installation activity, which is going to start to pick up in the fourth quarter and be substantially stronger in 2012. 
And then our favorable end markets are pretty much generally true in the -- so just so we are not doing well in the 30-plus percent leverage we got in Q3, we would hope it'll improve even a bit more in the rest of the year and next.
If we go next slide. If you look here at the Medical and Scientific Imaging segment, it was up 16% in revenue. Orders actually exceeded sales and orders were up sequentially from the second quarter. Operating profit was up 24% compared to the sales increase of 16%. So we had strong leverage here, about 34%. And the OP margin increased 150 basis points to 24.7%. Our high-end imaging solutions driven largely by Gatan's quantum and direct detection camera lines are continuing to perform in a fantastic way and we have a new product out there that's processing frame speeds at 83 gigabytes a second. I'm not sure anybody could relate to just exactly how fast that is, but it's leading-edge technology for the most supreme applications in the research area and has added substantially to our growth this year. 
The medical platform continues to perform well. The adoption rates for both Bladderscan and GlideScope continue to escalate. We continue to gain ground internationally in terms of consumables and our ultrasound business and our couch top patient positioning technology for the MRI processes is beginning to gain momentum. There's a lot of favorable papers, write-ups and comments about this, and we think it'll be a long-term winning proposition for the enterprise. 
In the third quarter, on an order comparison basis, we had very tough comps because of 2 things that happened last year. We do report our Rugged Mobile business in here, which is certainly not key to the enterprise but it had a particularly strong Q3 order for long-term delivery last year, which, of course, wouldn't have been repeated in any one quarter. So it's a new initiation of an order. And then we had very strong dosage delivery business last year, and this year was more normalized. So both of that created a bit a headwind in terms of comps. But if you mask, take that away, the book-to-bill was above one, sequentially higher than the second quarter, and our backlog is strong so we don't expect any difficulty here.
In the fourth quarter, we wind up, of course, with record backlog entering the quarter. So that kind of assures our shipment pattern should be fine. We expect to have continued growth in medical because the patient treatment technologies that were involved and our continuing to grow. We have a higher fourth quarter because Northern Digital, which was acquired, will begin to kick in. It has traditionally strong seasonality in the fourth quarter and we haven't seen anything that wouldn't suggest that will occur here.
Next slide. Here when we get to energy systems and controls, you can see once again very strong performance. Sales were up 22%. Orders were just slightly ahead of sales, up 12%. Operating profit was up 35% and our OP margins expanded 250 basis points to 25.7%. Growth again is led by the continued development of the diesel engine safety system technology and that continues to get this U.S. and North American shale activity. We've got some new engine OEMs that are building the technology into their platforms and that helps as well. We had a record Q3 in terms of our instrument sales around the refinery business, so that seems to be picking up steam. It had been slow. It had been much better this year, but still relatively slow. One of the very few businesses that's not back to the 2008 results and now that's largely there. 
We had an expansion in our Alpha, and Viatran and Dynisco family of businesses around sensor technologies. They've been up over 30% here for instrumentation to measure composites and process manufacturing. And just excellent execution throughout the segment with the exception of our nuclear techs business, which has been very soft due to the nuclear plant shutdowns around the world. But fortunately, it's not a big piece of the total. 
In the fourth quarter, we will benefit from an acquisition that we made right at the end of the third quarter called United Controls. United Controls is a small business in the Midwest, which has a large OEM component with Rolls-Royce. It's got great field service, technical support and its technology is very complementary to our compressor control business. We've done very little historically with Rolls-Royce and so this gives us a new partner in effect to provide field service and aftermarket application for technology improvements. And it certainly expands our OEM channel access. 
In the oil and gas area, the trends just continue to perform exceptionally well and there's no downturn of any kind expected this year or early next. And seasonality here has always been very important. At fourth quarter, there's a lot of MRO purchases that tend to get done in the fourth quarter with residual budgets, but we expect that would continue this year. And we also think margins in the segment will expand in the fourth quarter over where they were reported in the third.
Given all that, we look now to guidance update, next slide. The guidance, we're increasing our full year guidance from $4.20 to $4.30 to $4.29 to $4.33. Now we started out this year with guidance at $3.82 to $4.02. And when we look cumulatively, we've actually now increased our low-end guidance by $0.47. So at $4.29 to $4.33, that results in Q4 at $1.18 to $1.22. And our full year operating cash flow will exceed $575 million on that revenue.
Next slide. If you look at a summary here before we get into the Q&A period, what we have is the best quarter in the history of the company. It's the highest level of sales orders, backlog, net earnings, operating and free cash flow ever. Organic sales came in at plus 13%, largely driven by new products and new applications to existing customers and then to favorable niche markets. We're really not seeing any slowdown in any activity in any of things that we might consider to be bellwether items that would say things are getting slower. We're just -- we're not seeing that. Very broad-based momentum as we entered the fourth quarter, which has allowed us to increase our guidance. Our gross margin is at 53.7%, certainly best-in-class. Operating margin is at 23.5%, with 36% overall leverage a new revenue, again, I think probably best-in-class. Operating cash flow at 23% of sales is nothing short of spectacular. And really, a new milestone for us, it's just as we've said, I don't think people are focused on just how much our EBITDA is growing. But our cash flow, our operating cash flow now in the last 2 years has exceeded $1 billion for the first time in our history. And if you think about those acquisitions in the last 2 years at $1.1 billion and cash flow over $1 billion, and we give you some idea about our capacity in transactions looking forward and the cash machine that we've created here. So with that, I think we're ready for questions, John.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, all right,  Vicki. So if you'll start the question-and-answer part of the call.
componenttext: Okay, all right,  Vicki. So if you'll start the question-and-answer part of the call.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our first question from Matt Summerville with KeyBanc.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our first question from Matt Summerville with KeyBanc.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of questions. First, Brian, how are you thinking about the business whether it be in imaging or RF tag or industrial technology that bit touch areas that are at least in part funded by public sources, municipal sources, how are you feeling a
componenttext: Just a couple of questions. First, Brian, how are you thinking about the business whether it be in imaging or RF tag or industrial technology that bit touch areas that are at least in part funded by public sources, municipal sources, how are you feeling about those businesses heading into 2012? And I guess, what risks or conversely opportunities do you see in those businesses?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, it -- certainly in industrial, you got Neptune as selling product to municipal water facilities but we're not really seeing any slowness at all in that arena. As we said, orders are -- in the U.S. for them went up over 10% in the third quarter. So t
componenttext: Well, it -- certainly in industrial, you got Neptune as selling product to municipal water facilities but we're not really seeing any slowness at all in that arena. As we said, orders are -- in the U.S. for them went up over 10% in the third quarter. So that's really not a problem area for us at the moment. And in fact, I think the municipal funding has started to pick up a little steam with community bond so we were worried about that going into the year and it certainly outperformed our fears. It's not as a robust as it was in the past but new products and applications and selling some software along with data collection helps that. In the image area, you have the NIH situation in the U.S. and then a similar situation in Japan, a total of which people fear is a little slow but the technologies we've launched through our research scientists are so compelling that they really blown through any of that risk. We're not seeing anything that would be measured as softness that would be driven by the National Institute of Health Funding or really the Japanese. You see a little more of that actually in Europe than you do here. But nothing that's much of a headwind. So that's actually better than we would've expected in the radio frequency arena, again the applications we have tend to be cash registers for people. So really they're not really viewed as capital spending. I think if they weren't delivering sort of immediate paybacks for people, we'd be more worried than they are. We certainly performed better in the third quarter on an order-end sales basis than we would have expected because we do occasionally listen to the news and manage, if you look at all the externalities you'd be scared to death. But fortunately, our businesses are so niche-y and so specific and value-added that those externalities haven't had much effect on us at this time. So we're not seeing nor does anybody feel fearful about the fourth quarter or frankly next year.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, Brian, and then just one more follow-up. Can you talk a little bigger picture about what you guys are seeing from an M&A standpoint? It sounded like you are closed on -- it sounded at least like a relatively small transaction here within the last co
componenttext: Okay, Brian, and then just one more follow-up. Can you talk a little bigger picture about what you guys are seeing from an M&A standpoint? It sounded like you are closed on -- it sounded at least like a relatively small transaction here within the last couple of weeks. How are you thinking about M&A activity kind of over the near to intermediate term? How are multiples trending? What size transactions or businesses are you looking at? How healthy is your pipeline?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, there's a lot of questions in there, Matt. The United Controls is a small deal to us and it's about $25 million, but strategic. And then the lesser,  very strategic for compressor controls, so material to them. Pipeline remains very full. We have co
componenttext: Well, there's a lot of questions in there, Matt. The United Controls is a small deal to us and it's about $25 million, but strategic. And then the lesser,  very strategic for compressor controls, so material to them. Pipeline remains very full. We have continuing activity and a lot going on there. I think we've finally seen a little breakdown in Europe where the European banks aren't offering very much support whereas not too long ago you were seeing 6.5x debt staples from those folks and now you're not seeing any debt staples from those folks. So that has an effect both on the reality and the attitude of people. Debt staples in the U.S. have dropped. I think it's hard for most people to get a debt funding for a transaction more than about 5x EBITDA and so that trends the multiple down as we're not going to put in a whole lot more equity than they would have before when the debt staple was much higher. Furthermore, the spreads for them and the blended cost of their interest to get a deal done are higher now than they were as spreads have gone up a bit on the mezzanine portion of the debt. So we're seeing multiples come down a little bit. Sell orders are still -- their expectations throughout the year were too high. It's one of the reasons that, with our disciplined approach, we haven't done a large transaction, but we continue to look at a number of large transactions. And sometime, I think in the foreseeable future, we'll execute on something. Most of the deals we're looking at are relatively large and I wouldn't expect that there's always this kind of the United full situation, we could have 2 or 3 of those, but we're kind of patiently waiting for the right balance here. People still are worried about CMS reimbursement on medical, so that's an area you have to be exceptionally careful in. And in the software side, we've got things going that we like a lot. And it's just a price gap kind of discussion. And we're patient and ultimately it's better to be patient. We don't need to do a deal because a deal is available. We need to do a deal because it makes sense for our institutional holders and our shareholders.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Next we'll hear from Deane Dray  with Citi.
componenttext: Next we'll hear from Deane Dray  with Citi.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Brian and John, first question for price/cost in the quarter, can you take us through that? And be very interested on how much of that 13% organic was helped by price?
componenttext: Brian and John, first question for price/cost in the quarter, can you take us through that? And be very interested on how much of that 13% organic was helped by price?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, Dean, I'll take that one. It's -- we always look at the price/cost equation rather than looking at each of those in isolation. Those always have to be looked in combination with each other. And so what we always track is our gross profit margin. And
componenttext: Well, Dean, I'll take that one. It's -- we always look at the price/cost equation rather than looking at each of those in isolation. Those always have to be looked in combination with each other. And so what we always track is our gross profit margin. And the fact that gross profits came in at 53.7% and up 50 basis points from where we were at this point last year. It gives us confidence that our businesses are doing the right things with respect to pricing and heading off any material cost push inflation. As you know, the only real exposure that we have any type of raw material input cost is in copper and it goes into our Neptune business. And Neptune has really done a couple of very smart things. One, with the redesign of the residential water meter, which reduces the amount of material content as well as improves the quality for the customers, which is a real positive thing. So that mitigates some of that exposure. And then we also just enter into supply agreements that are usually 6 to 9 months out, which gives us a little bit better visibility at what the cost structure is going to look like on the input side, which allows us to still be able to manage the price equation in a way that doesn't really jerk the customers around all the time in that end market. So those are the things that we look at, and so we're confident that our businesses have done the right things on price/cost as long as we continue to have the gross profit margins where we see them.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then just over on the businesses. Brian, I hope you can expand on the point regarding the shale gas opportunity and I trust this includes the frac-ing phenomenon that's going on. And if I'm not mistaken, this opportunity crosses
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then just over on the businesses. Brian, I hope you can expand on the point regarding the shale gas opportunity and I trust this includes the frac-ing phenomenon that's going on. And if I'm not mistaken, this opportunity crosses both the industrial business, as well as the energy business, the dewatering pumps and the diesel engine shut-offs. So what is the opportunities for Roper in aggregate and do these 2 businesses within Roper combine to have more of a one go-to-market strategy or is it just individual selling of components?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, it's all of our pump businesses [indiscernible] Cornell and Roper have different reasons to be involved with frac-ing and movement. And in addition, out of those a lot of other things that are related to municipal water, it's a German company largel
componenttext: Well, it's all of our pump businesses [indiscernible] Cornell and Roper have different reasons to be involved with frac-ing and movement. And in addition, out of those a lot of other things that are related to municipal water, it's a German company largely involved in India and Australasia for the most part. Our Cornell and Roper businesses are dewatering and also directional drilling and support for the speed in which you can move the drill through the geological issues that are in front of that. Then the diesel shut-off valve is really making sure that all these diesel engines in fact do shut off instead of continue to run after somebody turned it off. Now we also have a couple other businesses, Viatran in northern New York, which is a sensor-related business that goes into oil and gas and supports some of the technology they need to know about reading information on sensors. So there's really about 6 different businesses. They don't go to market under one common sales force because it's not how that business works. So they share customers and talk about things with people but generally, different influences are making volume decisions about it. So you have to call through our channel, mostly direct to the end user or mine itself. And it does get closer and closer to mining applications, which is increasingly interesting to us.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Can you aggregate what the revenue opportunity is for this market?
componenttext: Can you aggregate what the revenue opportunity is for this market?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think in total, the family of businesses you're looking at are somewhere in the $200-plus million of revenue growing quite substantially but in the 20% range, not the 5% range.
componenttext: Well, I think in total, the family of businesses you're looking at are somewhere in the $200-plus million of revenue growing quite substantially but in the 20% range, not the 5% range.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: The thing to keep in mind in that, Dean, is this family of businesses, it is just truly $200 million, maybe a little bit more. But of course, not everything that they do is solely related to the oil and gas shale activity. It's been the key driver. It's b
componenttext: The thing to keep in mind in that, Dean, is this family of businesses, it is just truly $200 million, maybe a little bit more. But of course, not everything that they do is solely related to the oil and gas shale activity. It's been the key driver. It's been a key driver for each of them, but none of them are solely focused on that. These are niche applications that often time times will have other types of end uses. But as we have gone through into detail that we do each quarter with our businesses, the shale gas activity and the frac-ing activity continue to come up as one of the drivers for each of them.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011

componenttext: Next we'll hear from Mark Douglass with Longbow Research.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011

componenttext: If we can look at fourth quarter, John, it looks like the orders and backlog support, it appears to me double-digit organic sales in 4Q. Is that the right way to think about it at this point with minimal FX?

componenttext: Closer to high-single digits, but never totally about the revenue for us. It's about margin discipline and cash so...

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Right. And then, Brian, you're continuing to drive down working capital to very impressive levels. How much is left there? It looks like you're reaching [indiscernible], is that true or what do you think is...
componenttext: Right. And then, Brian, you're continuing to drive down working capital to very impressive levels. How much is left there? It looks like you're reaching [indiscernible], is that true or what do you think is...

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Can't be a lot left because, years ago, what we said to everybody and they used to throw ball bat to us. which that, you've got to have your payables equal to your inventory and then receivables is really a function of pricing and investment with your cus
componenttext: Can't be a lot left because, years ago, what we said to everybody and they used to throw ball bat to us. which that, you've got to have your payables equal to your inventory and then receivables is really a function of pricing and investment with your customer and nobody believed it. Everybody believes it now. And so when you look at where we are, getting the receivables down to 14.7% of sales is really a level performance that is, with us, never good enough but pretty freaking spectacular. So when you got 40% of your business not in the U.S., to get your receivables down to those kind of level is comforting. I think we've got better quality people doing that work down in the clinical and administrative arena. I think there's a real earned knowledge about where you want to invest in collections and the software and technology use to keep realtime data on the customers, and all of that has paid big dividends for us. At 6  % of sales, we're pretty happy. We were happy at 6.8% but we only like things to improve.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Next we'll hear from with Jeff Sprague with Vertical Research.
componenttext: Next we'll hear from with Jeff Sprague with Vertical Research.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Brian, could you elaborate on what's going on in CBORD? You said the security offering has kind of doubled. Like is that the comment over the last year? And could you give us a little more color on what you're doing there to integrate some of your other R
componenttext: Brian, could you elaborate on what's going on in CBORD? You said the security offering has kind of doubled. Like is that the comment over the last year? And could you give us a little more color on what you're doing there to integrate some of your other RF applications with CBORD to try to bring a broader sweep for that end market?;

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, a couple of things. Year-to-date, this year it's about double what was the same year-to-date period of a year ago. Got a major job at Miami University that we just completed the installation on there. There's a whole lot of publicity, white papers t
componenttext: Well, a couple of things. Year-to-date, this year it's about double what was the same year-to-date period of a year ago. Got a major job at Miami University that we just completed the installation on there. There's a whole lot of publicity, white papers that have been written about this. We worked both with [indiscernible] and different deployment strategies. So there's a lot of revenue that comes through the locking piece. We generally are at the front of the whole system solution, so we're providing a lot of different things to different people. And I'll have John talk a little bit about overall integration. We bring Inovonics in here with sensor technology and we do things with parkings troll that come out of transport. So it is a leading-edge solution to people we love at the university level, but not everybody can work with us people. It's not the easiest sale, there's a lot of sweat equity and a lot of customer service post sale.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: And in fact, integration is the right word. That's really what CBORD provides for their customers is a single integrated across a diverse campus set of software solutions. So if you have access control, you also have the ability to have payments in food c
componenttext: And in fact, integration is the right word. That's really what CBORD provides for their customers is a single integrated across a diverse campus set of software solutions. So if you have access control, you also have the ability to have payments in food court, et cetera and all of that ties back to a single database, single integrated realtime database about what a student or a doctor or a nurse has access to at any given time. In fact, we had some opportunities to bring together a variety of the businesses, one of them at a major university in the big 10 area, both for, and in fact in their healthcare solutions. So using CBORD as well as our Cisco business as well as Inovonics in a way that allows all of those to talk collaboratively together, which is a future opportunity, which we may be able to do more of. But it really gets to the heart of what CBORD does so efficiently and we look forward to being able to grow that going forward -

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Is there a way you can give us just some idea to get our head around the scale of the opportunity on -- if you think about maybe your most holistic complete application, whether it's at Miami or somewhere else, kind of what your potential value per studen
componenttext: Is there a way you can give us just some idea to get our head around the scale of the opportunity on -- if you think about maybe your most holistic complete application, whether it's at Miami or somewhere else, kind of what your potential value per student per year is or some kind of framework of reference so we can kind of think about how to model this or get our head around the ultimate opportunity there?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Maybe if I think about that in a way to give a little more crisp answer. The problem in answering the question is that if you look at where we get like the -- I wouldn't think of this a revenue per student because, let's say you're doing Michigan State Un
componenttext: Maybe if I think about that in a way to give a little more crisp answer. The problem in answering the question is that if you look at where we get like the -- I wouldn't think of this a revenue per student because, let's say you're doing Michigan State University, which is a big application for a variety of things at CBORD, you've got -- it's a big 10 school with thousands of that but it's not -- the incremental cost of a student is exceptionally low. And the dollar that we gain for an incremental student is very low. So it's really how much of a suite of services and data collection technologies they buy that's critical. So if it's a turnkey installation where somebody is putting in electronic locking mechanisms and parking control and crude management and nutrition management, they're generally going start out with a portion of the activity or try it in an area as opposed to putting in at the entire university. So the system grows over time into a full mature suite of applications and becomes very valuable. So it's really how many new things can you win to sort of get your foot in the door with these people as they build it out. And now we've been very fortunate in the last 2 years to displace another competitor in several locations and we look forward to continuing to do that. And we have an awful lot of sweat equity and activity involved. We just finished a CBORD user conference within the last couple of weeks with hundreds and hundreds of people in attendance. And there's over 500 different kinds of people who attend this conference that are thinking about ways to use our software and system data collection technologies in a variety of ways around the campus. So it's a mind-share thing that drives the growth sort of more than the, "Gosh, I got the largest university in the country." I mean, it could be that the smallest one would get you more revenue than a large one because the amount of c activity they're purchasing and the number of cards and applications that they're applying it to if it's sort of long-winded answer but it's the truth.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: And just final housekeeping one for me, if I could. John, just thinking about the 3 points of consolidated M&A and 2 points of FX, I believe the M&A is more than digital. Is there anything else in the other segments and can you give us a little color on t
componenttext: And just final housekeeping one for me, if I could. John, just thinking about the 3 points of consolidated M&A and 2 points of FX, I believe the M&A is more than digital. Is there anything else in the other segments and can you give us a little color on the FX?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, there's -- some of our RF and Northern Digital is hardly -- just a very small piece there.
componenttext: Well, there's -- some of our RF and Northern Digital is hardly -- just a very small piece there.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: So it's mostly iTrade?
componenttext: So it's mostly iTrade?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, inside RF, it's iTrade. And inside our Medical and Imaging business, it's going to be Northern Digital. The other part of your question around the FX, just to kind of go through quickly, the FX by segment were 2 out on a consolidated basis. It was 1
componenttext: Well, inside RF, it's iTrade. And inside our Medical and Imaging business, it's going to be Northern Digital. The other part of your question around the FX, just to kind of go through quickly, the FX by segment were 2 out on a consolidated basis. It was 1% in RF, it was 2% in Imaging and then 3% Industrial and 3 % in Energy. So really reflective of the more global set of businesses inside energy and industrial, whereas RF and Imaging really don't have as much exposure there because of the larger medical footprint, which is still largely U.S. although a lot of growth outside the U.S. in the RF business with a large amount of recurring revenue out of our telegraphic [ph] business.

componenttext: Well, we got our first trading office deployment in Europe with this large contract completed successfully in the quarter. So that's kind of critical turnkey nature of what happens. And then now that, that's in place, we'll start to see some deployment activity in Q4, which will help drive our double-digit growth there in that business in the fourth quarter and then much more revenue in 2012. Now that you've got the first trading deployment underway, they should start to roll it out to other vendors, so I think that will be very helpful to us next year. We still aren't allowed to talk about who it is because of the sensitivity of the customer, but it's among the most significant people in Europe. So we expect it to be long and [Indiscernible] benefits for us.

componenttext: $4.02, okay. Now you mentioned during your opening remarks that CCC Compressor Controls has a arrangement with Rolls-Royce? So...

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, no, just acquired this company called United Controls and that will be married up with Compressor Controls. So United Controls has been doing significant work for Rolls-Royce for some time. And Rolls-Royce -- when United Controls was available for s
componenttext: Well, no, just acquired this company called United Controls and that will be married up with Compressor Controls. So United Controls has been doing significant work for Rolls-Royce for some time. And Rolls-Royce -- when United Controls was available for sale, Rolls-Royce had a great deal to do with whether or not it could be sold and who would be allowed to buy it. So we were able to do that, and that gives us a venue to work with Rolls-Royce, which is fundamentally different than what we had from Compressor Controls where we've had some work with them and some fieldwork but nothing like bolt [ph] enjoys. So that's going to give us very interesting build-out around things in 2012 that already committed to United Controls and then the field service follow-on with that will be quite significant to us from a recurring revenue viewpoint. So it's a really very material transactions for Compressor Controls.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, yes, and could you just give us a little more perspective on that because when you acquired Compressor Controls in 1992, it was doing almost all its business in the aftermarket. Upgrading compressors that had been sold by OEMs with the OEMs controls
componenttext: Well, yes, and could you just give us a little more perspective on that because when you acquired Compressor Controls in 1992, it was doing almost all its business in the aftermarket. Upgrading compressors that had been sold by OEMs with the OEMs controls on them. And it was thought the time that there was a very large market for Compressor Controls in actually working with OEMs to put the controls on initially rather than retrofitting them later. But that really never developed because most of these compressor makers wanted to make their own controls and sell their own controls and was only 1% or 2% of the cost of the compressor. Anyway, so I think Compressor Controls continued to operate in the aftermarket. Now is this a change, is this a wedge into the OEM putting the controls directly on the compressors when they're shipped from the factory?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I wouldn't -- there's that possibility but that's not the core of the activity. Basically, United Controls has been doing for Rolls-Royce what we do for other people we can't name. So they're primarily an aftermarket business but they can provide an
componenttext: Well, I wouldn't -- there's that possibility but that's not the core of the activity. Basically, United Controls has been doing for Rolls-Royce what we do for other people we can't name. So they're primarily an aftermarket business but they can provide an OEM technology. We provide more OEM technology today than we ever have in the past for some large companies that can't be named. But I think, over time, who knows, but at the core, these are really aftermarket upgrades for people that could get dedicated algorithms that are meaningful to the end-user of the product where they can lower their speed or increase the speed, manage energy much more efficiently with the use of a turbine and get more throughput at the end. And United Controls has, I wouldn't say had a total lock on Rolls-Royce but, certainly been a very significantly player for them. And so like acquiring them, we get actually some additional algorithm and specific controls that are useful for Rolls applications just like the other ones we do for many other people.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. So it continues to be the situation that the OEM compressor makers really aren't providing the most efficient machine that they could provide? And you come along and make it that way, right?
componenttext: Okay. So it continues to be the situation that the OEM compressor makers really aren't providing the most efficient machine that they could provide? And you come along and make it that way, right?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: We can improve on what's out there, what they provided for this period of time. We would never argue against them. We love them as our customers and are prepared to sell even more to them sooner.
componenttext: We can improve on what's out there, what they provided for this period of time. We would never argue against them. We love them as our customers and are prepared to sell even more to them sooner.

componenttext: Brian, could you talk just a minute or 2 about the just the tone of business in Medical Scientific and maybe the outlook there? I mean, if I kind of do the math with the FX and make an assumption on Northern Digital, kind of low-single digit core local currency growth this quarter and we talked about strong backlog maybe entering the fourth quarter. But how do you feel about the tone of business there going forward with some of the funding issues?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, it's really been not bad at all. The situation is if you look at the life science CapEx-type companies out there from those that are reported, they've been up about 4% in the third quarter. We're doing better than that. The reality is that we had a
componenttext: Well, it's really been not bad at all. The situation is if you look at the life science CapEx-type companies out there from those that are reported, they've been up about 4% in the third quarter. We're doing better than that. The reality is that we had a very large order for Rugged Mobile, which reports in this segment. That was a turnkey situation and if you take that out in both equations, and then we have one particular customer in medical that buys our dosage pumps, normally, this is not -- it's a lumpy business but every once in a while, you get an exceptional order for multiple months and that happened in the third quarter last year. That's masking the strength there. The strength in medical is really a bit better than you're able to see in the aggregate numbers. So we also have really important family of products around couch tops, which we have been launching throughout the year. And they're in a bunch of different trial applications. People are quite bullish about that for 2012. So it's a little slower than it was. It's consistently been in the low double-digit arena. Now it's closer to sort of 10% growth. But it's nothing that -- we're not seeing any mega trend that would say there's a real problem in Medical. The camera businesses grew modestly, so they also kind of pulled down a little bit,  [indiscernible] that was spectacular.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on the industrial tech side, just to clarify your comments about Neptune. We had -- the business was flat in the U.S. but strong in Canada and Mexico in the quarter and the orders were plus 10% in the U.S. Is there a reason that you saw for
componenttext: Okay. And then on the industrial tech side, just to clarify your comments about Neptune. We had -- the business was flat in the U.S. but strong in Canada and Mexico in the quarter and the orders were plus 10% in the U.S. Is there a reason that you saw for the flatness in that third quarter in the U.S.? I mean, it sounds like is this a funding issue where orders were better than sales in the quarter or. . .

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, I don't think it is a funding issue. I think it's just a question of timing and the comparison to the prior year. If you kind of take a little bit of a wider lens to this, I mean Neptune, just if you excludes -- so we've got some very nice winds with
componenttext: No, I don't think it is a funding issue. I think it's just a question of timing and the comparison to the prior year. If you kind of take a little bit of a wider lens to this, I mean Neptune, just if you excludes -- so we've got some very nice winds with both the Canada project, which is continuing, which will give us in the neighborhood of $15 million, maybe a little bit more million dollars this year and double that next year. So that will continue to ramp up. We also had a nice win with some Mexico meters. Those meters, more standard meters, going into Mexico, which have a slightly different margin profile but still a nice win for us. But if you take a wider lens and look at just the U.S. for Neptune, really on the year-to-date basis, revenue was up kind of in a mid-single digit range and the orders continue to outpace sales. So, I mean, it's just a question of the confidence they have against the very strong third quarter last year but on the wider lens, looking year-to-date basis, we're still in a pretty good position there.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: I have a question, it's a slightly out in left field. You guys have done a good job managing through the '08, '09 recession in a considerable working capital terms, we're looking at strong organic growth. If we are going into a slow growth environment, co
componenttext: I have a question, it's a slightly out in left field. You guys have done a good job managing through the '08, '09 recession in a considerable working capital terms, we're looking at strong organic growth. If we are going into a slow growth environment, could you just walk us through the succession planning that you guys have at Roper? Are there anything on your contracts that sort of limit your term in office? And for Brian, and for John, thanks.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: You mean long-term contracts that we have with all of these customers?
componenttext: You mean long-term contracts that we have with all of these customers?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, no, management contracts.
componenttext: No, no, management contracts.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Oh, yes. We generally don't have contracts for people. We have long-term compensation programs for people. They're all involved with different forms of stock option and other stock criteria and then their cash bonus programs are related to improvement yea
componenttext: Oh, yes. We generally don't have contracts for people. We have long-term compensation programs for people. They're all involved with different forms of stock option and other stock criteria and then their cash bonus programs are related to improvement year-over-year in operating income. So if you think about going into any kind of a slow-growth environment, one of the reasons our people are so nimble in our opinion is that the only way they earn a bonus to drive continued performance is to get better in the new year than they were in the prior year. There's no sort of forgiveness for the fact that the market's difficult. So all these guys are prepared to be quite nimble. They have very strong operating people in all of those units and those people are -- they understand their compensation better than any of us do and I think we understand it quite well. So they're highly motivated about that and they have a very strong view of how stuff happens. And enterprise level, we're somewhat compensated the same way on a cash basis. So that sort of focuses attention here. We continue to add modestly to our corporate staff. We've got -- we've strengthened our legal area and tax area. We've brought in a couple of new executives this year that are dedicated to corporate development activity in software and medical orientation. So we really have the strongest team of people that we've ever had. For myself, I got a long-term vesting program on all my equity so that continues out to, geez, I don't know, 2014 or '15 or something. And I would expect that my program of one year updates would continue just like all [indiscernible] for quite some time.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: So there are no -- there's no mandatory retirement ages for senior executives?
componenttext: So there are no -- there's no mandatory retirement ages for senior executives?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: One of things about a company like us, we don't have a pension plan. So when you don't have a pension plan, it's pretty hard to have a mandatory retirement program. So we do not have a mandatory retirement program. I think the only that's speaks to that i
componenttext: One of things about a company like us, we don't have a pension plan. So when you don't have a pension plan, it's pretty hard to have a mandatory retirement program. So we do not have a mandatory retirement program. I think the only that's speaks to that is that our board has a mandatory retirement at age 74 and most of them are not yet in their 70s.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, but that's not for the CEO, CFO and anyone else?
componenttext: Okay, but that's not for the CEO, CFO and anyone else?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think you wouldn't be surprised to learn that when you're a technology company like we are, we're providing OEM technology to people, people have no interest in us telling intel inside unless they want to do that. So they guard their own end marke
componenttext: Well, I think you wouldn't be surprised to learn that when you're a technology company like we are, we're providing OEM technology to people, people have no interest in us telling intel inside unless they want to do that. So they guard their own end market brand situation carefully and we're there to protect them in that regard. So we don't provide information about who is incorporating our technology and it's almost always part of the agreement we have with anyone, anywhere. So that's -- it's our own terms, or the guts of a lot of people's businesses that you talk to routinely.

componenttext: The Roper Industries Third Quarter 2011 Financial Results Conference Call will now begin. Just a reminder, today's presentation is being recorded. At this time, I would like to turn the call over to Mr. John Humphrey, Chief Financial Officer. Please go ahead.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Vicki, and thank you all for joining us this morning as we discuss the results of our record third quarter. Joining me this morning is Brian Jellison, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Paul Soni, Vice President and Controller
componenttext:
Thank you, Vicki, and thank you all for joining us this morning as we discuss the results of our record third quarter. Joining me this morning is Brian Jellison, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Paul Soni, Vice President and Controller.
Earlier this morning, we issued a press release announcing our financial results. The press release also includes replay information for today's call. We have prepared slides to accompany today's call, which are available through the webcast and also available at our website at www.roperind.com.
Now if you'll please turn to Slide 2. We begin with our Safe Harbor statement. During the course of today's call, we'll be making forward-looking statements, which are subject to risks and uncertainties as described on this page and as detailed more fully in our SEC filings. You should listen to today's call in the context of that information.
And now if you'll please turn to Slide 3. I'll turn the call over to Brian Jellison, Roper's Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer. After his prepared remarks, we'll take questions from our telephone participants. Brian?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. Good morning, everybody. We'll start off with a quick overview of the Q3 financial results and then talk specifically about the segment performance and outlook for the fourth quarter, update you on our guidance summary and then open it up
componenttext:
Thank you, John. Good morning, everybody. We'll start off with a quick overview of the Q3 financial results and then talk specifically about the segment performance and outlook for the fourth quarter, update you on our guidance summary and then open it up to questions and answers. 
So first slide. If we look at the Q3 financial results, once again, they're an all-time record for any quarter in the history of the company, not just a record third quarter. Orders were at the highest level in history, sales, the same. Backlog, highest level, net earnings, a highest level, and operating and free cash flow in the quarter set a new standard for the company. Our total sales in the quarter were up 18% and organic sales were up 13%, which was frankly better than expected. 
Our book-to-bill was greater than one for the 9th straight quarter and our record backlog of $876 million is up $106 million from the third quarter a year ago. Operating margins were terrific throughout the enterprise, they were up 230 basis points so that operating margin was 23% of revenue in the quarter. Our EBITDA was $203 million in the quarter, a fairly astonishing number by any standard, and EBITDA margin was 28.6%. Our operating cash flow was 23% of sales at $167 million and our free cash flow was 22% of sales at $157 million.
Next slide. If you look at the income statement, you should see that bookings again were above 1, at 1.01. Net sales were, as we said, up 13% organically. Gross profit picked up 50 basis points from a year ago. Our operating income was up 30% from $128 million to $167 million, and margin at 23 %, up from 21.2% in the third quarter a year ago. Our tax rate was actually a headwind in the quarter year. In the third quarter last year, it's only 25.9%. As most of you would know, third quarter results tend to have whatever rollover there is in that 104A calculation for filing tax returns. This year, our tax rate was 27.7%, a 180 basis points increase over the prior year, which took a couple a pennies out of our results. 
Net earnings were $110 million, up 31% from the prior year and our diluted earnings per share were $1.12 versus $0.87.
Next slide. Free cash flow in the quarter was truly spectacular. 22% of revenue and 142% of net earnings, so it'd be the 14th consecutive year that our free cash flow has exceeded net earnings. And really, we had very strong execution throughout the family of businesses. And you can see the comparisons prior year here on the graph.
Next slide. We had quite substantial EBITDA gross. I'm not sure people caught up to just how much our trailing EBITDA continues to grow. We're up 33% in EBITDA over the prior year and our trailing 12 months EBITDA now ending the third quarter is $779 million. That's up from $585 million in the corresponding trailing 12-month period ended in the third quarter of '10, and up from $507 million in 2009. Part of the reason for that is continued margin expansion. Our EBITDA margins in 2009 were 24 % for that TTM period. In 2010, they were up 140 basis points to 25.9% and this year they've skyrocketed to 28 % from 25.9%.
Next slide. Our asset velocity performance continues to be best-in-class. You can see inventory has actually dropped to 7.4% from 8.9% just 2 years ago. Our receivables are down 200 basis points to 14.7% from 16.7%, just a terrific performance by all our field operating units around receivables. And payables and accruals have actually come down, or our numbers would be even more spectacular. So in total, when we look at the inventory plus receivables minus payables and accruals, we finished the quarter at 6 %. That's 240 basis points better than just 2 years ago. So our exceptional performance in that category continues.
Next slide. Here we look at our sort of balance sheet and financial position. We ended the quarter with $246 million in cash. Our trailing 12 months EBITDA is $779 million. Our gross debt number is $1,174,000,000. If you take that $246 million and cash away, you got net debt at $928 million. Shareholder equity continues to be strong there, in excess of $3 billion, meaning our net debt-to-net cap number is about 23%. Our gross debt-to-EBITDA is about 1.5x, so we have very ample capacity inside anything we'd like to do. And our EBITDA-to-interest coverage is over 12x. Now in the last 2 years, we invested $1.1 billion in transactions. But as you can see, the balance sheet is stronger than ever.
Next slide. So here we'll take a look at our segment performance and the outlook for the rest of the year. 
Next slide. Our Q3 segment performance was remarkably similar. You can see EBITDA margins in industrial, RF and medical all were 31%, and energy, they were 29%. The OP margins continue to march forward as we have revenue growth and we capture leverage associated with that and throughout the enterprise, we're very happy with the margin performance.
Next slide. If we go to the largest segment in the quarter was RF Technology. It had sales up 19%, operating profit was up 41% and the operating profit margin reached 23.8%, up 380 basis points from the corresponding period in the prior year. Orders exceeded revenue. If you look at the specific commentary here, by the way, the leverage there on incremental revenue was about 44%. So we had very strong growth throughout the segment, organic sales, up 15%. The software businesses had double-digit organic growth, with particular tribute to CBORD, who continues to have quite spectacular performance around Integrated Security Solutions that we provide the universities. That business has nearly doubled this year compared to last. Our Freight Matching business grew at a double-digit rate as we've got more new subscribers and their very favorable dynamics occurring in the spot market due to volatility in gasoline prices and driver shortages and truck shortages. 
Our Toll & Traffic Solutions business, which is less than half of the segment, we remind people, did well as a result of an upgrade where we're converting Puerto Rico from a coin-base technology to an electronic technology and we had strong tag shipments in several locations around the world.
In the fourth quarter, looking forward, we're going to continue to benefit from this electronic tolling project in Puerto Rico. Our iTrade business enters with a strong backlog and we expect double-digit growth and it will finally be showing up as organic growth here in the fourth quarter for us. The CBORD backlog remains strong enough to assure double-digit growth in the fourth quarter. We expect to get continued margin improvement, even given what we had here in the third quarter. We think we'll even do a bit better in the fourth quarter. And our Technolog operations in France, where we've been installing a system, we would hope that, that gets completed in the fourth quarter and then in 2012, that'll allow us to get our data services revenue, which comes in at lower revenue but much higher margins.
Next slide. Here, looking at the industrial technology segment, while we often focus on Neptune because it's traditionally been about half the segment, growth in the other areas is nothing short of spectacular. Here, orders were up substantially above the sales revenue of $185 million. Sales were up 15% from the prior year. Operating profit was up 16% and operating profit margin in the industrial businesses was 28.2%. 
Fluid handling continues to perform just in a very strong manner, driven really by all the shale, gas and oil activity that's occurring in Canada and the U.S. Lots of new customers and a lot of new applications. New products and strong end markets are also helping our material test business, which is off to a record year by a considerable margin. 
And then in Neptune in North American meter revenue was relatively flat, but we had strong growth in Mexico and Canada. Surprisingly, the U.S. order flow in the third quarter was up more than 10% in the U.S. We had a very successful launch of our low-profile, lead-free residential water meter. A lot of people have gone out and checked the Shed The Lead video that we have and it certainly created a lot of interest in our water meter business. 
So we look to Q4, we expect strong seasonality. Generally speaking, we had year-end buys from people in both this and the energy business and we haven't seen any trends that would indicate that would not occur again this year. Neptune is going to get double-digit growth, led by the Toronto installation activity, which is going to start to pick up in the fourth quarter and be substantially stronger in 2012. 
And then our favorable end markets are pretty much generally true in the -- so just so we are not doing well in the 30-plus percent leverage we got in Q3, we would hope it'll improve even a bit more in the rest of the year and next.
If we go next slide. If you look here at the Medical and Scientific Imaging segment, it was up 16% in revenue. Orders actually exceeded sales and orders were up sequentially from the second quarter. Operating profit was up 24% compared to the sales increase of 16%. So we had strong leverage here, about 34%. And the OP margin increased 150 basis points to 24.7%. Our high-end imaging solutions driven largely by Gatan's quantum and direct detection camera lines are continuing to perform in a fantastic way and we have a new product out there that's processing frame speeds at 83 gigabytes a second. I'm not sure anybody could relate to just exactly how fast that is, but it's leading-edge technology for the most supreme applications in the research area and has added substantially to our growth this year. 
The medical platform continues to perform well. The adoption rates for both Bladderscan and GlideScope continue to escalate. We continue to gain ground internationally in terms of consumables and our ultrasound business and our couch top patient positioning technology for the MRI processes is beginning to gain momentum. There's a lot of favorable papers, write-ups and comments about this, and we think it'll be a long-term winning proposition for the enterprise. 
In the third quarter, on an order comparison basis, we had very tough comps because of 2 things that happened last year. We do report our Rugged Mobile business in here, which is certainly not key to the enterprise but it had a particularly strong Q3 order for long-term delivery last year, which, of course, wouldn't have been repeated in any one quarter. So it's a new initiation of an order. And then we had very strong dosage delivery business last year, and this year was more normalized. So both of that created a bit a headwind in terms of comps. But if you mask, take that away, the book-to-bill was above one, sequentially higher than the second quarter, and our backlog is strong so we don't expect any difficulty here.
In the fourth quarter, we wind up, of course, with record backlog entering the quarter. So that kind of assures our shipment pattern should be fine. We expect to have continued growth in medical because the patient treatment technologies that were involved and our continuing to grow. We have a higher fourth quarter because Northern Digital, which was acquired, will begin to kick in. It has traditionally strong seasonality in the fourth quarter and we haven't seen anything that wouldn't suggest that will occur here.
Next slide. Here when we get to energy systems and controls, you can see once again very strong performance. Sales were up 22%. Orders were just slightly ahead of sales, up 12%. Operating profit was up 35% and our OP margins expanded 250 basis points to 25.7%. Growth again is led by the continued development of the diesel engine safety system technology and that continues to get this U.S. and North American shale activity. We've got some new engine OEMs that are building the technology into their platforms and that helps as well. We had a record Q3 in terms of our instrument sales around the refinery business, so that seems to be picking up steam. It had been slow. It had been much better this year, but still relatively slow. One of the very few businesses that's not back to the 2008 results and now that's largely there. 
We had an expansion in our Alpha, and Viatran and Dynisco family of businesses around sensor technologies. They've been up over 30% here for instrumentation to measure composites and process manufacturing. And just excellent execution throughout the segment with the exception of our nuclear techs business, which has been very soft due to the nuclear plant shutdowns around the world. But fortunately, it's not a big piece of the total. 
In the fourth quarter, we will benefit from an acquisition that we made right at the end of the third quarter called United Controls. United Controls is a small business in the Midwest, which has a large OEM component with Rolls-Royce. It's got great field service, technical support and its technology is very complementary to our compressor control business. We've done very little historically with Rolls-Royce and so this gives us a new partner in effect to provide field service and aftermarket application for technology improvements. And it certainly expands our OEM channel access. 
In the oil and gas area, the trends just continue to perform exceptionally well and there's no downturn of any kind expected this year or early next. And seasonality here has always been very important. At fourth quarter, there's a lot of MRO purchases that tend to get done in the fourth quarter with residual budgets, but we expect that would continue this year. And we also think margins in the segment will expand in the fourth quarter over where they were reported in the third.
Given all that, we look now to guidance update, next slide. The guidance, we're increasing our full year guidance from $4.20 to $4.30 to $4.29 to $4.33. Now we started out this year with guidance at $3.82 to $4.02. And when we look cumulatively, we've actually now increased our low-end guidance by $0.47. So at $4.29 to $4.33, that results in Q4 at $1.18 to $1.22. And our full year operating cash flow will exceed $575 million on that revenue.
Next slide. If you look at a summary here before we get into the Q&A period, what we have is the best quarter in the history of the company. It's the highest level of sales orders, backlog, net earnings, operating and free cash flow ever. Organic sales came in at plus 13%, largely driven by new products and new applications to existing customers and then to favorable niche markets. We're really not seeing any slowdown in any activity in any of things that we might consider to be bellwether items that would say things are getting slower. We're just -- we're not seeing that. Very broad-based momentum as we entered the fourth quarter, which has allowed us to increase our guidance. Our gross margin is at 53.7%, certainly best-in-class. Operating margin is at 23.5%, with 36% overall leverage a new revenue, again, I think probably best-in-class. Operating cash flow at 23% of sales is nothing short of spectacular. And really, a new milestone for us, it's just as we've said, I don't think people are focused on just how much our EBITDA is growing. But our cash flow, our operating cash flow now in the last 2 years has exceeded $1 billion for the first time in our history. And if you think about those acquisitions in the last 2 years at $1.1 billion and cash flow over $1 billion, and we give you some idea about our capacity in transactions looking forward and the cash machine that we've created here. So with that, I think we're ready for questions, John.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2011
